(1)  A person who fails to sign an acknowledgment of receipt of a notice of civil infraction is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(2)  Any person willfully violating his or her written and signed promise to appear in court or his or her written and signed promise to respond to a notice of civil infraction is guilty of a misdemeanor regardless of the disposition of the notice of civil infraction. A written promise to appear in court or written promise to respond to the notice of civil infraction may be complied with by an appearance by counsel. 
(3)  A person who willfully fails to pay a monetary penalty or to perform community service as required by a court under this chapter may be found in contempt of court as provided in RCW chapter 7.21. 
(Ord. No. V-36, § 14(1.27.120), 3-23-2010) 
1.27.130 - Certificate of correction. 
    At the request of a person responsible, the code enforcement officer will re-inspect to determine if correction of the violation has been accomplished. If so, the officer will sign and provide to such person responsible a certificate of correction. If at least 48 hours prior to the hearing on the infraction, the person responsible presents a certificate of correction to the municipal court, the infraction will be dismissed with the exception of fees associated with handling and processing the infraction. 
(Ord. No. V-36, § 15(1.27.130), 3-23-2010) 
1.27.140 - Remedies not exclusive. 
    The levy of a notice of violation or civil infraction is not exclusive and does not preclude other remedies for violations of the Municipal Code, such as, but not limited to, revocation of license or permit, collection of penalties and interest, suspension of municipal service and abatement of nuisance. 
(Ord. No. W-28, § 4, 3-11-2014; Ord. No. V-36, § 16(1.27.140), 3-23-2010) 
1.27.145 - Liability and defenses of responsible person. 
(1)  Who must comply . The obligation for compliance with the Cheney City Code, engineering and design standards, permits, approvals, conditions, rules, policies, correction notices, stop work orders, emergency orders, or notices of violation issued by the city is upon the property owner(s), occupant(s), applicant or person who is responsible for compliance with the matters set forth above. 
(2)  Liability . The director, his designee, or an enforcement officer may take, in whole or in part, actions against any responsible person. All applicable civil penalties may be imposed against each responsible person(s). 
(3)  Defenses . A responsible person shall not be liable under this section when the responsible person proves, by a preponderance of the evidence, one of the following: 
(A)  The violation was caused solely by an act of God; 
(B)  The violation was caused solely by another responsible person over whom such responsible person had no authority or control, and such person could not have reasonably prevented the violation; 
(C)  The violation was caused solely by a prior owner or occupant and such person took possession of the subject property without knowledge of the violation, after using reasonable efforts to identify the same; provided the responsible person shall be liable for all continuing, recurrent, or new violations after becoming the owner or occupant of the subject property; or 
(D)  The responsible person implemented and maintained all appropriate improvements, facilities to receive city services, drainage control facilities, treatment facilities, flow control facilities, erosion and sediment controls, source controls, and best management practices identified in engineering standards, permits or other approvals, rules promulgated by the director, in manuals published by the Washington State Departments of Ecology and Health, correction notices, stop work orders, or as otherwise identified and required by the director in writing. 
(Ord. No. W-28, § 5, 3-11-2014) 
1.27.150 - Severability. 
    The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this chapter or its application to any person or circumstance is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, the remainder of this chapter shall not as a result of said section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase be held unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. V-36, § 17(1.27.150), 3-23-2010) 
CHAPTER 1.28 - NOTICE AND ORDER OF CORRECTION-BUILDING CODE 

1.28.010 - Notice and order of correction. 
    The enforcement officer of the city shall be authorized to issue a notice and order of correction to require compliance with any provision of the following titles of the Cheney Municipal Code: 
(1)  Title 10, Environmental Regulations; 
(2)  Title 12, Streets and Sidewalks; 
(3)  Title 18, Fire Code; 
(4)  Title 19, Building and Construction; 
(5)  Title 20, Manufactured Home Parks; 
(6)  Title 21, Zoning; 
(7)  Title 22, Subdivisions; or 
(8)  Title 23, Development Code Administration. 
(Ord. No. T-43, § 1(part), 2003) 
1.28.020 - Contents and service of the notice and order of correction. 
    The notice and order of correction shall contain: 
(1)  The Code section(s) deemed to be in noncompliance or in violation; 
(2)  The city's reasons or basis for the noncompliance or violation determination; 
(3)  The name of the board or city body authorized to render a reasonable interpretation of the Cheney Municipal Code section(s) in question; and 
(4)  The place and date any appeal must be filed. 
The notice and order of correction shall be served in person or by regular U.S. mail with postage prepaid, and if served by U.S. mail, the date of service shall be three days after the written notice and order of correction is mailed by the enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. T-43, § 1(part), 2003) 
1.28.030 - Appeal; reasonable interpretation. 
(a)  Any person served with a notice and order of correction may appeal the enforcement officer's determination of a city ordinance, by requesting a reasonable interpretation of the Code section cited in the notice and order. A written request for a reasonable interpretation, setting forth all procedural and substantive exceptions to the notice and order shall be filed with the office of the city clerk within 21 days of the service of the notice and order of correction. Any procedural or substantive exception not listed in the appeal shall be deemed waived. A failure to file a written request for a reasonable interpretation of the Code provision, within the 21 days set forth in this section, shall be conclusive that the Code interpretation of the enforcement officer is correct. 
(b)  The reasonable interpretation of language in a city ordinance, by the reviewing body, shall be deemed a final order and binding on the parties. However, nothing in this section shall allow the reviewing body to determine the issue of the infraction liability, which is the sole duty and responsibility of the court. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall authorize a board or a city body to give a reasonable interpretation of a state statute. Any dispute concerning a reasonable interpretation of language in a state statute shall be contested during the infraction hearing in the court. 
(Ord. No. T-43, § 1(part), 2003) 
1.28.040 - Issuance of civil infraction. 
    After a reasonable interpretation of the Code sections has been issued or waived, the building official shall: 
(1)  Rescind, amend or correct the notice and order of correction, if the reasonable Code interpretation, by the reviewing body, does not support the original order of correction; or 
(2)  If the reasonable Code interpretation is waived or supports the order of correction, the building official may file a civil infraction under the provisions of Chapter 7.80 of the Revised Code of Washington with the Cheney Municipal Court. The notice of infraction shall be served in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. T-23, § 1(part), 2003) 
1.28.050 - Civil infraction; penalty. 
    In addition to any other penalty provided by law and unless otherwise provided, every person who fails, refuses, or neglects to comply with the notice and order of correction, after obtaining or waving the reasonable interpretation by the reviewing body, shall be deemed to have committed a Class 1 civil infraction. The maximum penalty and the default amount for committing a Class 1 civil infraction shall be $250.00, not including statutory assessments. Each day's failure to comply with the order of correction constitutes a separate infraction. 
(Ord. No. T-43, § 1(part), 2003) 
1.28.060 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall be applicable to the provisions of Chapter 1.28: 
    The term "building official" shall include that person designated by the mayor of the City of Cheney as the city's building official. 
    The term "enforcement officer" shall include the director of community development, director of public works, fire chief, building official, code enforcement officer, deputy code enforcement officer, and the city administrator or any other person designated such authority by the mayor. 
    The term "person" shall include an individual, corporation, joint venture, partnership, estate, trust, limited liability company, association, government, governmental subdivision, agency, instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity. 
(Ord. No. U-95, § 4, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. T-43, § 1(part), 2003) 
CHAPTER 1.30 - COUNTY CODE CHAPTERS 5.04 AND 5.12 ADOPTED BY REFERENCE 

1.30.010 - County Code chapter 5.04 and 5.12 adopted by reference. 
    Adoption by reference and amendment to CMC 1.30.010 . Pursuant to RCW 35A.11.020 and 35A.12.140, the city adopts by reference Chapters 5.04 (see Resolution No. 13-1198 adopted December 17, 2013) and 5.12 of the Spokane County Code, both of which are attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by this reference as presently constituted or hereinafter amended as the animal control regulations of the City of Cheney. Unless the context requires otherwise, references to Spokane County shall be construed to mean the City of Cheney and references to County staff, unless the context indicates otherwise, shall refer to the city administrator or designee. 
(Ord. No. W-26, § 2, 2-20-2014; Ord. No. T-83, § 1, 2005) 
1.30.020 - Modifications of chapter 5.04 authorized. 
    Chapter 5.04 of the Spokane County Code, as adopted by the City of Cheney, shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  Any reference to "Spokane County" or "county" means "City of Cheney;" 
(2)  "County current expense fund" means "city general fund;" 
(3)  "Board of hearing officers" means "a hearing officer designated by the mayor;" 
(4)  "Board of county commissioners" means "city council or their designee;" 
(5)  "Board's decision" means "city council's decision;" 
(6)  "County sheriff" means "chief of police of the City of Cheney;" 
(7)  "Spokane County district court" means "Cheney Municipal Court;" and 
(8)  Any reference to the "unincorporated areas of Spokane County means the "incorporated area of the City of Cheney." 
(Ord. No. T-83, § 2, 2005) 
1.30.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-26, § 2, adopted Feb. 20, 2014, repealed § 1.30.030, which pertained to the adoption by reference of County Code Ch. 5.12 and derived from Ord. No. T-89, § 1, adopted in 2005. 
1.30.040 - Modifications of chapter 5.12 authorized. 
    Chapter 5.12 of the Spokane County Code, as adopted by the City of Cheney, shall be modified as follows: 
(1)  Any reference to "Spokane County" or "county" means "City of Cheney;" 
(2)  "County current expense fund" means "city general fund;" 
(3)  "Board of hearing officers" means "a hearing officer designated by the mayor;" 
(4)  "Board of county commissioners" means "city council or their designee;" 
(5)  "Board's decision" means "city council's decision;" 
(6)  "County sheriff" means "chief of police of the City of Cheney;" 
(7)  "Spokane County district court" means "Cheney Municipal Court;" and 
(8)  Any reference to the "unincorporated areas of Spokane County" means the "incorporated area of the City of Cheney." 
(Ord. No. T-89, § 2, 2005) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
CHAPTER 2.04 - TIME AND PLACE OF COUNCIL MEETINGS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
For statutory provisions regarding council meetings see RCW 35A.12.110. 

2.04.010 - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the city council shall be held in the council room of City Hall, 609 Second Street, in the City of Cheney, Washington, on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month at the hour of 6:00 p.m. Any regular meeting falling on a legal holiday shall be convened on the next business day. 
(Ord. No. E-32, § 1, 1957; Ord. No. S-66, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. T-60, § 1, 2004) 
2.04.020 - Special meetings. 
    All special meetings of the city council shall be convened by the mayor at any time. 
CHAPTER 2.08 - BOARD OF PARK COMMISSIONERS 

2.08.010 - Created. 
    A board of park commissioners is created and established. The board shall consist of seven members, who shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council from individuals on the basis of their recognized fitness. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 1, 1993) 
2.08.020 - Term of office-Filling vacancies. 
A.  The members of the board shall hold office for a period of three years. 
B.  An appointee shall continue in office until the successor to the position is appointed. All vacancies on the board shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, to serve for the unexpired term. Members of the board shall reside within the boundaries of Cheney School District 360. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 2, 1993) 
2.08.030 - Officers-Quorum-Meetings. 
A.  Officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary and such other officers as may be necessary. Officers shall be elected in January of each year. A recording secretary may be allowed by the board either from within or without its own membership. It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside at all meetings of the board and of the secretary to keep official minutes of all meetings and of all proceedings of the board unless a recording secretary is appointed. 
B.  A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and a majority vote of those present shall be necessary to carry any proposition. 
C.  Meetings of the board shall be scheduled at least once each month. The board shall fix the time and place of its meetings. The meetings of the board shall be public. Special meetings of the board may be called by the chairman or upon notice signed by four members of the board. 
D.  The board may adopt rules and regulations for the conduct of its business. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 3, 1993) 
2.08.040 - Removal of board member. 
    Any member of the board may be removed from office by the mayor with the consent of the city council following due process for cause. The unexcused absence of any member from two consecutive regular meetings of the board may result in the board member's removal upon request by the mayor and confirmation by council. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 4, 1993) 
2.08.050 - Powers and duties generally. 
    The board shall have all of the powers and perform all the duties necessary and incidental to its operation. The board shall have power to conduct any form of recreation or cultural activity that will employ the leisure time of the people in a constructive and wholesome manner, and shall have care and supervision of all parks belonging to the city. The board shall act in advisory capacity to the mayor and city council and make recommendations relating to park property and programs including but not limited to the following: 
A.  The development, acquisition, disposal, maintenance and operation of park property, improvements and equipment, including community buildings and recreational facilities; 
B.  The management, supervision and use of park property and facilities by persons and groups for passive and active recreation which may include organized programs, events and activities; 
C.  Permitting, installing and maintaining any statuary, monuments, or works of art presented to the city for use or exhibit in parks or recreation areas; 
D.  Soliciting and receiving on behalf of the city any gifts or bequests of money or other personal property or any donation to be applied, principal and interest, for either temporary or permanent use for playgrounds, parks, or other recreational purposes, the same to be deposited with the city treasurer to be used exclusively for park and recreational purposes; 
E.  Granting privileges to be exercised on parks and recreation property of the city, the revenue from which shall be used for parks and recreational purposes; provided, however, that no concession shall be granted for the sale of any intoxicating liquors, beer, and/or wine in any public park: 
1.  The director of parks and recreation is authorized to issue licenses and permits on terms established by the board, subject to approval by the mayor; 
F.  Implementing and monitoring grants, contracts, leases, and licenses for the use and benefit of park property or facilities; 
G.  Making reasonable rules and regulations for the use, and management of park and recreation facilities of the city, including the power to fix terms and charges for the use of any municipally owned or controlled park or recreation facility; 
H.  Doing all other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient management and control of the parks and recreation facilities of the city. 
(Ord. No. W-39, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. P-68, § 5, 1993) 
2.08.060 - Budget and fiscal powers and duties. 
A.  The board shall, upon a schedule created by the office of the mayor, review the parks and recreation budget as created by the parks and recreation department staff and make recommendations on such budget to the office of the mayor and city council. 
B.  Expenditures of the funds appropriated for park and recreation purposes and purchases with such funds shall be made as per city policy as provided in section 2.40.030 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 6, 1993) 
2.08.070 - Rules and regulations-Promulgation and effect-Violation. 
A.  Rules and regulations adopted by the board under the authority granted by this chapter shall be promulgated by filing a copy thereof with the city clerk, by posting a copy thereof on the bulletin board in the lobby of the city hall for not less than five days prior to the regulation taking effect, and by having a copy available for public review in the parks and recreation office. 
B.  Any person who shall willfully and intentionally violate any such rule or regulation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 7, 1993) 
2.08.080 - Compensation. 
    The members of the board shall receive no salary; however, when the board determines that it is desirable for members to attend a state, regional, or national conference dealing with park and recreation issues, it may recommend the attendance and payment of the actual expenses involved in attending such meetings through requests in the annual budget. If approved in the annual budget, reimbursements for these expenditures shall be allowed as per the same policies as for all other city travel. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 8, 1993) 
2.08.090 - Park and recreation employees. 
    The mayor shall be the appointing and discharging authority for the employees of the city engaged in park and recreation activities. The board may make recommendations to the mayor concerning the appointment and discharge of such employees. 
(Ord. No. P-68, § 9, 1993) 
2.08.100 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-39, adopted May 27, 2014, repealed § 2.08.100, which pertained to board decisions and appeals to city council and derived from Ord. No. P-68, § 10, adopted in 1993. 
2.08.110 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-39, adopted May 27, 2014, repealed § 2.08.110, which pertained to an effective period and derived from Ord. No. P-68, § 11, adopted in 1993. 
CHAPTER 2.09 - BOARD OF YOUTH COMMISSIONERS 

2.09.010 - Created. 
    A Board of Cheney Youth Commissioners is created and established. The Board shall consist of 13 voting members. All positions shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council from individuals on the basis that they are currently enrolled in grades 6 through 12 and residing within the boundaries of the Cheney School District 360 during the member's term. 
(Ord. No. T-69, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. U-31, § 1(part), 2006; Ord. No. V-32, § 1(2.09.010), 12-8-2009) 
2.09.020 - Term of office-Filling vacancies. 
(a)  Each member shall serve a term of two years, except for persons appointed during their senior year at Cheney School District 360, in which such person shall serve a term of one year; 
(b)  An appointee shall continue in office until the successor to the position is duly appointed. All vacancies on the board shall be filled in the manner as the original appointment, to serve for the unexpired term; 
(c)  Any member of the board may be removed from office by the mayor with consent of the city council following due process for cause; 
(d)  An unexcused absence of any member from three consecutive regular meetings of the board may result in the board member's removal upon request by the mayor and confirmation by city council; 
(e)  Term of office shall run from July 1 to June 30 of each calendar year; 
(Ord. No. T-69, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. U-31, § 1(part), 2006; Ord. No. V-32, § 1(2.09.020), 12-8-2009) 
2.09.030 - Officers-Quorum-Meetings. 
(a)  Officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, secretary, and other officers as may be necessary. Officers shall be elected in the first scheduled meeting in October of each year. A recording secretary may be allowed by the board either from within or without its own membership. It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside at all meetings of the board and of the secretary to keep official meetings and of all proceedings of the board unless a recording secretary is appointed; 
(b)  A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum, seven voting members for the transaction of business. Alternates may fill in for regular voting members who are not present. A majority vote is 50 percent plus one of the members present shall be necessary to carry any proposition; 
(c)  Meetings of the board shall be held twice each month on the first and third Mondays. Alternate schedules may be set by the board during times of holidays and summer vacations; 
(d)  Special meetings of the board may be called by the chairman or upon notice signed by four members of the board; 
(e)  The board may adopt rules and regulations for the conduct of its business; 
(f)  All meetings shall be open to the public; 
(g)  The chief administrative officer of the youth commission shall be the parks and recreation director or under their supervision a designee who shall be appointed to the position by, and serve at the pleasure of, the mayor. 
(h)  The youth commission is authorized to hold joint meetings with one or more city boards or agencies in any combination. 
(Ord. No. T-69, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. U-31, § 1(part), 2006; Ord. No. V-32, § 1(2.09.030), 12-8-2009) 
2.09.040 - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The board shall have all of the powers and perform all the duties necessary and incidental to its operation. The board shall have the power to conduct any form of recreation or cultural activity that will employ the leisure time of the youth in a constructive and wholesome manner. The youth commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the mayor, the city council, and the park board. The principal functions of the youth commission shall be to prepare a comprehensive plan for anticipating and influencing the desires of the youth of the community, and to make its recommendations thereon to the city council. 
(b)  Officers of the board shall be a chair, vice chair, and secretary selected by a majority vote of the youth commission and their duties are: 
(1)  The chair shall appoint any special committees and the chair in his or her absence; 
(2)  The chair is empowered to call additional special meetings as needed, with three days' notice; 
(3)  The chair shall prepare the agenda for each meeting from items submitted by the youth commission members, staff, and the public; 
(4)  The chair shall provide annual updates to the park board and the mayor, and other groups as desired; 
(5)  The vice chair shall perform the duties of the chair in his or her absence; 
(6)  When necessary, the vice chair shall assume any duties assigned by the chair; 
(7)  The vice chair shall succeed to the office of the chair in the event the chair steps down during an unexpired term; 
(8)  The secretary shall record and prepare minutes of all regular and special meetings of the youth commission; 
(9)  The secretary shall keep a record of attendance of commission members of the youth commission meetings; 
(10)  The secretary shall maintain all records of the advisory committee; 
(11)  The secretary will file the original copy of the minutes when they have been approved by the board and signed by the chair with the city clerk; 
(Ord. No. T-69, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. U-31, § 1(part), 2006; Ord. No. V-32, § 1(2.09.040), 12-8-2009) 
CHAPTER 2.10 - CHENEY PUBLIC LIBRARY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. No. F 81. 

2.10.010 - Cheney Library Advisory Board established. 
    There is hereby established the Cheney Library Advisory Board to consist of five members, who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council. 
(Ord. No. R-69, § 1(part), 1999) 
2.10.020 - Membership, qualifications, term of appointment and vacancies. 
(a)  The initial members of the board shall be the members of the board of trustees of the Cheney Public Library and each person shall serve as a member of the board until the expiration of the term as a trustee. Thereafter, members of the board shall be residents of the city, or other resident within Spokane County and shall be persons of good character and learning with an interest in promoting library services for all people qualified to use such services in the city. 
(b)  A new member shall be appointed to the board for a term of two years, provided the appointment shall be varied as may be necessary so as not to have more than two member's terms expire in any one year. 
(c)  Vacancies on the board shall be filled by mayoral appointment as soon as a qualified member is available, and pending appointment and confirmation, the mayor may appoint a member pro tem. 
(Ord. No. R-69, § 1(part), 1999) 
2.10.030 - Duties of the board-Chairman of the board. 
(a)  The board shall meet at least annually and shall make such investigation as it deems proper in order to advise the city council as to the status of library services in the city and to recommend changes to existing services and in all respects advise the council upon matters affecting and relating to library services. The board shall consider all library services available in the city and in particular services provided by the Spokane County Library District. 
(b)  The board may adopt bylaws to regulate the conduct of its affairs. 
(c)  Annually, the board shall elect from its members, one person to serve as chairman. 
(Ord. No. R-69, § 1(part), 1999) 
2.10.040 - Budget. 
    Members of the board shall serve without pay, provided the board may request council to provide for payment of expenses in the annual budget of the city. 
(Ord. No. R-69, § 1(part), 1999) 
CHAPTER 2.12 - RETIREMENT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State wide city employees' retirement system-See generally chapter 41.44. 

2.12.010 - Participation in state system-Employees covered. 
    The City of Cheney has elected and does hereby elect to participate in the statewide system for pension, relief, disability and retirement for city employees provided by chapter 71, Laws of 1947. All employees and officers of the city shall be included in the system, except members of the fire department. Provided that no elective official shall be included unless the official so elects and files a written notice of the election with the board of trustees of the pension system and with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. B94, § 1, 12-6-1949) 
2.12.020 - Number of employees covered. 
    The number of employees and officials, aside from elective officials, who shall be included as members of the pension system is approximately 20. 
(Ord. No. B94, § 2, 12-6-1949) 
2.12.030 - Transmission of evidence to state. 
    A certified copy of this chapter shall be transmitted to the board of trustees of the statewide system as evidence of the election of the city to join such pension system. 
(Ord. No. B94, § 3, 12-6-1949) 
2.12.040 - Basis for prior service credit. 
    The basis for prior service credit shall be 1 33/100 percent of final compensation, known as "full prior service credit." 
(Ord. No. B94, § 4, 12-6-1949) 
CHAPTER 2.14 - FIRE DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. No. I-75. 

2.14.010 - Creation of department. 
    There is created a department of the City of Cheney to be known as the Cheney Fire Department. It shall be comprised of full-paid and part-paid firefighters and such other employees as the city council may provide. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
2.14.020 - Appointment. 
A.  Full-paid firefighters shall be appointed by the mayor, in accordance with the provisions of sections 2.50.460, et seq., of the Cheney City Code and the rules and regulations of the Cheney Civil Service Commission. 
B.  Part-paid firefighters and officers shall be appointed by the mayor upon recommendation of the fire chief in accordance with the rules and regulations of the City of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
2.14.040 - Duties of officers. 
A.  The fire chief is the chief executive officer of the fire department, having authority to control, manage and direct all officers and men subject to the authority and direction of the mayor. 
B.  Officers and firefighters of the department shall perform such duties as may be prescribed by the chief, and by departmental regulations. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
2.14.050 - Building inspections. 
    Building inspections shall be made by the department officers, in accordance with the Cheney Fire Code, to determine the arrangement of buildings with respect to one another, to familiarize themselves with the inside of every building and its contents, to study the best methods of attacking every building in case of fire, and to note all new obstructions. The fire chief and the other officers of the department are empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making such inspections. Records shall be kept of all inspections including notes and sketches. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976; Ord. No. S-91, § 1, 2002) 
2.14.060 - Retirement benefits-Entitlement. 
    All part-paid firemen shall be entitled to the benefits of the death and disability and pension and retirement provision provided by RCW chapter 41.24. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
2.14.070 - Retirement benefits-Enrollment. 
    The city finance director shall be the secretary-treasurer of the board of trustees created by RCW chapter 41.24 and shall enroll each fireman under the death and disability provisions of said chapter; and when requested in writing by a fireman shall enroll each fireman making the request under the pension and retirement provisions of said chapter. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
2.14.080 - Retirement benefits-Number of firemen. 
    The part-paid fire department personnel of the city shall not at any time exceed 25 firemen for each 1,000 of population or fraction thereof of the city's population; provided that at no time shall the membership of the fire department be less than 15 firemen. 
(Ord. No. J-47, § 2(part), 1976) 
CHAPTER 2.20 - PLANNING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
For statutory provisions on the creation of city planning commissions, see RCW 35.63.020 and 35.63.030; for provisions authorizing code cities to provide by ordinance for a planning agency, see RCW 35A.63.020. 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. Nos. I-54, H-24, H-15, D-31. 

2.20.010 - Created-Members' appointment, term, vacancies. 
A.  The creation of the city planning commission by Ordinance No. D-31 enacted March 16, 1954, is confirmed and ratified. 
B.  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, the city planning commission shall consist of seven members who shall be selected as follows: All seven members shall be appointed by the mayor for a four-year term on confirmation by the city council. 
C.  Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of terms shall be filled for unexpired terms. Members may be removed, after public hearing, by the mayor, with the approval of the city council for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The members shall be selected without respect to political affiliations and they shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977; Ord. No. P-41, § 1, 1992) 
2.20.015 - Chief administrative officer. 
    The chief administrative officer of the planning commission shall be the planning coordinator who shall be appointed to the position by, and serve at the pleasure of, the mayor. 
(Ord. No. L-18, § 2, 1982; Ord. No. P-41, § 2, 1992) 
2.20.020 - Power and duties generally. 
    The planning commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the mayor and the city council. The principal functions of the planning commission shall be to prepare a comprehensive plan for anticipating and influencing the orderly and coordinated development of land and building uses of the city and its environs; to recommend to the city council the division of the city into appropriate zones, a map of such zones to be known as the zoning map, and regulations providing for the use of land, buildings, and structures, size of yards, courts, open spaces, density of population, ratio of land area to the area of buildings and structures, setbacks, area required for off-street parking, and such other standards, requirements, regulations, and procedures as are appropriately related thereto; to recommend to the city council regulations related to the approval or disapproval of plats, subdivisions, and dedications; and to examine proposed plats, subdivisions and dedications and make its recommendations thereon to the city council. The planning commission is authorized to hold joint meetings with one or more city or county planning agencies in any combination. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
For statutory grant of power, see RCW 35.63.060. 
2.20.030 - Recommendations to council-Ordinances. 
    The city council may refer to the planning commission, for its recommendation and report, any ordinance, resolution or other proposal relating to any of the matters and subjects referred to in titles 21 and 22 of the Cheney City Code, and the commission shall promptly report to the council thereon, making such recommendations and giving such counsel as it may deem proper in the premises. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.040 - Recommendations to council-Additions and dedications. 
    All plats or plans of subdivisions of land within the city or proposed additions, as well as dedications of streets and alleys, offered to the city council for acceptance, shall first be submitted to the planning commission for its recommendation and report, which report shall be made to the city council within 30 days after submission or at such earlier date as the council shall direct. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.050 - Secretary. 
    The planning commission may designate one of its members to act as secretary without salary, or if requested by the commission, the mayor shall designate a member of the paid staff of the city to serve as such secretary. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.060 - Quorum. 
    A majority of the membership of the planning commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Any action taken by a majority of those present when those present and voting constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting of the planning commission shall be deemed and taken as the action of the commission. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.070 - Comprehensive plan-Required elements. 
    The planning commission shall prepare a comprehensive plan, which may be prepared as a whole or in successive parts, for anticipating and influencing the orderly and coordinated development of land and building uses of the City of Cheney and its environs. It shall consist of a map or maps, diagrams, charts, reports and descriptions and explanatory text or other devices and materials to express, explain or depict the elements of the plan; and it shall include a recommended plan, scheme or design for each of the following elements: 
(a)  A land-use element that designates the proposed general distribution, general location, and extent of the uses of land. These uses may include, but are not limited to, agricultural, residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, educational, public, and other categories of public and private uses of land. The land-use elements shall also include estimates of future population growth in, and statements of recommended standards of population density and building intensity for, the area covered by the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  A circulation element consisting of the general location, alignment, and extent of existing and proposed major thoroughfares, major transportation routes, and major terminal facilities, all of which shall be correlated with the land-use element of the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.080 - Comprehensive plan-Optional elements. 
    The comprehensive plan may include also any or all of the following optional elements, but is not limited to them: 
(a)  A conservation element for the conservation, development and utilization of natural resources; 
(b)  An open space, park, and recreation element; 
(c)  A transportation element showing a comprehensive system of surface, air, and water transportation routes and facilities; 
(d)  A public-use element showing general locations, designs, and arrangements of public buildings and uses; 
(e)  A public utilities element showing general plans for public and franchised services and facilities; 
(f)  A redevelopment or renewal element showing plans for the redevelopment or renewal of slum and blighted areas; 
(g)  An urban design element for general organization of the physical parts of the urban landscape. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.090 - Comprehensive plan-Notice and hearing. 
    After preparing the comprehensive plan, or successive parts thereof, as the case may be, the planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing on the comprehensive plan or successive part. Notice of the time, place, and purpose of such public hearing shall be given by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation delivered in the city at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. Continued hearings may be held at the discretion of the planning commission but no additional notices need be published. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.100 - Comprehensive plan-Forwarding to city council. 
    Upon completion of the hearing or hearings on the comprehensive plan or successive parts thereof, the planning commission, after making such changes as it deems necessary following such hearing, shall transmit a copy of its recommendations for the comprehensive plan, or successive parts thereof, to the city council through the mayor's office, who shall acknowledge receipt thereof and direct the clerk to certify thereon the date of receipt. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.110 - Comprehensive plan-Approval by city council. 
    Within 60 days from its receipt of the recommendation for the comprehensive plan, as above set forth, the city council at a public meeting shall consider the same. The city council within 120 days from receipt of the recommendation of the planning commission shall vote to approve or disapprove or to modify and approve, as modified, the comprehensive plan or to refer it back to the planning commission for further proceedings, in which case the city council shall specify the time within which the planning commission shall report back to the city council its findings and recommendations on the matters referred to it. The final form and content of the comprehensive plan shall be determined by the city council. An affirmative vote of not less than a majority of total members of the city council shall be required for adoption of a resolution to approve the plan or its parts. The comprehensive plan, or its successive parts, as approved by the city council, shall be filed with the city clerk and shall by available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.120 - Comprehensive plan-Amendments and modifications. 
    All amendments, modifications, or alterations in the comprehensive plan or any part thereof shall be processed in the same manner as set forth in sections 2.20.090 through 2.20.110. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.130 - Comprehensive plan-Effect. 
    From the date of approval by the city council, the comprehensive plan, its parts and modifications thereof, shall serve as a basic source of reference for future administrative action; provided that the comprehensive plan shall not be construed as a regulation of property rights or land uses; provided further, that no procedural irregularity or informality in the consideration, hearing, and development of the comprehensive plan or a part thereof, or any of its elements, shall affect the validity of any zoning ordinance or amendment thereto enacted by the city council after the approval of the comprehensive plan. 
    The comprehensive plan shall be consulted as a preliminary to the establishment, improvement, abandonment, or vacation of any street, park, public way, public building, or public structure, and no dedication of any street or other area for public use shall be accepted by the city council until the location, character, extent, and effect thereof shall have been considered by the planning commission with reference to the comprehensive plan. The city council shall specify the time within which the planning commission shall report and make a recommendation with respect thereto. Recommendations of the planning commission shall be advisory only. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
2.20.140 - Comprehensive plan-Continued study. 
    The planning commission will continually review and recommend revisions where warranted to keep the comprehensive plan updated and effective. The comprehensive plan shall be reviewed by the planning commission at least once each calendar year; whenever the commission determines adjustment in the plan is needed, it shall recommend to the city council adoption of the revised plan. 
(Ord. No. J-78, § 1(part), 1977) 
CHAPTER 2.24 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. No. D-13. 

2.24.010 - Purposes. 
    The declared purposes of this chapter are to provide for the preparation and carrying out of plans within the City of Cheney in the event of a disaster, and to provide for the coordination of disaster related functions of the city with all other public agencies and affected private persons, corporations and organizations. Any expenditures made in connection with such emergency services activities, including mutual aid activities, shall be deemed conclusively to be for the direct protection and benefit of the inhabitants and property of the City of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. O-2, § 1(part), 1986) 
2.24.020 - Definitions. 
A.  Emergency services. As used in this chapter the term "emergency services" means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters. 
B.  Disaster. As used in this chapter, the term "disaster" means actual or threatened enemy attack, sabotage, extraordinary fire, flood, storm, epidemic, riot, earthquake or other similar natural or manmade public calamity. 
(Ord. No. O-2, § 1(part), 1986) 
2.24.030 - Director of emergency services-Appointment-Duties. 
    There is created the position of director of emergency services. The director shall be appointed by the mayor. The duties of the director shall be: 
(a)  To control and direct the effort of the emergency services organization of the city for the accomplishment of the purpose of this chapter; 
(b)  To direct coordination and cooperation between departments, services and staff on the emergency services; 
(c)  To represent the emergency service organization in all dealings with public and private agencies pertaining to disaster and disaster relief and recovery. 
(Ord. No. O-2, § 1(part), 1986) 
2.24.040 - Director-Emergency powers. 
    In the event of the proclamation of a disaster as herein provided, or the proclamation of a state of extreme emergency by the mayor the director is hereby empowered: 
(a)  To make and issue rules and regulations on matters reasonably related to the protection of life and property as affected by such disaster; provided, however, such rules and regulations must be confirmed at the earliest practicable time by the city council; 
(b)  To obtain vital supplies, equipment and such other properties found lacking and needed for the protection of the life and property of the people, and bind the city for the fair value thereof, and if required immediately, to commandeer the same for public use; 
(c)  To require emergency services of any city officer or employee and, in the event of proclamation of a state of extreme emergency by the governor in the region in which this city is located, to command the aid of as many citizens of this community as he thinks necessary in the execution of his duties; such persons shall be entitled to all privileges, benefits and immunities as are provided by state law for registered emergency workers; 
(d)  To requisition necessary personnel or material of any city department or agency; 
(e)  To execute all of the special powers conferred upon him by this chapter or by resolution adopted pursuant thereto, all powers conferred upon him by any statute, agreement approved by the city council or by any other lawful authority. 
(Ord. No. O-2, § 1(part), 1986) 
CHAPTER 2.28 - LIGHT DEPARTMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
For statutory authority to acquire and operate utilities-see RCW 35.92.050. 

2.28.010 - Establishment of light department. 
    There is hereby established a light department of the City of Cheney which shall be owned, operated, maintained and controlled by the city as a public utility pursuant to and under the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. No. W-38, § 1, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. A-152, § 1, 1935) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-38, § 1, adopted May 27, 2014, changed the title of § 2.28.010 from "Created" to "Establishment of light department" as set out herein. 
2.28.020 - Head of department. 
    The chief administrative officer of the light department shall be the light department director who shall be appointed to the position by and serve at the pleasure of, the mayor. The director shall be under the supervision of the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. W-38, § 2, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. A-152, § 2, 1935; Ord. No. A-1791/2, 1935; Ord. No. L-18, § 1, 1981) 
2.28.030 - Duties. 
    The officers and employees of the light department shall perform such duties and render such services in connection with the department as may be required of them by ordinance, policy or the department director. 
(Ord. No. W-38, § 3, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. A-152, § 3, 1935) 
2.28.040 - Electric utility tax. 
    There shall be paid in the manner provided by law, by the city light department to the current expense fund of the City of Cheney a tax equal to six percent of the gross operating revenue received by the light department. 
(Ord. No. W-38, § 4, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. L-1, § 1, 1981; Ord. No. B-5, § 1, 1938) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-38, § 4, adopted May 27, 2014, changed the title of § 2.28.040 from "Earnings tax" to "Electric utility tax" as set out herein. 
CHAPTER 2.32 - CITY ATTORNEY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
For statutory provisions for city attorney, see RCW 35.24.020; for bond provisions, see RCW 35.24.090; for duties prescribed by statute, see RCW 35.24.110. 
Prior ordinance history: Ordinance Nos. A-13, F-22, and F-27. 

2.32.010 - Appointment of city attorney. 
    As directed by RCW 35.12.020 the mayor shall appoint, subject to confirmation by a majority of the city council, a person, or persons, to serve as city attorney. The person or persons appointed may be full or part-time employees of the city or may serve under a contractual relationship. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992) 
2.32.015 - Special attorney appointments. 
    The mayor may from time to time appoint one or more attorneys in addition to the city attorney to perform tasks as may be assigned, including but not limited to the appointment of bond counsel. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992) 
2.32.020 - Appointment of city prosecutor or special city prosecutor. 
    In addition to the city attorney provided for in section 2.32.010, the mayor may appoint a city prosecutor whose responsibility will be limited to representing the city in the city court and on appeals from the city court. Special prosecutors may be appointed from time to time to prosecute such matters in the city court as the mayor shall direct. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992) 
2.32.030 - Qualifications. 
    Any person appointed pursuant to this chapter shall be an attorney at law admitted to practice in the State of Washington. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992) 
2.32.040 - Duties. 
A.  The city attorney shall serve as general corporation counsel to the city. The attorney shall perform such tasks as may be inherent in the office and as may be directed by the mayor. 
B.  Not by way of limitation, the city attorney shall: 
1.  Attend meetings of the city council unless excused; 
2.  Attend meetings of the city planning commission, city board of appeals, hearing examiner, and civil service commission for police and fire when requested; 
3.  Prepare or review ordinances upon request; 
4.  Prepare or review contracts; 
5.  Attend meetings of the city staff upon request; 
6.  Advise the mayor, council and city staff on matters of law; 
7.  Except as to duties assigned to a city prosecutor, represent the city in the city's municipal court; 
8.  Appear in all legal actions brought against the city, or otherwise appropriately tender defense to counsel employed by an insurance carrier or insurance pool; 
9.  Bring suit upon behalf of the city when directed to do so by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992; Ord. No. V-77, § 1, 9-27-2011) 
2.32.050 - Compensation of attorney. 
    Payment to be made to an attorney appointed to represent the city shall be set by salary ordinance for an attorney serving as a full or part-time paid employee of the city, or as provided in any personal services contract under which an attorney is employed. Services of a part-time employee attorney for representing the city in matters outside the city before state or federal boards or courts shall be compensated in addition to the salary fixed by ordinance at an hourly rate as may be agreed upon between the city and attorney. 
(Ord. No. P-45, § 1(part), 1992) 
CHAPTER 2.33 - PUBLIC DEFENDER 

2.33.010 - Office of public defender created. 
    There is created the office of the public defender to provide qualified legal counsel for indigent criminal defendants, entitled to representation by the Constitution of the United States or the State of Washington. The determination of indigency shall be made by the municipal court. The office of public defender is not created in limitation of that function but to make available to the court one or more qualified persons where the right to counsel attaches to the defense of a criminal case. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 1, 12-9-2014) 
2.33.020 - Qualifications. 
    Any person appointed to serve as public defender shall be an attorney duly licensed to practice law in the State of Washington. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 2, 12-9-2014) 
2.33.030 - Selection-Term. 
    The mayor shall appoint one or more persons to serve as public defender. The municipal court upon, request of the mayor, shall provide names of qualified attorneys that the court reasonably believes have the skill and experience to provide legal counsel for indigent criminal defendants. The terms and consideration for the public defender services shall be established through written contract approved by the city council ("Contract Public Defender"). Where necessary and appropriate the municipal judge shall appoint a qualified attorney on a case by case basis. The words "necessary and appropriate" for the purposes of this section means the contract public defender is not available to provide legal representation or a conflict of interest exists such that separate legal counsel must be appointed in order to protect the interests of the indigent criminal defendant. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 3, 12-9-2014) 
2.33.040 - Compensation for conflict public defender. 
    A person appointed by the municipal court to serve as conflict public defender shall not be paid more than $250.00 per case plus reimbursement of costs pursuant to RCW 10.101.030. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. T-86, § 1, 2005; Ord. No. W-54, § 4, 12-9-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-54, § 4, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, amended § 2.33.040 and, in so doing, changed the title of said section from "Compensation" to "Compensation for conflict public defender," as set out herein. 
2.33.050 - Duties and standards. 
    The public defender shall exercise that degree of skill and knowledge required of other attorneys providing similar services and shall devote reasonable time and effort to the defense of the indigent defendant. To comply with RCW 10.101.030 as well as the Superior Court Criminal Rules (CrR) 3.1 and Limited Jurisdiction Court Criminal Rules (CrRLJ) 3.1 as amended, the public defender's misdemeanor case load standards shall not exceed the representation of indigent criminal defendants in 400 cases for any calendar year (Alternative 1) or 300 cases per year as determined through a case weighting policy (Alternative 2). A "case" is defined at CrRLJ 3.3. A criminal case includes all filed charges arising out of the same incident. 
Alternative 1 : The case load of the public defender shall not exceed 400 misdemeanor cases per attorney per calendar year. The case count for the public defender who also engages in the private practice of law shall be adjusted to reflect the relative percentage of criminal defense cases in relation to the attorney's total practice of law. For example, an attorney whose practice consists of 50 percent of indigent defense services provided to the city, may not exceed 200 misdemeanor cases per calendar year. 
Alternative 2 : The case load of the public defender shall not exceed 300 misdemeanor cases per attorney per year as determined under a case-weighting policy. The city hereby adopts the Model Public Defense Case Weighting Policy for misdemeanors as adopted by the Washington State Office of Public Defense ("OPD Case Weighting Policy"), except as modified herein or by local practice. The clerk of the Cheney Municipal Court shall maintain a copy of the OPD Case Weighting Policy, as modified by the city. Case credits for the purpose of case weighting shall be determined in accordance with the OPD Case Weighting Policy, as modified herein. 
    The public defender will not receive a case credit when: the court dismisses a case on the motion of the prosecuting attorney before legal representation has been assigned; the public defender services have been limited to explaining to the defendant the implication of the city prosecutor reducing a criminal matter to a civil infraction, dismissal prior to first appearance of arraignment; a conflict of interest exists and the public defender voluntarily withdraws from the representation; or in the reasonable judgment of the public defender circumstances arose that eliminated the need to expend time and resources to resolve the case. 
    The city recognizes that certain types of misdemeanor cases require a limited amount of time and effort to ensure effective representation. Where a case satisfies a certain set of requirements, the municipal court has adopted administrative procedures and policies to expeditiously resolve those misdemeanors through stipulations and civil compromises that do not result in a criminal conviction. Such cases can include resolution through diversion, reduction to an infraction, stipulated order of continuance or other order that does not involve a finding of guilt. In addition to the above, a sentence violation, other non-charge representation or a matter where the public defender does not need to appear on behalf of the defendant, such cases shall be accounted for at less than one-third ( 1/3 ) full case credit. 
    Annually, the mayor, municipal court, and public defender shall agree upon whether the case counting method will be based upon the total number of misdemeanor cases in a year assigned to the public defender or a numerical case weighting system as described in the OPD Case Weighting Model Policy. Such determination shall be reflected in writing between the mayor, municipal court, and public defender. 
    The public defender shall comply with the requirement set forth in CrRLJ 3.1 and file a signed certification of compliance on a quarterly basis with the municipal court on the form set forth in the criminal court rules of the State of Washington. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 5, 12-9-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-54, § 5, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, amended § 2.33.050 and, in so doing, changed the title of said section from "Duties" to "Duties and standards," as set out herein. 
2.33.060 - Independent judgment. 
    The public defender shall exercise independent judgment when providing criminal defense services to ensure effective legal representation. The public defender's conduct shall conform to the rules of professional conduct, case law and standards of the Washington State Bar Association. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 6, 12-9-2014) 
2.33.070 - Representation limited to municipal court. 
    Unless otherwise required by law the public defender's representation of a criminal defendant shall be limited to the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998; Ord. No. W-54, § 7, 12-9-2014) 
2.33.080 - Other employment not prohibited. 
    A person appointed by the mayor to serve as public defender shall not solely by reason of such appointment be disqualified from any other employment. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998) 
2.33.090 - Other costs of defense. 
    A public defender may apply to the municipal court for payment of expenses in addition to payment for the service provided. The city shall pay such reasonable defense costs as are ordered by the court after notice to the city and hearing. No costs shall be incurred at public expense unless prior approval of the court is obtained. 
(Ord. No. R-67, § 1(part), 1998) 
CHAPTER 2.36 - FINANCE DIRECTOR AND CITY CLERK[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-35, § 1, adopted May 27, 2014, changed the title of Ch. 2.36 from "Finance Director" to "Finance Director and City Clerk" as set out herein. 

2.36.010 - Offices created-Appointment and removal. 
    There are created the offices of finance director and city clerk, which offices shall be filled by the appointment of the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the city council, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 2, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 1, 1975) 
2.36.020 - Finance director as city clerk. 
    Upon the recommendation of the mayor, the duties of the finance director and city clerk may be performed by one person or separate individuals. Where the duties are performed by separate individuals, each person shall receive city council confirmation, take the oath of office and maintain a fidelity bond. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 3, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 2, 1975) 
2.36.030 - Supervision by city administrator. 
    The finance director is under the supervision and direction of the city administrator. The city clerk, if position is filled by a separate employee, shall be under the supervision of the finance director. Both positions are subject to the direction of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 4, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 3, 1975) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-35, § 4, adopted May 27, 2014, changed the title of § 2.36.030 from "Supervision by administrative assistant" to "Supervision by city administrator" as set out herein. 
2.36.040 - Duties. 
(a)  The finance director shall have general responsibility for all the city's financial activities. Specifically, the finance director shall: 
(1)  Receive, safely keep, deposit and account for all money, credit and obligations of the city and disburse the same through warrants countersigned by the city administrator or mayor; 
(2)  Plan, direct and coordinate the budget control and fiscal accounting activities of the city; 
(3)  Manage the city's finance office and information technology with responsibility for employee work assignments and standards, evaluating performance, and other related personnel functions of the department; 
(4)  Supervise utility billing, collection, payroll, accounts receivable and payable, capital asset reporting and financial activity; 
(5)  Post revenues and expenditures, update accounting journals, balance funds and bank accounts; 
(6)  Prepare necessary financial reports and statements to include coordinating the annual audit performed by the state auditor. 
(b)  The city clerk shall have responsibility to keep and produce all the official records of the city. Specifically, the city clerk shall: 
(1)  Shall keep full and true record of every act and proceeding of the city council and keep such books, accounts and make such reports as may be required by the division of municipal corporations in the office of the state auditor; shall record all ordinances, annexing thereto a certificate giving the number and title of the ordinance, stating that the ordinance was published and posted according to law and that the record is a true and correct copy thereof. The record copy with clerk's certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the contents of the ordinance and of its passage and publication and shall be admissible as such evidence in any court or proceeding; 
(2)  Be the custodian of the seal of the city and shall have authority to acknowledge the execution of all instruments by the city which require acknowledgement; may appoint a deputy for whose acts and his bondsmen shall be responsible, and he and his deputy shall have authority to take all necessary affidavits to claims against the city and certify them without charge; 
(3)  Receive and respond to requests to obtain or review public records of the city; and 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 5, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 4, 1975) 
2.36.050 - Salary. 
    The finance director and city clerk shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the city council through the annual city budget and salary ordinance. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 6, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 5, 1975) 
2.36.060 - Bond. 
    The finance director and city clerk shall each furnish bonds to secure the faithful performance of their duties in the amount of $100,000.00 per office. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 7, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. I-95, § 6, 1975) 
2.36.070 - Authority regarding payments to city. 
    The finance director and all other agents and employees of the city are authorized to accept cash, credit cards, personal checks and electronic fund transfers, payable to the city for any accounts, debts, dues, licenses, fines, forfeitures, or other sums due the city, and should any payment be dishonored by the payee bank, there is levied a charge to cover the city's cost of collection as determined by city council resolution which shall be added to and become a part of the original sum due the city. 
(Ord. No. W-35, § 8, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. M-38, § 1, 1983; Ord. No. J-97, § 1, 1977) 
CHAPTER 2.40 - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

2.40.010 - Office created-Appointment and removal. 
    There is created the office of city administrator, which office shall be filled by the appointment of the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the city council. The city administrator may be removed from office upon recommendation of the mayor and concurrence by the city council through a majority vote. Unless otherwise stated, removal from office shall result in termination of employment effective on the day following the city council action. 
(Ord. No. W-40, § 1, 6-24-2014; Ord. No. W-36, § 1, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. J-8, § 1, 1975; Ord. No. I-45, § 1, 1973) 
2.40.020 - Scope of authority. 
    The city administrator shall be the chief administrative officer for the city, under the direction and authority of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. W-36, § 2, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. J-8, § 2, 1975; Ord. No. I-45, § 2, 1973) 
2.40.030 - Duties. 
    The city administrator shall have the following specific duties, powers and responsibilities, as provided in this chapter or otherwise: 
The city administrator shall, subject to the direction of the mayor: 
(1)  Supervise, administer and coordinate the activities and functions of city officers, departments, commissions and boards to fulfill the requirements of city ordinances, resolutions and the policies of the city council and to include implementing the decisions, regulations and policies of city departments. 
(2)  Regularly report to the mayor concerning the status of all assignments, duties, projects and performance of the various city officers, departments, commissions and boards. 
(3)  Oversee preparation and submission to the mayor of the annual budget and be responsible for its administration after adoption. 
(4)  Supervise all expenditures by the various city offices, departments, commissions and boards, for the purpose of keeping the same within the limitations of the annual budget of the city. 
(5)  Perform such other duties and responsibilities as the mayor may direct. 
(Ord. No. W-36, § 3, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. U-57, § 1, 2007; Ord. No. J-8, § 3, 1975; Ord. No. I-45, § 3, 1973) 
2.40.040 - Salary. 
    The city administrator shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the city council through written agreement, the annual budget and salary ordinances. 
(Ord. No. W-36, § 4, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. J-8, § 4, 1975; Ord. No. I-45, § 4, 1973) 
2.40.050 - Combination of position. 
    The office of city administrator may be combined with any other appointive position in the city; provided that, where combined, the compensation shall be fixed by the council for the combined office and shall not necessarily be the total of the compensation fixed for each office individually. 
(Ord. No. J-8, § 5, 1975; Ord. No. I-45, § 5, 1973) 
2.40.060 - Residency requirement. 
    No person shall be employed by the City of Cheney as the city administrator unless such person shall reside within the corporate limits of the City of Cheney or such residency is established within six months after such person's effective date of employment. Based on extenuating circumstances such as condition of the housing market, construction delays or other reasonable factors beyond the control of the city administrator, the time period may be extended for up to a year at the discretion of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. W-36, § 5, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. U-57, § 2, 2007; Ord. No. J-84, § 1, 1977) 
2.40.070 - Failure to establish residency requirement. 
    Any person employed by the City of Cheney as city administrator after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section who shall fail to establish residence within the period referred to in section 2.40.060; or who, having established residence within the corporate limits of the city, shall remove his residence from within such corporate limits, shall be removed from the position of city administrator. 
(Ord. No. W-36, § 6, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. J-84, § 2, 1977) 
CHAPTER 2.46 - SALARIES AND COMPENSATION[10] 

Footnotes:

For statutory provisions regarding compensation of elective officers, see RCW 35A.12.070. 

2.46.010 - Mayor's salary. 
    The salary of the Mayor of the City of Cheney shall be the sum of $1,500.00 per month. 
(Ord. No. W-09, § 1, 6-25-2013, eff. 1-1-2014; Ord. No. P-82, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. P-11, § 1, 1991; Ord. No. O-69, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. N-54, § 1, 1985; Ord. No. L-15, § 1, 1981; Ord. No. K-44, § 1, 1979; Ord. No. J-75, § 1, 1977; Ord. No. J-2, § 1, 1975; Ord. No. I-36, § 1, 1973; Ord. No. G-1, § 1, 1967; Ord. No. E-87, § 1, 1, 1961) 
2.46.020 - Salary-Member of council. 
    The salary for each member of the city council shall be the sum of $450.00 per month. 
(Ord. No. W-09, § 2, 6-25-2013, eff. 1-1-2014; Ord. No. P-82, § 2, 1993; Ord. No. P-11, § 2, 1991; Ord. No. O-69, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. N-54, § 5, 1985; Ord. No. L-15, § 2, 1981; Ord. No. 19-36, § 1, 1979; Ord. No. K-44, § 2, 1979; Ord. No. J-75, § 2, 1977; Ord. No. J-2, § 2, 1975; Ord. No. I-36, § 2, 1973; Ord. No. G-1, § 2, 1967; Ord. No. E-87, § 2, 1, 1961) 
2.46.030 - Increasing and diminishing salaries. 
    The salary of members of the city council shall not be increased or diminished after their election (or appointment) or during their several terms of office, including, but not limited to, the current terms of office of the now incumbent members of the city council. 
(Ord. No. K-36, § 2, 1979; Ord. No. E-87 § 3, 1961) 
2.46.040 - Information technology equipment. 
    The mayor and each council member of the City of Cheney will receive a lap-top computer, router/firewall, a modem, and a printer. This will allow the chief administrative officer and the governing body access to the citizens through the city web page to conduct business of the citizenry and with city hall. At the end of their term in office all equipment will be returned to the city. 
(Ord. No. T-94, § 1, 2005) 
CHAPTER 2.50 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. Nos. G-55, G-86, H-8, I-50 and I-51. 

2.50.010 - Creation of civil service commission. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by RCW chapters 41.12 and 41.08, there is created a civil service commission for the police and fire departments, respectively. The commission shall be composed of three members, who shall be appointed by the mayor. The terms of the commissioners shall be for a period of three years, staggered so that the term of one commission member shall expire such that no two commissioners will be appointed or reappointed at the same time. The terms, however, shall not affect the length of terms of any existing civil service commissioners. Enactment of this section shall not be deemed to interrupt the continuity of the civil service commission acting on the date of adoption hereof. 
(Ord. No. P-75, § 1(part), 1993) 
2.50.020 - RCW sections adopted by reference. 
(a)  RCW 41.08.010 to 41.08.220, inclusive, and RCW 41.12.010 to 41.12.220, inclusive, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, are adopted by this reference by the city, and all of the details and provisions of said sections are made a part of this section as fully as if set forth in full herein, except as provided below. 
(b)  Exception: Notwithstanding anything in RCW chapter 41.08 to the contrary, in addition to any opportunity afforded the appointing authority to exercise a choice in the filling of a vacancy by the terms of RCW chapter 41.08, whenever requisition is made upon the commission for the names of persons eligible for appointment to any vacancy, including both original appointments and promotions, the commission instead of furnishing the name of the one person highest on any eligibility list, shall certify to the appointing authority the names of the five persons highest on such eligibility list for each vacancy, if there are five such persons available. The appointing authority may forthwith appoint one of the certified persons to such vacant position. 
(Ord. No. Q-46, § 1, 1995; Ord. No. P-75, § 1(part), 1993) 
2.50.030 - Number of persons appointed and positions-City council determination. 
    The number of persons to be appointed and positions to be filled shall be determined from time to time by the city council in the adoption of the annual budget for the city. 
(Ord. No. P-75, § 1(part), 1993) 
2.50.040 - Office of the chief of police. 
    There is hereby created the office of the chief of police for the purpose of providing for the protection of life and property and the maintenance of order within the city. The chief of police shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the city council, to serve and meet all eligibility requirements for the office of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. R-90, § 1(part), 1999) 
2.50.050 - Excluded from civil service commission. 
    The office of the chief of police in accordance with RCW 41.12.050 is excluded from the provisions of the Cheney Civil Service Commission in CMC section 2.50.020. 
(Ord. No. R-90, § 1(part), 1999) 
2.50.060 - Special police officers. 
1.  The purpose of this section is to assist the police department in carrying out its law enforcement responsibilities by conferring upon persons certain law enforcement authority in limited and specific instances. 
2.  This section supplements and specifies the general administrative procedures and provides the substantive regulations of special police officers. 
3.  Special police officers under this chapter differ from private detectives and security guards licensed under RCW 18.165 and chapter RCW 18.170 in that they have a police commission and they differ from members of the police reserve force. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 1, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.070 - Definitions. 
    Applicant is the person employing the individual for whom a special police commission is sought. 
    Special police officer is an individual employed by someone other than the city police department for security and safety purposes having a commission from the chief of police to exercise the powers of a law enforcement officer limited to the scope of their employment and the terms of their commission. 
    The subject of an application is the individual for whom the commission is sought. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 2, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.080 - License required. 
1.  No person may act or pretend to act as a special police officer without a current valid commission; 
2.  No person may employ an individual as a special police officer unless the individual has a current and valid commission issued by the chief of police; and 
3.  The authorization required for a special police officer is in the form of a commission from the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 3, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.090 - Application. 
    The applicant is required to set forth in the application; 
1.  The name and address of the applicant; 
2.  The address or other description of the location(s) where the subject will be employed; 
3.  The full name, date of birth and address of the subject; 
4.  All facts known to the applicant regarding the subject's qualifications; 
5.  The reason why the applicant believes the subject should be commissioned; and 
6.  A description of the proposed responsibilities and functions of the subject and of the subject's present scope of employment. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 4, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.100 - Qualifications. 
A.  To be eligible for a commission a subject, at the time of application, must: 
1.  Be at least 21 years of age; 
2.  Be a citizen of the United States; 
3.  Have a high school diploma or equivalent; 
4.  Be of good moral character; and 
5.  Not have been convicted of a: 
a.  Felony, 
b.  Crime of moral turpitude, or 
c.  Crime involving a controlled substance; 
6.  Not have been involuntarily committed to an institution or treatment program for: 
a.  A mental disorder, or 
b.  Alcohol or controlled substance abuse; 
7.  Have at least 90 days of experience in safety and security duties in the applicant's employ. 
a.  This qualification may be waived by the chief of police if the subject: 
i.  Is employed by the applicant and the chief of police determines that the subject has had 90 days of experience in safety and security duties with a previous employer, or 
ii.  Has completed the training in subsection (B) of this section. 
B.  In addition to subsection (A) of this section, before receiving a commission a subject must: 
1.  Must have satisfactorily completed a police academy, reserve academy, equivalency academy or other training program as prescribed or approved by the Washington State Criminal Justice Training Commission. 
2.  Make an oath to uphold the Constitution and laws of the United States, uphold the laws of the state of Washington and the ordinances of the city of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 5, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.110 - Special regulations. 
1.  No special police officer, while on duty as such, may carry any firearm or dangerous weapon unless their commission specifically authorizes them to do so. 
2.  The chief of police issues identification insignia to each special police officer. An officer is required to carry that identification on their person at all times when on duty and to display it when called upon to identify themselves. 
3.  A special police officer may wear such badge and uniform as approved by the chief of police. 
4.  A special police officer may use a motor vehicle with special marking, insignia, lights, or equipment with prior approval of the chief of police. 
5.  While performing the duties of employment, a special police officer is required to conform to the standards of conduct prescribed for police officers and shall not do any act which would be unlawful if committed by a law enforcement officer. 
6.  The chief of police may require a special police officer to undergo additional training whenever appropriate. 
7.  Every special police officer must comply with such rules and regulations regarding licensing, training, conduct and other matters as the chief of police may from time to time issue. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 6, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.120 - Termination. 
1.  A special police commission expires after one year or as determined in writing by the chief of police. An expired commission may be renewed upon application.
