2.  A special police commission ends upon termination of the special police officer's employment by the applicant. 
3.  The applicant must immediately notify the chief of police of a special police officer's termination of employment. 
4.  The chief of police may suspend or revoke a commission at any time with or without cause. The suspension or revocation of the commission is not subject to appeal. 
5.  Upon expiration, termination, suspension, or revocation of their commission, the special police officer must immediately surrender to the applicant their identification card, badge, uniform and other property connected with their office. 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 7, 1-9-2018) 
2.50.130 - Responsibility of applicant. 
    The conferral of a special police commission does not affect the employer/employee relationship between the applicant and the special police officer. The employer remains responsible for the conduct of the special police officer within the scope of employment until the applicant notifies the chief of police of termination of employment as required by CMC 2.50.120(B). 
(Ord. No. X-21, § 8, 1-9-2018) 
CHAPTER 2.51 - MUNICIPAL COURT 

2.51.010 - Municipal court established. 
    The Cheney Municipal Court is organized and constituted as the municipal court of Cheney, pursuant to RCW chapter 3.50 and as amended by the Court Improvement Act of 1984, chapter 258, Laws of 1984. All of the functions and duties of the present Cheney Municipal Court, together with all cases pending thereunder, are transferred to the constituted municipal court of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. N-27, § 1(part), 1984) 
2.51.020 - Municipal court-Jurisdiction-Powers-Duties. 
    The municipal court of Cheney shall possess such jurisdiction and shall exercise such power and duties as are set forth in RCW chapter 3.50 as now enacted and as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. N-27, § 1(part), 1984) 
2.51.030 - Municipal judges-Appointment-Qualifications-Jurisdiction. 
    A municipal court judge or judges and judges pro-tem, if any, shall be appointed by the mayor pursuant to RCW chapter 3.50. Such judge or judges shall possess such qualifications and shall exercise such jurisdiction as provided for in RCW chapter 3.50 as now enacted and as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. N-27, § 1(part), 1984) 
2.51.040 - Municipal judges-Compensation. 
    The municipal court judge or judges shall receive such compensation as shall be established in each annual budget, provided further that the city may contract with Spokane County for services of a judge. 
(Ord. No. N-27, § 1(part), 1984) 
CHAPTER 2.53 - YOUTH COURT 

2.53.010 - Youth court established. 
    The Cheney Youth Court is created under the Cheney Municipal Court chapter 3.50 RCW and pursuant to chapter 3.72 RCW. 
(Ord. No. U-68, § 1(part), 2008) 
2.53.020 - Youth court jurisdiction-Powers-Duties. 
    The Cheney Youth Court established by the Cheney Municipal Court chapter 3.50 RCW as a youth court pursuant to chapter 3.72 RCW shall possess jurisdiction over traffic infractions alleged to have been committed within the City of Cheney by juveniles ages 16 and 17 title 46 RCW; and students who violate school rules and policies chapter 28A.300.420 RCW; and shall exercise such powers and duties as are set forth in chapter 3.72 RCW as now enacted and hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. U-68, § 1(part), 2008) 
2.53.030 - Youth court participants. 
    Youth court participants shall serve under the supervision of the Cheney Municipal Court and an adult coordinator and may serve in various capacities within the youth court, acting in the role of jurors, lawyers, bailiffs, clerks and judges chapter 3.72 RCW. 
(Ord. No. U-68, § 1(part), 2008) 
2.53.040 - Youth court fees. 
    The court may require that a youth pay a nonrefundable fee to cover the cost of administering the program. The fee may be waived or reduced for a participant. Fees will be paid to and accounted for by the court. 
(Ord. No. U-68, § 1(part), 2008) 
CHAPTER 2.52 - POLICE COURT BAILIFF 

2.52.010 - Office created. 
    There is created the office of police court bailiff. 
(Ord. No. I-100, § 1, 1975) 
2.52.020 - Appointment-Removal. 
    The police court bailiff shall be appointed by the police judge and shall serve at the pleasure of the police judge. 
(Ord. No. I-100, § 2, 1975) 
2.52.030 - Duties. 
    The police court bailiff shall perform such duties as directed by the police judge as may be necessary for the orderly and expeditious dispatch of business of the court. 
(Ord. No. I-100, § 3, 1975) 
2.52.040 - Salary. 
    The salary of the police court bailiff is fixed at the sum of $80.00 per month during the calendar year 1975, and thereafter, such salary as may be fixed by the city council in its general salary ordinance. 
(Ord. No. I-100, § 4, 1975) 
CHAPTER 2.58 - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

2.58.010 - Office created-Compensation. 
    The offices of code enforcement officer and deputy code enforcement officer are created. The code enforcement officer and such deputies as the mayor shall determine shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the mayor. The code enforcement officer and the deputies shall receive such compensation as the city council shall from time to time provide. 
(Ord. No. K-8, § 1, 1978; Ord. No. 6-83, § 2, 1969) 
2.58.020 - Enforcement powers. 
    In addition to the powers and duties provided by other city ordinances and existing provisions of the city code, the code enforcement officer and deputy code enforcement officers shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 15 and of all ordinances relating to sewer and sewage disposal; 
(2)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 16 and of all ordinances relating to water connections and charges; 
(3)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 17 and of all ordinances relating to the installation, distribution and transmission of gas; 
(4)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 19 and of all ordinances relating to the building code, the moving of buildings and to the plumbing code; 
(5)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 20 and of all ordinances relating to mobile homes and mobile home parks; 
(6)  Enforce the penal provisions of chapter 8.12 and of all ordinances relating to garbage collection and disposal; 
(7)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 7 and of all ordinances relating to the keeping and harboring of animals within the city; 
(8)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 21 and of all ordinances relating to zoning and land use; 
(9)  Enforce the penal provision of title 11, section 11.48.250, relating to the parking and removal of unlawfully parked vehicles during snow fall; and 
(10)  Enforce the penal provisions of title 14 and of all ordinances relating to electricity and its use. 
(Ord. No. 6-83, § 3, 1969; Ord. No. K-8, § 2, 1978; Ord. No. M-4, 1982) 
CHAPTER 2.60 - HEARING EXAMINER[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
For statutory provisions creating the office of hearing examiner and establishing the duties and responsibilities therefor, see article XI, section 11 of the state constitution, RCW 35A.63.170, 35A.11.020, RCW 36.70B.120(3), RCW 58.17.330 and 35A.21.160. 

2.60.010 - General. 
    This chapter establishes the duties and responsibilities of a hearing examiner and other officials and agencies with respect to the administration of this Code. The city council through resolution shall establish the cost and fees to be paid by an applicant or appellant. 
(Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005; Ord. No. V-77, § 2, 9-27-2011) 
2.60.012 - Purpose. 
    This chapter creates an administrative hearing and adjudicatory system to act upon quasi-judicial and other administrative matters to: 
(a)  Review certain land use and regulatory matters; and 
(b)  Ensure due process and appearance of fairness in such proceedings. 
(Ord. No. V-77, § 3, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. W-48, § 1, 10-28-2014) 
2.60.020 - Creation of hearing examiner. 
    The position of the City of Cheney Hearing Examiner is created. The hearing examiner is referred to as the "hearing examiner," or "examiner." 
(Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005; Ord. No. V-77, § 4, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. W-48, § 2, 10-28-2014) 
2.60.030 - Appointment of an examiner. 
    The hearing examiner shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. The terms of the appointment may be made through a professional service contract, or through an intergovernmental agreement. 
(Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005; Ord. No. V-77, § 5, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. W-48, § 3, 10-28-2014) 
2.60.040 - Qualifications. 
    The hearing examiner(s) shall be licensed to practice law in the State of Washington and possess qualifications related to the duties of the office to include training and experience to conduct administrative or quasi-judicial hearings with expertise in administrative law, land use law and planning, and the ability to conduct public hearings and issue decisions. 
(Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005; Ord. No. V-77, § 6, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. W-48, § 4, 10-28-2014) 
2.60.042 - Freedom from improper influence. 
    No person, including city officials, elective or appointive, shall attempt to influence an examiner in any pending matter, except at a public hearing duly called for such purposes, or to interfere with any examiner in the performance of his duties in any other way; provided, that this section shall not prohibit the city attorney from rendering legal services to the examiner upon request or prohibit other persons or officials from responding in writing to requests for information from the examiner. 
(Ord. No. V-77, § 7, 9-27-2011) 
2.60.050 - Duties and powers. 
(a)  The examiner shall exercise the authority designated in title 10, environment, title 21, zoning, title 22, subdivisions and chapter 23.120, appeals of the Cheney Municipal Code, and such other matters which may be assigned to the hearing examiner from time to time by action of the city council. Hearings held by the hearing examiner shall constitute the hearings required by state law or city ordinance. The hearing examiner's decision shall have the effect of either a recommendation or an administrative decision appealable within a specified time to the city council in writing by an aggrieved party. The hearing examiner shall hear the following matters: 
(1)  Binding site plans (five lots or more); 
(2)  Conditional use permits; 
(3)  Critical areas reviews; 
(4)  Variances; 
(5)  Appeals from a planning official decision, including but not limited to, binding site plan (four lots or less), short plat, lot line adjustment/merger, permit review decisions, administrative interpretations; 
(6)  Appeals of the public works director's decision(s) under chapter 19.08; and 
(7)  Appeals of SEPA threshold determinations. 
(b)  The examiner's decision shall be in writing and include findings and conclusions, based upon the record. The findings and conclusions shall, to the extent applicable, set forth the manner in which the decision would carry out and conform to state law, the city comprehensive plan, development regulations, policies, rules or standards of the city. 
(Ord. No. X-53, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. W-48, § 5, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 8, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005) 
2.60.052 - Planning staff report. 
    On any matter coming before the hearing examiner, the responsible city department shall coordinate and assemble relevant information and documents from city departments, governmental agencies and other interested parties to include a staff report summarizing the facts, and, depending on the matter, findings and recommendations. At least five calendar days prior to the scheduled hearing, the staff report will be filed with the examiner and copies mailed to the applicant and made available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. W-48, § 6, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 9, 9-27-2011) 
2.60.060 - Rules. 
    The following procedures shall be followed by the hearing examiner, provided that the hearing examiner is granted the authority to prescribe such other rules and procedural matters as necessary to conduct a fair and timely hearing. 
(a)  The hearing examiner shall ensure that: 
(1)  Reasonable notice is given to the applicant and all interested parties of the date(s) for the hearing; 
(2)  The hearing is conducted in general conformance with RCW 34.05.428 through RCW 34.05.452 as modified in the reasonable discretion of the hearing examiner; and 
(3)  Cause a record of the proceedings to be maintained which shall constitute the basis for the decision or recommendation. 
(b)  The hearing examiner shall issue a written decision including findings of fact and conclusions based upon the record within ten calendar days following the conclusion of the hearing and submission of all written materials, unless otherwise provided by law. 
(c)  A copy of the hearing examiner's written decision or recommendation shall be transmitted by mail to the applicant and other parties of record, and filed with the city clerk. 
(d)  The applicant and any person with legal standing may request reconsideration of the decision of the hearing examiner based an erroneous interpretation of law, an unlawful procedure, an erroneous application of law to fact or a failure to make a decision based upon substantial evidence. The written request for reconsideration shall be submitted to the city clerk within ten days of the date of the decision. The request shall set forth the specific errors or new information which should be considered by the hearing examiner. Thereafter, the examiner may make such orders and decision as reasonably necessary. 
(e)  All decisions shall be shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. W-48, § 7, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 10, 9-27-2011; Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005) 
2.60.062 - Enforcement hearings. 
(a)  The hearing examiner may hear appeals of code enforcement violations in addition to the municipal court system using the same process as described in section 2.60.060 
(b)  Notice to the appellant shall be processed as described in Title 1.27 (Civil Infraction System). 
(c)  Appeal to the superior court of the hearing examiner's decision in an enforcement hearing shall be filed within 21 calendar days of the examiner's written decision. 
(Ord. No. W-48, § 8, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 11, 9-27-2011) 
Sec. 2.60.064. - Type of hearing and appeal procedure. 
    The examiner will conduct either an "open record hearing" or a "closed record appeal" as defined in RCW 36.70B.020, as amended. For the purpose of an enforcement hearing, there shall be an "open record hearing," which shall follow issuance of the code enforcement violation. 
    City ordinance or state law shall prescribe whether the examiner is conducting an open record or closed record proceeding. For an open record hearing, the appellant, the applicant, and the city, as appropriate, shall be designated parties to the proceeding. Each party may participate and present testimony through witnesses or written documents. The hearing examiner may allow testimony and the submission of information by interested persons, groups, associations or other entities. Where the hearing examiner is conducting an appeal proceeding participation by interested persons, groups, associations, or other entities is limited to presenting testimony and information through a party to the appeal. 
    Appeals that are a "closed record" hearing, must be upon the record, provided that new evidence which was not available at the time of the hearing may be presented in such appeal. The term "new evidence" means evidence discovered after the hearing and shall not include evidence which was available or which could reasonably have been available. 
    An appeal must be submitted in writing, with the appropriate fee, to the city clerk as set forth in chapter 23.120. Such written appeal shall state specific errors of law, fact, procedure, omissions from the record, and errors in the interpretation of the comprehensive plan or new evidence which was not available at the time of the hearing. 
    After a timely appeal has been filed and upon payment of fees a hearing will be held by the hearing examiner in accordance with adopted appeal procedures. 
    Further process is set forth in chapter 23.120. 
(Ord. No. X-53, § 2, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. W-48, § 9, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 12, 9-27-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-48, § 9, adopted Oct. 28, 2014, amended § 2.60.060 and, in so doing, changed the title of said section from "Appeals" to "Type of hearing and appeal procedure," as set out herein. 
2.60.070 - Removal. 
    An examiner may be removed from office for cause by the affirmative vote of a majority of the city council. 
(Ord. No. U-1, § 1(part), 2005) 
2.60.080 - Stay. 
    During the pendency of an appeal before the hearing examiner or city council, the applicant shall stay any grading, construction or alteration of the property until final decision of the city council. 
(Ord. No. W-48, § 10, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 13, 9-27-2011) 
2.60.090 - Conflict of interest. 
    The hearing examiner shall not conduct nor participate in any hearing where the hearing examiner has a direct or indirect personal interest which would influence the decision making process. Any actual or potential conflict of interest shall be disclosed to the parties immediately upon discovery. Thereafter, either party may object to the hearing examiner continuing in the matter whereupon, the hearing examiner shall make a determination as to whether the examiner will continue to preside over the matter. 
(Ord. No. W-48, § 11, 10-28-2014; Ord. No. V-77, § 14, 9-27-2011) 
CHAPTER 2.62 - LABOR CONTRACT WITH STATE 

2.62.010 - City entrance. 
    The city shall enter into that certain collective bargaining agreement entitled "Working Agreement," dated May 12, 1970, between the city, a municipal corporation of the State of Washington, as employer, and the Washington State Council of County and City Employees and Local 1135C of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO, as the union, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. G-97, § 1, 5-26-1970) 
2.62.020 - Execution-Delivery to union. 
    The mayor and city clerk are authorized and directed to execute and deliver to said union the "Working Agreement" on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. G-97, § 2, 5-26-1970) 
CHAPTER 2.66 - TEMPORARY APPOINTMENT TO CLASSIFIED POSITIONS IN THE POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS 

2.66.010 - Circumstance. 
    Whenever any member of the classified service in either the police department or in the fire department shall, by reason of sickness or injury, become physically or mentally unfit for duty, the mayor may temporarily appoint another person to perform the duties of such disabled member. Such other person temporarily appointed shall assume the rank and perform the duties and bear the responsibilities of the classified position to which he is temporarily appointed, and shall receive the salary and other compensation provided by law for the position to which he is temporarily appointed. 
(Ord. No. H-60, § 1, 1971) 
2.66.020 - Conditions. 
    The existence or occurrence of any one of the following events shall be conclusive that a temporary appointment as provided above may be made: 
(a)  The granting of a disability leave to a member of the classified service by the Spokane County disability board acting in accordance with RCW 41.26.120; or 
(b)  The absence from duty of a member of the classified service as a result of sickness or injury for a period of 15 consecutive calendar days where a duly licensed physician has certified that such member cannot reasonably be expected to return to full duty within 180 days from the last day of duty of such member. 
(Ord. No. H-60, § 2, 1971) 
2.66.030 - Duration. 
    Any such temporary appointment shall be for a period of not to exceed six months duration. 
(Ord. No. H-60, § 3, 1971) 
2.66.040 - Compliance. 
    Any such temporary appointment shall be made in accordance with RCW 41.08, 41.12, and the civil service rules of the Cheney civil service commission adopted by it pursuant to said chapters. 
(Ord. No. H-60, § 4, 1971) 
2.66.050 - Absence report. 
    Whenever any member of the classified service in either the police department or in the fire department has been absent from duty, by reason of injury or illness, for 15 or more consecutive calendar days, such member shall, at the written request of the mayor, submit to physical examination by a duly licensed physician designated by the mayor and the designated physician shall determine and report to the mayor the nature and extent of the member's illness or injury and the reasonably probable date the member will be able to return to duty. As an alternative, the mayor may accept the certificate of one of the member's attending physicians. 
(Ord. No. H-60, § 5, 1971) 
CHAPTER 2.70 - CODE OF ETHICS FOR PUBLIC OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES 

2.70.010 - Policy declaration. 
    High moral and ethical standards among public officials and public employees are essential to gain and maintain the confidence of the public because such confidence is essential to the conduct of free government. They are agents of the people and hold their positions for the benefit of the people. The proper operation of democratic government requires of public officials and public employees that they be independent and impartial when establishing policy and that their positions never be used for personal gain. A code of ethical conduct is necessary for the guidance of public officials and public employees where conflicts do occur as well as to prevent conflicts of interest. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 1, 1972) 
2.70.020 - Definitions. 
    "Public official" and "public employee" include all elected and appointed officers of the city, all employees of the city and the members of all city boards and commissions, whether compensated by wage or salary or not. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 2, 1972) 
2.70.030 - Use of public property. 
    No public official or public employee shall use or permit the use of city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal convenience or profit, except when such services are available to the public generally or are provided as city policy for the use of such public official or public employee in the conduct of official business. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 3(part), 1972) 
2.70.040 - Obligations to citizen. 
    No public official or public employee shall grant, nor shall any citizen attempt to obtain, any special consideration, treatment or advantage beyond that which is available to every other citizen. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 3(part), 1972) 
2.70.050 - Code of ethics. 
    The purpose of the code of ethics is to assist public officials and public employees to establish guidelines to govern their own conduct. The code is also intended to help develop traditions of responsible public service. No public official or public employee shall engage in any act which is in conflict with the performance of his official duties. A public official or public employee shall be deemed to have a conflict of interest if he: 
(1)  Receives or has any financial interest in any sale to or by the city of any service or property when such financial interest was received with the prior knowledge that the city intended to purchase such property or obtain such service; 
(2)  Accepts or seeks for others any service, information or thing of value on more favorable terms than those granted to the public generally, from any person, firm or corporation having dealings with the city; 
(3)  Accepts any gift or favor from any person, firm or corporation having any dealings with the city if he knows or has reason to know that it was intended to obtain special consideration; 
(4)  Influences the selection of or the conduct of business with a corporation, person or firm having business with the city if he personally or through household relatives has financial interest in or with the corporation, person or firm; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any transaction specifically authorized by RCW 42.23.030; 
(5)  Is an employee, officer, partner, director or consultant of any corporation, firm or person having business with the city, unless he has disclosed such relationship as provided by subsection (9) of this section; 
(6)  Engages in or accepts private employment or renders services for private industry when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or would impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties; 
(7)  Appears in behalf of a private interest before any regulatory governmental agency or represents a private interest in any action or proceeding against the interest of the city in any litigation to which the city is a party, unless he has a personal interest and this personal interest has been disclosed to the regulatory governmental agency. A councilman may appear before regulatory governmental agencies on behalf of constituents in the course of his duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations; however, no public official or public employee shall accept a retainer or compensation that is contingent upon a specific action by a city agency; 
(8)  Directly or indirectly possesses a substantial or controlling interest in any business entity which conducts business or contracts with the city, or in the sale of real estate, materials, supplies or services to the city, without disclosing such interest as provided by subsection (9) of this section. An interest is not a substantial interest if such interest does not exceed one-tenth of one percent of the outstanding securities of the business concern; or, if the interest is an unincorporated business concern, one percent of the net worth of such concern; or the financial interest of a corporation, person or firm does not exceed five percent of the net worth of the public employee and his household relatives; 
(9)  As a councilman, has a financial or other private interest in any legislation, or other matters coming before the council, and fails to disclose such an interest on the records of the city council. This provision shall not apply if the councilman disqualifies himself from voting by stating the nature and extent of such interest. Any other public official or public employee who has a financial or other private interest and who participates in discussion with or gives an official opinion to the council and fails to disclose on the records of the council the nature and extent of such interest is in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 4, 1972) 
2.70.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who knowingly and intentionally violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person, firm, corporation or organization which willfully attempts to secure preferential treatment in its dealings with the city by offering any valuable gifts, whether in the form of services, loan, thing or promise, or any other form, to any public official or public employee, shall have its current contracts with the city cancelled and shall not be able to bid on any other city contract for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. I-16, § 9, 1972) 
CHAPTER 2.71 - APPEARANCE OF FAIRNESS 

2.71.010 - Challenge of decision-Procedure. 
(a)  Washington State law requires that all hearings which are quasi-judicial in nature shall comply with the Appearance of Fairness Doctrine, and decision makers require reasonable advance notice in order to be able to respond. Any person who wishes to challenge any decision maker on the grounds of the appearance of fairness, shall file a written statement on a form provided by the city clerk not later than 4:30 p.m. on the last working day prior to the day of the hearing. 
(b)  Any person who fails to timely file the written statement as required by the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be deemed to have waived any objection on the grounds of appearance of fairness. 
(Ord. No. S-20, § 1, 2000) 
CHAPTER 2.72 - PROCEDURES FOR AUTHORIZING THE DEFENSE OF CLAIMS OR ACTIONS AGAINST AN ELECTED OR APPOINTED OFFICER, EMPLOYEE OR VOLUNTEER 

2.72.010 - Purpose. 
(a)  The ordinance codified in this chapter implements the requirements of RCW 36.16.134, as hereafter amended, requiring local governmental agencies to create a procedure for authorizing the defense of an action or proceeding brought against an elected or appointed officer, employee or volunteer at the expense of the city. 
(b)  This chapter also authorizes the indemnification of an officer, employee or volunteer of the city in accordance with RCW 36.16.138 and chapter 48.62 RCW, as hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. S-18, § 2, 2000) 
2.72.020 - Standard of conduct. 
    This chapter applies to any threatened or pending action, claim or other proceeding against any past or present elected or appointed officer, employee or volunteer of the city, to the extent the conduct arises out of and is within the scope of such person in good faith performance, purported performance, or failure of performance of his or her official duties. 
(Ord. No. S-18, § 3, 2000) 
2.72.030 - Determination of conduct. 
    Unless ordered or adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction, the defense and indemnification of an elected or appointed officer, employee, or volunteer may be authorized only as follows: 
(1)  To the extent that the claimant has been successful on the merits; and 
(2)  Where there has been a determination, by a majority vote of all the city council not interested in or a party to the action, claim or other proceeding, that the standard of conduct requirement in section 2.72.020 has been satisfied. In the event a majority vote cannot be obtained because of the interest of members of the city council, then all members of the city council shall be permitted to vote. 
(Ord. No. S-18, § 4, 2000) 
2.72.040 - Notice. 
    Any past or present elected or appointed officer, employee or volunteer who seeks defense and indemnification in any action, claim or proceeding must give notice, in writing, to the mayor of his or her request for defense and indemnification before incurring any costs, disbursements or attorneys fees for which reimbursement is sought, and provide a copy of any and all claims, pleadings, reports or other written statements regarding the allegations. 
(Ord. No. S-18, § 5, 2000) 
2.72.050 - Scope of defense and indemnification. 
(a)  General. The city shall pay the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred and connected with the defense, settlement or monetary judgments, including costs, disbursements and reasonable attorneys fees arising out of any action, claim or other proceeding, within the standard of conduct referred to in section 2.72.020, and for which notice has been given pursuant to section 2.72.040. The city council shall be the sole judge of the reasonable and necessary expenses to be borne by the city. 
(b)  Punitive damages. The city council may authorize payment of an award of punitive damages by a majority vote of the full council. 
(c)  Criminal conduct. Defense and indemnification shall not be authorized for any claim or action founded upon a violation of a statute, law, rule or regulation punishable by fine, imprisonment, or both. 
(Ord. No. S-18, § 6, 2000) 
CHAPTER 2.74 - DISPOSAL OF SURPLUS PROPERTY[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. V-93, § 1, adopted July 24, 2012, effective August 24, 2012, repealed the former Ch. 2.74, §§ 2.74.010-2.74.070. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted a new Ch. 2.74 as set out herein. The former Ch. 2.74 pertained to city property sale and derived from Ord. No. I-74, §§ 1-7, adopted 1974; Ord. No. O-48, § 1(part), adopted 1987; Ord. No. R-12, § 1, adopted 1997. 

2.74.010 - Surplus city property. 
    Whenever it appears to the mayor that any real or personal property owned by the city no longer has utility to the city and it would be in the best interest of the city to sell and dispose of the property, the mayor is authorized to dispose of the real or personal property as follows. 
(1)  If the reasonable value for a parcel or portion thereof of real property or an item of personal property has greater value than $5,000.00, the mayor shall refer the matter to the city council for consideration and action. 
(2)  For real and personal property having a value of less than $5,000.00, the mayor may declare the same as surplus and sell or dispose of the property as set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 3, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.020 - Sale of surplus property. 
    Disposing of property. Real property or personal property with a value less than $5,000.00 ("surplus property") which no longer has utility to the city may be disposed of at public or private sale with the proceeds from such sale paid into the fund from which such property was acquired. Surplus property will be offered for sale, transfer or donation through one of the following methods: 
a.  Sale or transfer to other governmental entity; 
b.  Sale to the general public by auction, sealed bid or negotiation; or 
c.  Donation to an organization that supports the poor or the infirm, upon agreement to use the property for such purposes. 
(1)  Disposal priorities. 
a.  Surplus property will be transferred or sold for reasonable value, if practical. 
b.  Surplus property that does not have a reasonable market value with the cost of sale or disposition exceeding its value may, at the discretion of the mayor, be disposed of in the most efficient and expeditious manner. 
(2)  Valuation. The minimum price to be obtained for the sale of surplus property shall be established by the mayor through either: 
a.  An appraisal of the property by a person knowledgeable or experienced in valuing such property; 
b.  Review of similar property offered for sale through generally acceptable commercial transactions such as public/private offers found in a newspaper, trade publication, internet site or other reasonable source; or 
c.  Through an exercise of reasonable judgment based upon an opinion of value from persons familiar with the property. 
Real property with an estimated value in excess of $5,000.00 shall have the minimum price set based upon the opinion of an individual either licensed to sell and offer real estate or certified to perform written appraisals in the State of Washington. 
(3)  Utility property. Whenever real or personal property has been acquired for public utility purposes, which no longer has utility to the needs of the city, a public hearing shall be held before the city council before the property may be lease, sold or conveyed. RCW 35.94.040. At the public hearing, the city council shall consider a resolution that identifies the surplus property; provided that for items of personal property with an estimated value of less than $5,000.00 per item, the resolution may state "Miscellaneous items of personal property, not exceeding $5,000.00 per item,." are set forth on an attached exhibit. The resolution may also identify certain utility property that will be disposed of through a recycling or other specialized company, such as transformers, wires and other facilities where it is in the public interest to dispose of these items according to good utility practices. 
(4)  Methods of disposal. 
a.  Public auction. The city may dispose of surplus property through auction to the general public conducted by the city, its agent or any local governmental entity. 
b.  Sealed bid. The city may dispose of surplus property through sealed bid, provided: the city places public notice in a newspaper of general circulation and on the city website. Bids shall be opened and announced to the public at the time and place stated in the offer requesting bids. The city shall accept the highest bid for the property, provided such bid is equal to or greater than the established minimum price. Nothing herein prevents the mayor or city council from rejecting all bids. A bid request is an invitation to make an offer to purchase property. Acceptance occurs through payment of consideration or other written acknowledgment by the city. 
c.  Negotiation. Sale through negotiation shall be done at arms-length, which means there is a willing seller and a willing buyer with neither party obligated to buy or sell the property. A good faith attempt shall be made by the mayor or designee to obtain a reasonable price that reflects the market value of the property. 
d.  Notice. The notice of the surplus property shall include a description of the item, the date for the public bid opening and a statement that further information may be obtained through the office of the city clerk. The date of notice on the city website and in the newspaper shall be at least ten days prior to the bid opening. When a public hearing is required, the notice of the public hearing, shall be set forth on the city council agenda and be posted on the city's website. Notice and publication in newspaper of general circulation shall not be necessary when the sale is to another governmental entity or the city determines that the property will be donated to an organization that supports the poor or the infirm. 
(Ord. No. W-66, § 1, 6-23-2015; Ord. No. V-93, § 3, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.030 - Negotiation. 
    Negotiation shall be the method of disposal whenever the mayor determines that such procedure is the most advantageous to the city. The reasons for selecting disposition by negotiation shall be set forth in the records of the city. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 4, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.040 - Warranty, guarantee of quality, and conveyance. 
    All sales of surplus property shall be "as is" and the city takes no responsibility for, and makes no guarantee with respect to the sold items. To the extent known, the city shall disclose significant defects prior to sale. No sale shall be invalid due to a defect discovered after sale which may have been discovered by reasonable inspection of the property. This condition of sale is automatically incorporated into all transactions between the city and the purchasers of surplus property. 
    The mayor and city clerk are authorized to execute such documents as are necessary to convey the property to the purchaser. In the event it is necessary to convey real property, the deed shall be presented to city council for final approval. 
    No conveyance shall occur until payment of the full purchase price. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 5, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.050 - Withdrawal from sale or rejection of bids. 
    The city may withdraw from sale any item at any time prior to the formation of a contract to include rejecting any and all bids to serve the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 6, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.060 - Sale of surplus property to appointed officials or employees. 
    Surplus property shall not be sold to appointed officials or employees of the city except an item of a personal nature that was exclusively used during employment which depicts or represents their office or service may be sold to such person upon termination of employment as surplus property for reasonable value. 
    City officials who are involved in the decision to surplus city property or administer the sale are prohibited from purchasing surplus property from the city. 
    Upon retirement or special recognition of a city employee, the city may declare certain items of personal property to have no continuing value to the city and present such items to the individual as a recognition of exemplary service to the city. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 7, 7-24-2012) 
2.74.070 - Notification to accounting. 
    A detailed list including description, asset tag number, former location, responsible department and sales price for all items disposed shall be sent to the city finance director immediately after disposal for removal from the Capital Asset Management System. 
(Ord. No. V-93, § 8, 7-24-2012) 
CHAPTER 2.78 - INFORMATION GATHERING AND ANALYZING 

2.78.010 - Findings-Purpose. 
    It is determined by the city council, that the study and collection of information, data and opinions on the administrative and enforcement efficiency and costs attendant therewith and the societal effects of proposed, pending or enacted legislation is necessary for legislative planning or revision, and that a prompt, informative response to inquiries from legislators and public administrators, and attendance at legislative committee hearings, relating to the effect of legislation on municipal finances, services and authority, is necessary and helpful to the legislator in the enlightened performance of the legislative function and serves the best interests of the citizens and the public, and is declared to be a municipal purpose. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 1, 1976) 
2.78.020 - Mayor to designate persons to gather and analyze information. 
    The mayor is authorized to designate city employees or representatives to collect, accumulate and analyze information concerning the effect of enacted legislation or the anticipated effect of proposed or pending legislation; to consult with employees or representatives of other municipalities or counties and associations thereof; to respond and provide data and information and give testimony to state legislators, legislative committees, state administrative officers or other municipalities investigating the city's experience or anticipated costs, benefits or problems from such enacted or proposed legislation. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 2, 1976) 
2.78.030 - City's representative-Duties generally. 
    In all matters in which an official staff employee, or other representative appears on behalf of the city, such representative shall observe, carry out or support the known relevant policies of the city council and shall consult the mayor and/or the city council for advice and guidance when required. All such informational activity shall be conducted with prudence and good judgment and within all legal regulation of such activity. Such representative shall not have any authority to make any statements, commitments or promises binding upon the city, but may speak to influence the passage, defeat or amendment of legislation affecting the city in accordance with the policy or position approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 3, 1976) 
2.78.040 - City's representative-Compensation. 
    While engaged in such informational, educational and testimonial activity, a city employee shall continue to receive his or her current salary as a city employee. No additional compensation shall be paid or accrue to an elected official during his or her term of office with the city for such research, informational or lobbying services to this city. An employee or official shall receive reimbursement for the reasonable costs of travel, lodging and personal meals reasonably incurred in the course of such service, in accordance with the city's regular policies and rates as to such reimbursement. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 4, 1976) 
2.78.050 - Entertainment expenditures nonreimbursable. 
    No expenditures from city funds for the hosting, entertainment or campaign assistance of any legislator or state officer shall be authorized, expended or reimbursed. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 5, 1976) 
2.78.060 - Lobbying activities to comply with state regulations. 
    The city's employee or representative in such informational or lobbying activities shall comply fully with all state regulations relating to ethical practices and conduct, and comply with all regulations relating to the reporting of expenditures in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. J-28, § 6, 1976) 
CHAPTER 2.80 - SMALL CONTRACT AUTHORITY 

2.80.010 - Purpose. 
    The mayor has the responsibility to supervise the administration of the city government and its interests, to include ensuring that all contracts and agreements are faithfully kept and performed for the benefit of the city. To facilitate the efficient administration of the city when procuring goods, services, equipment, property and public works, the city council grants the mayor purchasing and contract authority in amounts and conditions set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. V-41, § 2(2.80.010), 6-8-2010) 
2.80.020 - Purchase authority. 
    The mayor may enter into contracts (to include amendments) and establish a binding commitment between the city and a person or entity for the purpose of procuring goods, services, equipment, property and public works which are routine and necessary acquisitions in the best interest of the city. The authority of the mayor is conditioned upon the following: 
(1)  The procurement has been authorized through budget appropriation of the city council; 
(2)  The contract and amount is reported to the city council at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting; and 
(3)  The total amount of the contract (or amendment) does not exceed $10,000.00. 
The above contracts are effective without specific approval by the city council, provided the mayor may elect to present any contract to the city council for consideration. 
(Ord. No. V-41, § 3(2.80.020), 6-8-2010) 
2.80.030 - Contract change orders and contract amendments. 
    The mayor, pursuant to policy adopted by the city council, may authorize changes in work through a change order or contract amendment, provided such funds have been previously appropriated or otherwise made available by the city council. 
(Ord. No. V-41, § 4(2.80.030), 6-8-2010) 
2.80.040 - Contract procurement. 
    The mayor is authorized to adopt rules and regulations for the procurement of goods, services, equipment, property and public works to include, but not be limited to, development of bid specifications, bid requests, notice and award, provided the same are consistent with state law and city ordinance. It is the intent of the council to promote fair and competitive bid practices for the city. All adopted rules, policies and procedures shall be filed with the city clerk and available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. V-41, § 5(2.80.040), 6-8-2010) 
CHAPTER 2.86 - CREATION, ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCING OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS 

2.86.010 - Duties of various city officials. 
    Unless otherwise ordered by the mayor or prescribed by law, the following city officials will perform the duties indicated with respect to the creation, administration and financing of all local improvement districts of the city: 
(1)  City clerk. The city clerk is responsible for receiving all petitions for the creation of local improvement districts, giving all required public notices and placing all matters upon the agenda for council consideration. 
(2)  City engineer. The city engineer shall prepare all assessment rolls and preliminary assessment rolls, determine the sufficiency of all petitions for the creation of local improvement districts and be in charge of the physical construction of the public works authorized by this chapter. 
(3)  City treasurer. The city treasurer shall perform all the duties required of the "treasurer" in RCW chapters 35.43 through 35.56, inclusive; negotiate, obtain and administer all short term financing and otherwise administer all the financing provisions of local improvement districts including but not limited to the maintenance and administration of assessment rolls, the guarantee fund, bonds and warrants and property acquired by foreclosure, and superintend foreclosure of all delinquent assessments. 
(4)  Mayor. The mayor shall have overall responsibility for local improvements by the city, and in all cases not specifically covered by law, ordinance or resolution, determine the proper means of administering such local improvements. 
(Ord. No. N-40, § 1, 1984) 
2.86.020 - Delinquent installments-Penalties. 
    Whenever any annual or other installment upon any local improvement assessment shall become delinquent, there shall immediately be added to such delinquent installment a sum equal to such portion of the delinquent sum as is determined by multiplying the delinquent sum by the rate of interest applicable to the assessment increased by five percentage points. The sum so determined shall thereafter accrue interest at the same rate as the balance of the assessment. A new penalty shall be assessed each year and shall include a penalty upon all prior penalties assessed and not paid. 
(Ord. No. N-40, § 2, 1984) 
CHAPTER 2.90 - HOTEL/MOTEL TAX ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

2.90.010 - Hotel/motel tax advisory committee. 
    A hotel/motel tax advisory committee is established. The purpose of the hotel/motel tax advisory committee is to perform the functions of a lodging tax advisory committee under RCW 67.28.1817 with duties as described in this chapter or as directed by the city council, following procedures as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 2, 2007) 
2.90.020 - Membership and term. 
    The hotel/motel tax advisory committee shall be comprised of five voting members, each appointed by the Cheney City Council. The Cheney City Council may appoint nonvoting members to the HTAC. Members of the HTAC are not required to be residents of the City of Cheney, with the exception of the elected official required by state law. 
(1)  Voting members shall be as follows: 
(A)  One member shall be either the mayor or a Cheney City Council member, who shall serve as chair; 
(B)  Two members shall be representatives of businesses required to collect tax under this chapter; 
(C)  Two members shall be persons involved in activities authorized to be funded by revenue received under this chapter. 
(2)  The term of membership shall be through December 31 of the year following appointment; provided that a member's term shall not expire until the appointment of a new member is effective. By statute, eligibility for appointment under subsection (1)(B) or (1)(C) of this section is mutually exclusive. The city council shall review the membership of the advisory committee annually and make changes as appropriate. Each year, organizations representing businesses required to collect the lodging tax, organizations involved in activities authorized to be funded by lodging tax revenue, and local agencies involved in tourism promotion may submit recommendations for membership on the HTAC. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 3, 2007) 
2.90.030 - Duties. 
(a)  A city proposal shall be submitted to the hotel/motel tax advisory committee for review and comment if the city proposes an increase in the rate of the tax imposed under this chapter, the repeal of an exemption from a tax imposed under this chapter, or a change in the use of revenue received under this chapter. The hotel/motel tax advisory committee shall submit comments on such a proposal to the city council in a timely manner through generally applicable public comment procedures. Comments from the hotel/motel tax advisory committee shall include an analysis of the extent to which the proposal will accommodate activities for tourists or increase tourism, and the extent to which the proposal will affect the long-term stability of the lodging tax fund created under this chapter. 
(b)  The hotel/motel tax advisory committee should submit its comments on the proposal no more than 44 days after its receipt of the proposal. However, failure of the hotel/motel tax advisory committee to submit comments shall not prevent the city from acting on the proposal once 45 days have elapsed since the proposal was submitted to the hotel/motel tax advisory committee. The city is not required to submit an amended proposal to the hotel/motel tax advisory committee. 
(c)  In addition to the foregoing, the hotel/motel tax advisory committee will submit a report to the city's finance director as to whether the proposed budget for hotel/motel tax revenue and hotel/motel fund expenditures is consistent with long-term stability of the lodging tax fund. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 4, 2007) 
2.90.040 - Quorum. 
    A quorum of the hotel/motel tax advisory committee shall be a majority of persons currently serving as voting members of the committee. A quorum must be present in order for a vote to be taken on a recommendation to go to the city council. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 5, 2007) 
2.90.050 - Procedure. 
(a)  The chair shall propose an agenda for meetings, shall preside at all meetings, and shall vote on matters being voted on by hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting. The chair shall be responsible for assuring that hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting reports are presented to the city on time and shall select a member to record decisions of hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting that establish policies or recommendations. 
(b)  The hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting may select a vice-chair or a temporary chair to act in the absence of the chair. 
(c)  The hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting may adopt a written policy of hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting practices, not inconsistent with this chapter or other direction of city council. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 6, 2007) 
2.90.060 - Voting. 
    Each voting member, as defined in this chapter, is entitled to one vote. All matters establishing policies, recommendations or decisions shall be decided by a majority vote of voting members present. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 7, 2007) 
2.90.070 - Compensation and reimbursement of expenses. 
    The members of the hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting shall receive no compensation. However, the hotel/motel tax advisory committee may request specific support and/or expenses necessary to carry out its responsibilities by a request made, in advance, to the mayor and approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 8, 2007) 
2.90.080 - Removal. 
    A member of hotel/motel tax advisory committee meeting may be removed during the member's term by the city council only for sufficient cause. Sufficient cause means: 
(1)  Absence for two consecutive meetings without prior excuse from the chair; or 
(2)  A violation of the public trust or malfeasance in the judgment of the city council whose decision shall be final and non-appealable. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 9, 2007) 
2.90.090 - Annual economic impact report. 
    The hotel/motel tax advisory committee shall assist the city in compiling an annual economic impact report and such other report(s) to the Department of Community, Trade and Economic Development required by law including but not limited to section 67.28.1816 of the Revised Code of Washington. 
(Ord. No. U-67, § 10, 2007) 
Title 3 - FINANCE 
CHAPTER 3.04 - WARRANTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Order of redemption prescribed by statute-See RCW 35A.21.110. 

3.04.010 - Order of redemption. 
    All city warrants shall be redeemed by the treasurer in the order of their issue, according to priority of number, and it shall be his duty to make calls for, by publication in the official city paper (if any), and pay city warrants whenever the fund on hand amounts to $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 41, § 1, 1886) 
CHAPTER 3.08 - FUNDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
For statutory provisions indicating that municipal funds and accounts are governed and controlled by the general law, see RCW 35A.40.010. 

3.08.010 - Light fund-Created. 
    There is created in the city treasury a special fund to be known and designated as the "light fund." 
(Ord. No. A-151, § 1, 1931) 
3.08.020 - Light fund-Deposits. 
    There shall be deposited in the light fund all revenues of the municipal light system. 
(Ord. No. A-151, § 2, 1931) 
3.08.030 - Light fund-Expenditures. 
    There shall be paid from the light fund all salaries and wages and all expenses of maintenance and operation for all materials and supplies of the municipal light system. 
(Ord. No. A-151, § 3, 1931) 
3.08.040 - Cumulative recreation park fund-Created. 
    There is hereby created and established a fund in the city treasury to be designated as "cumulative recreation park fund" pursuant to chapter 60 of the Laws of 1941. 
(Ord. No. B-49, § 1, 8-3-1943) 
3.08.050 - Cumulative recreation park fund-Deposits. 
    Such monies as are now budgeted or may hereafter be budgeted for construction, equipment and other capital outlay of and for a playground and recreation park in the City of Cheney on property now owned by the city and within the corporate limits of the city shall be placed in the cumulative recreation park fund. 
(Ord. No. B-49, § 2, 8-3-1943) 
3.08.060 - Cumulative recreation park fund-Expenditures. 
    The monies placed in the cumulative recreation park fund shall be accumulated from year to year and may be expended at such time as the city council shall direct for the purpose of development, construction, equipment and other capital outlay of and for the playground and recreation park on property now owned by the city and within the corporate limits of the city and for no other property. 
(Ord. No. B-49, § 3, 8-3-1943) 
3.08.065 - Parks and recreation utility tax fund-Created. 
(a)  There is created and established a special revenue fund in the office of finance to be known and designated as the "parks and recreation utility tax fund" for the deposit of monies in such fund and expenditures therefrom. 
(b)  There shall be deposited and placed in the fund all sums which have been before the effective date, or are now, or shall in the future be collected, by utility tax, permits and licenses, intergovernmental revenue, charges for fees and services, fines or restitution, rent proceeds or any other monies designated for parks and recreational services or programs. 
(c)  The monies in the fund may be expended only for the purpose of maintenance, operations, capital facilities, assessments by other funds and other expenses for the parks and recreation programs and services shall be paid from this fund. 
(Ord. No. T-44, § 1, 2003) 
3.08.070 - Cumulative fire equipment fund-Created. 
    Pursuant to chapter 60 of the laws of the State of Washington for the year 1941 there is hereby established in the treasury of the City of Cheney a cumulative reserve fund hereby designated as the "cumulative fire equipment fund" for the purpose of accumulating funds for the payment of the cost of a new fire truck together with necessary and incidental equipment therefor to be purchased by the City of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. B-91, § 1, 10-4-1949) 
3.08.080 - Cumulative fire equipment fund-Deposits. 
    The city treasurer shall deposit in the cumulative fire equipment fund all sums now or hereafter budgeted and appropriated for the purposes of said fund or which is transferable to said fund. 
(Ord. No. B-91, § 2, 10-4-1949) 
3.08.090 - Cumulative fire equipment fund-Expenditures. 
    The only expenditure which may be made from the cumulative fire equipment fund shall be for the payment of a new fire truck for the City of Cheney together with incidental and necessary equipment therefor. 
(Ord. No. B-91, § 3, 10-4-1949) 
3.08.100 - Light contingency reserve fund-Created-Deposits. 
    There is hereby created a special reserve fund in the city treasury of the City of Cheney known and designated as the "city light contingency reserve fund" into which fund shall be deposited monthly or at other stated intervals monies of the city light department budgeted each year for such fund. 
(Ord. No. E-24, § 1, effective 1-1-1957) 
3.08.110 - Light contingency reserve fund-Expenditures. 
    The city light contingency reserve fund hereby created shall be used only for capital repair, replacements or extensions of the facilities of the city light department when proper budget appropriations have been made therefor or for payment of immediate repairs to facilities caused by storm, flood or other unforeseen casualty cause. 
(Ord. No. E-24, § 2, effective 1-1-1957) 
3.08.120 - Garbage equipment reserve fund; created; purpose. 
    Under provisions of chapter 60, Laws of 1941, as amended by chapter 38, Laws of 1953, there is hereby created and established a special fund in the city treasury of the City of Cheney to be known and designated as the "cumulative reserve fund for garbage equipment" for the purpose of accumulating funds with which to purchase trucks and other equipment to be used for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and other refuse. 
(Ord. No. E-81, § 1, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.130 - Garbage equipment reserve fund-Deposits. 
    There shall be deposited and placed in the cumulative reserve fund for garbage equipment all sums which have been heretofore, or are now, or shall in the future be budgeted and appropriated for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. E-81, § 2, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.140 - Garbage equipment reserve fund-Accumulation of monies. 
    The monies in the cumulative reserve fund for garbage equipment shall be allowed to accumulate from year to year until the city council shall determine to expend the monies for the purpose herein specified. 
(Ord. No. E-81, § 3, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.150 - Garbage equipment reserve fund-Expenditures. 
    The monies in the cumulative reserve fund for garbage equipment may be expended only for the purpose of purchasing trucks and other equipment to be used for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and other refuse and for no other purpose unless there be an approving vote by a majority of the electors of the City of Cheney at a general or special election voting on a proposal submitted to the electors to allow other specified uses to be made of said fund. 
(Ord. No. E-81, § 4, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.160 - Arterial street fund-Created. 
    In accordance with chapter 7, Laws of 1961, extraordinary session, there is hereby created and established a special fund in the city treasury of the City of Cheney to be known and designated as the "arterial street fund." 
(Ord. No. E-82, § 1, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.170 - Arterial street fund-Source of monies. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of said chapter 7, Laws of 1961, extraordinary session, all monies and funds received by the city from the State of Washington for the construction, improvement and repair of arterial streets and attributed to the one-half cent per gallon additional tax imposed by said 1961 amendatory act, together with matching funds of the City of Cheney from any other legally available source amounting to not less than 25 percent of the cost of each approved project, shall be deposited in and expended out of the arterial street fund. 
(Ord. No. E-82, § 2, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.180 - Arterial street fund-Expenditures. 
    All monies expended from the arterial street fund shall be expended exclusively for the construction, improvement and repair of arterial streets as that term is defined in RCW 46.04.030, and such expenditures shall be made only after approval of each project by the State Highway Department, State of Washington, and in the manner prescribed by the auditor of the State of Washington, Division of Municipal Corporations. 
(Ord. No. E-82, § 3, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.190 - Street, truck and equipment reserve fund-Created. 
    Under provisions of chapter 60, Laws of 1941, as amended by chapter 38, Laws of 1953, there is hereby created and established a special fund in the city treasury of the City of Cheney to be known and designated as the "cumulative reserve fund for street, truck and equipment" for the purpose of accumulating funds with which to purchase trucks and other equipment used for the construction, improvement, repair and maintenance of the city streets. 
(Ord. No. E-83, § 1, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.200 - Street, truck and equipment reserve fund-Deposits. 
    There shall be deposited and placed in the cumulative reserve fund for street, truck equipment all sums which have been heretofore, or are now, or shall in the future be budgeted and appropriated for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. E-83, § 2, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.210 - Street, truck and equipment reserve fund-Accumulation. 
    The monies in the cumulative reserve fund for street, truck and equipment shall be allowed to accumulate from year to year until the city council shall determine to expend the monies for the purpose herein specified. 
(Ord. No. E-83, § 3, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.220 - Street, truck and equipment reserve fund-Expenditures. 
    The monies in the cumulative fund for street truck and equipment may be expended only for the purpose of purchasing trucks and other equipment used for the construction, improvement, repair and maintenance of the city streets and for no other purpose unless there be an approving vote by a majority of the electors of the City of Cheney at a general or special election voting on a proposal submitted to the electors to allow other specified uses to be made of said fund. 
(Ord. No. E-83, § 4, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.230 - Police patrol car and radio reserve fund-Created. 
    Under provisions of chapter 60, Laws of 1941 as amended by chapter 38, Laws of 1953, there is hereby created and established a special fund in the city treasury of the City of Cheney to be known and designated as the "cumulative reserve fund for police patrol car and radio" for the purpose of accumulating funds with which to purchase police patrol cars, radio and other incidental equipment related thereto for police department use. 
(Ord. No. E-84, § 1, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.240 - Police patrol car and radio reserve fund-Deposits. 
    There shall be deposited and placed in the cumulative reserve fund for police patrol car and radio all sums which have been heretofore, or are now, or shall in the future be budgeted and appropriated for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. E-84, § 2, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.250 - Police patrol car and radio reserve fund-Accumulation. 
    The monies in the cumulative reserve fund for police patrol car and radio shall be allowed to accumulate from year to year until the city council shall determine to expend the monies for the purpose herein specified. 
(Ord. No. E-84, § 3, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.260 - Police patrol car and radio reserve fund-Expenditures. 
    The monies in the cumulative reserve fund for police patrol car and radio may be expended only for the purpose of purchasing police patrol cars, radios and other incidental equipment related thereto for police department use and for no other purpose unless there be an approving vote by a majority of the electors of the City of Cheney at a general or special election voting on a proposal submitted to the electors to allow other specified uses to be made of said fund. 
(Ord. No. E-84, § 4, 8-8-1961) 
3.08.270 - Payroll fund-Created. 
    Pursuant to authority contained in chapter 27, laws of Washington, 1953, there is hereby created a fund, to be known and designated as the "payroll fund," into which shall be paid and transferred from and after January 1, 1963, from the various department funds of the City of Cheney which are now or may hereafter be established, and from the current expense fund, an amount equal to the various salaries and compensations of the various city employees. 
(Ord. No. F-5, § 1, 12-11-1962) 
3.08.280 - Payroll fund-Transfers. 
    On the last day of each and every month the city treasurer is hereby authorized empowered and directed to transfer from the various fund of the various departments, sufficient funds to pay the salaries and payrolls of the employees of the various and respective departments of the city for that month. 
(Ord. No. F-5, § 2, 12-11-1962) 
3.08.290 - Payroll fund-Use. 
    Said "payroll fund" shall be used and payments therefrom be made only for the purpose of paying and compensating employees of the City of Cheney for services rendered. 
(Ord. No. F-5, § 3, 12-11-1962) 
3.08.300 - Payroll fund-Warrants-Issuance authorized. 
    The city treasurer is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to issue warrants on and against said fund in payment of services rendered to the city by its various employees in the various departments. Said warrants shall be issued only after there has been filed with the city treasurer properly certified payrolls, due bills or time certificates stating the nature of the services rendered and the amount due or owing and the persons entitled thereto. 
(Ord. No. F-5, § 4, 12-11-1962) 
3.08.310 - Payroll fund-Warrants-Purpose. 
    All warrants issued on or against said fund shall be solely and only for the purposes herein set forth and shall be payable only out of and from said fund. Each warrant issued under the provisions of this chapter shall have printed upon its face the words, "payable out of the payroll fund." 
(Ord. No. F-5, § 5, 12-11-1962) 
3.08.320 - Claims fund-Created. 
    Pursuant to authority contained in chapter 27, Laws of Washington, 1953, there is hereby created a fund to be known and designated as the "claims fund," into which shall be paid and transferred from and after January 1, 1963, from the various department funds of the City of Cheney which are now or may hereafter be established, and from the current expense fund, an amount equal to the approved claims against the city for any purpose excepting payroll. 
(Ord. No. F-6, § 1, 1962) 
3.08.330 - Claims fund-Transfer. 
    The city treasurer is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to transfer from the various funds of the various departments of the City of Cheney sufficient funds to pay all claims against the city for any purpose except payroll. Such transfer shall be made at the direction of the city council and only after the city council shall have approved the payment of said claims. 
(Ord. No. F-6, § 2, 1962) 
3.08.340 - Claims fund-Issuance of warrants. 
    The city treasurer is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to issue warrants on and against said fund in payment of claims against the city for any purpose, excepting payroll. Said warrants shall be issued only after said claims against the city have been approved for payment by the city council. 
(Ord. No. F-6, § 3, 1962) 
3.08.350 - Claims fund-Warrants-Purpose. 
    All warrants issued on or against said fund shall be solely and only for the purpose herein set forth and shall be payable only out of and from said fund. Each warrant issued under the provisions of this chapter shall have printed upon its face the words, "payable out of the claims fund." 
(Ord. No. F-6, § 4, 1962) 
3.08.395 - Park and recreation capital reserve fund. 
(a)  There is hereby established in the office of the city treasurer a fund which shall be known as the park and recreation capital reserve fund. 
(b)  There shall be deposited in the fund such funds as shall be appropriated by the city council and any other funds which are properly by law to be deposited therein. 
(c)  The funds deposited in the reserve fund may be used at the direction of the city council for the acquisition of land, buildings and appurtenances for park and recreation purposes, for the construction of structures, buildings, or other improvements on property devoted to park and recreation purposes, for the acquisition and purchase of equipment and facilities for park and recreation purposes, and for any other capital expenditure for park and recreation purposes.

(Ord. No. D-3, § 7(part), 8-15-1960) 
3.08.410 - Use of fund.

(Ord. No. D-3, § 7(part), 8-15-1960)

3.08.450 - Alcoholism fund-Established-Deposits. 
    There is established in the city treasury a fund to be designated as the alcoholism fund. Into this fund there shall be paid such share of the city's revenue from liquor taxes and profits, the same not to be less than two percent thereof, as is required to be devoted to the support of an alcoholism program approved by the secretary of the state department of social and health services under chapter 77, Laws of 1972, Secondary Extraordinary Session, and as such law may be subsequently amended. Further, any additional funds which may be available for such purpose from all sources including grants from federal government, the State of Washington, and from any person or persons or organization shall be deposited to such fund. 
(Ord. No. H-97, § 1, 1972) 
3.08.460 - Alcoholism fund-Expenditures.

(Ord. No. H-97, § 2, 1972) 
3.08.470 - Safe schools/healthy students fund-Created. 
    There is created and established a special revenue fund in the office of finance to be known and designated as the "safe schools/healthy students fund," for the deposit of monies in such fund and expenditures wherefrom. 
(1)  There shall be deposited and placed in this fund all sums which have been, or are now, or shall in the future be collected, reimbursed or any monies designated for the purpose of the safe schools/healthy students initiative. 
(2)  The monies in this fund may be expended only for the purpose of coordinating activities, technical assistance and training related to improving the safe school environment to the stakeholders of the Spokane County Safe Schools/Healthy Students Initiative Grant, providing technical assistance to Cheney, Deer Park, Medical Lake, Nine Mile Falls, Riverside and Spokane County school districts in crisis management and emergency response preparation. 
(Ord. No. U-6, § 1, 2005) 
3.08.480 - Information technology fund-Created. 
    There is created and established a special revenue fund in the office of finance to be known and designated as the "information technology fund," for the deposit of monies in such fund and expenditures wherefrom. 
(1)  There shall be deposited and placed in this fund all sums which have been, or are now, or shall in the future be collected, taxes, permits or licenses, intergovernmental state shared revenues, charges for fees and services, fines or restitution, rent proceeds or any other monies designated for the purpose of information technology for the city. 
(2)  The monies in this fund may be expended only for the purpose of maintenance, operations, capital outlays, assessments by other funds and other expenses directly related to the operation of information and communication operating facilities of the city.

3.08.720 - State unemployment compensation fund. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of RCW 50.44.060 there is created and established an internal service fund in the office of finance to be known and designated as the "state unemployment compensation fund," for the purpose of accumulating funds for the reimbursement for unemployment claims from the department of employment security, providing for the deposit of moneys in such fund and expenditures therefrom: 
(1)  There shall be deposited and placed in said fund all sums which have been heretofore, or are now, or shall in the future be assessed to operating funds, be budgeted and appropriated for such purpose. 
(2)  The moneys in said fund shall be allowed to accumulate from year to year from periodic cash contributions received from operating funds. The amount of cash contributions will be determined on the estimate of future unemployment claims and shall be adjusted periodically based on reimbursement claim experience. Interest earnings on investments of the contributions shall be used for the benefit of the internal service fund. 
(3)  The moneys in said fund may be expended only for the purpose of reimbursement of unemployment claims from the department of employment security and for no other purpose. 
(Ord. No. R-61, § 1, 1999)

CHAPTER 3.12 - SALES AND USE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. No. G 88. 

3.12.010 - Imposition. 
    There is imposed a sales or use tax, as the case may be, as authorized by RCW 82.14.030(2), upon every taxable event, as defined in RCW 82.14.020, occurring within the City of Cheney. The tax shall be imposed upon and collected from those persons from whom the state sales tax or use tax is collected pursuant to RCW chapters 82.08 and 82.12. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 1, 1983) 
3.12.020 - Rate. 
    The rate of the tax imposed by section 3.12.010 shall be one-half of one percent of the selling price or value of the article used, as the case may be; provided, however, that during such period as there is in effect a sales tax or use tax imposed by Spokane County under section 17(2), chapter 49, Laws of 1982, First Extraordinary Session at a rate equal to or greater than the rate imposed by this section, the county shall receive 15 percent of the tax imposed by section 3.12.010; provided further, that during such period as there is in effect a sales tax or use tax imposed by Spokane County under section 17(2), chapter 49, Laws of 1982, First Extraordinary Session at a rate which is less than the rate imposed by this section, the county shall receive from the tax imposed by section 3.12.010 that amount of revenues equal to 15 percent of the rate of the tax imposed by the county under section 17(2), chapter 49, Laws of 1982, First Extraordinary Session. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 2, 1983) 
3.12.030 - Administration and collection. 
    The administration and collection of the tax imposed by this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of RCW 82.14.050. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 3, 1983) 
3.12.040 - Inspection of records. 
    The City of Cheney consents to the inspection of such records as are necessary to qualify the city for inspection of records of the department of revenue, pursuant to RCW 82.32.330. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 4, 1983) 
3.12.050 - Entrance into contract. 
    The mayor and clerk are authorized to enter into a contract with the department of revenue for the administration of this tax. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 5, 1983) 
3.12.060 - Referendum procedure. 
    This chapter shall be subject to referendum as provided in chapter 99, Laws of Washington, 1983 Regular Session. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 6, 1983) 
3.12.070 - Penalties. 
    Any seller who fails or refuses to collect the tax as required with the intent to violate the provisions of this chapter or to gain some advantage or benefit, either direct or indirect, and any buyer who refuses to pay any tax due under this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined no more than $500.00 or imprisoned for not more than six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. M-25, § 7, 1983) 
CHAPTER 3.16 - TRAVEL EXPENSES 

3.16.010 - Applicability. 
    Whenever city officials or employees are authorized to travel outside the City of Cheney or its immediate environs on official city business for the purpose of conducting city business or for the purpose of attending meetings, conferences or conventions on behalf of the city, the manner and amount of reimbursement for the expense incurred shall be as set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. I-27, § 1, 1973) 
3.16.020 - Basis for reimbursement-Subsistence and lodging expenses. 
(a)  The reimbursement for subsistence and lodging expenses incurred on official business shall be on an actual expense basis whereby the employee or official will be reimbursed by the city for the reasonable and justifiable expense incurred during official travel.
