    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as in any way changing the time or manner of calling and paying local improvement bonds, nor the method of levying and collecting assessments and reassessments for the purpose of paying for local improvements; but the provisions hereof are cumulative and intended to supplement the existing ordinance of the city in relation to the making of local improvements and the levying and collection of assessments and reassessments to pay therefor. 
(Ord. No. D-49, § 10, 7-5-1955) 
CHAPTER 12.20 - CONSTRUCTION OF CURBS AND SIDEWALKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ords. F-7, I-24, M-20, O-44 and O-91. 

12.20.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate, control, and assure the proper installation and construction of curbs and sidewalks within the right-of-way in the city. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Access streets means those city streets that are not designated as arterial streets. 
    Arterial streets means those streets designated by the city and recognized by the Washington State Department of Transportation as functionally classified arterial streets. 
    City standards means the most current adopted city standards, drawings and specifications. 
    Contractor means a person currently registered by State of Washington Department of Labor and Industry as general or specialty contractor. 
    Curbs means curb and gutter combination sections including paving of those areas between the curb and existing street pavement as per the city construction standards. Pre-existing curbs constructed from asphalt cement are not recognized as meeting city standards for curb construction and shall be replaced with Portland cement curbs. 
    Department of public works, hereinafter referred to as the "department," means the department of public works of the city. The director of public works or agents appointed by the director shall be authorized to act in the department's behalf. 
    Homeowner means an individual(s) that has(have) a legal or equitable interest as a property owner and who is currently residing at that same property of a single-family or duplex dwelling. 
    Substantial improvement means any repair, reconstruction, addition or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the assessed value of the structure either: (1) before the improvement or repair is started, or (2) if the structure has been damaged and is being restored, before the damage occurred. 
    Sidewalk means a cement concrete walkway surface constructed within the city right-of-way according to city standards. Sidewalk width shall be no less than a total of 60 inches or no less than the existing widths of sidewalks common to the area as determined by the director of public works. 
    Occupancy classification means the purpose for which a building, or part thereof, or property parcel, is used or intended to be used. 
    Owner-occupied means a person who actively and freely owns or claims rightful ownership of a structure/building and property and currently resides at the same. 
    Persons means an individual, partnership, corporation, association, business venture, public or private utility, or special service district. 
    Property owner means a person who actively and freely owns or claims rightful ownership of a structure/building and/or real property. 
    Right-of-way means improved or unimproved public property dedicated or deeded to the city for the purpose of providing for vehicular, pedestrian and public use. 
    Streets means right-of-way. 
    Travelway means area between the curb or edges of asphalt which provide the surface for travelway. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.030 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to perform or cause to perform any work in a city right-of-way on sidewalks or curbs without first having obtained a permit therefor from the director of public works or his/her designee as provided in this chapter. City personnel or contractors working on the city's behalf will not be assessed a fee for a curb and sidewalk construction permit. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.040 - Curbs and sidewalks required. 
    Curbs and sidewalks shall be required to be permitted and constructed within city rights-of-way on city access and arterial streets where the same are not already in existence, or the same are in a state of disrepair as declared by the director of public works, on all sides or private property parcels adjacent to city access and arterial streets whenever any permit is used for new construction or for substantial improvement to a parcel, or any improvements resulting in a change of occupancy classification. Improvement resulting in a change in occupancy classification shall be deemed to have occurred if a manufactured home or mobile home siting permit is issued to locate a manufactured home or mobile home at any specific location, space or site, where a manufactured home or mobile home has not previously been lawfully located and existing at the effective date hereof, except in property zones R-l, R-1M, R-2, and R-3. 
    Where curbs and sidewalks are otherwise required under this section no permit for construction, substantial improvement, or to site a manufactured home or mobile home shall issue except upon application of the owner, or an owner, of the real property where the permitted activity is to occur, and the property owner shall be responsible for compliance herewith. 
    Curbs and sidewalks required to be constructed as provided by this chapter, shall be complete and accepted by the director of public works prior to occupancy, use, or change of use of the property permitted for new construction, substantial improvement, change of occupancy classification, or occupancy of a manufactured home or mobile home located at a specific location, space or site not previously occupied by a lawfully existing manufactured home or mobile home. Sidewalks hereby required shall extend the entire street front of the lot, parcel of land, or tract, upon which the new construction, substantial improvement or change of use is done, and shall attach to existing sidewalks on adjoining land. The city shall not provide water or electrical power to any structure or manufactured home or mobile home occupied in violation of the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. S-44, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. R-17, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. R-15, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.050 - Curbs and sidewalk construction. 
    Permittees applying to construct curbs and sidewalks shall be registered contractors in the State of Washington as regulated by the State of Washington Department of Labor and Industries. 
    The director of public works may permit a home owner of property to construct sidewalk within the city right-of-way if the director of public works can be reasonably assured that public safety will not be compromised either in construction or in the quality of the work to be accomplished. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.060 - Curbs and sidewalk specifications. 
    All sidewalks adjacent to access and arterial streets in the city shall be constructed of concrete 60 inches in total width, four inches in thickness and upon grade approved by the city engineer or director of public works. Curbs and sidewalks shall be constructed on no less than four inches of compacted crushed gravel. 
    All curbs adjacent to access and arterial streets in the city shall be constructed of concrete, and of the Type B (curb and gutter) or Type E-4 (straight back) curb design as provided and shown in the City of Cheney development manual. 
    All curbs and sidewalks shall be constructed of materials and methods as prescribed in the 1996 Washington State Standard Specifications for Road, Bridge, and Municipal Construction, as now existing or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.070 - Curb-to-curb roadway widths. 
    All access streets in the city shall have a minimum curb-to-curb width of 36 feet. All urban minor arterial streets in the city shall have a minimum curb-to-curb width of 60 feet. All urban collector arterial streets in the city shall have a minimum curb-to-curb width of 46 feet. The permittee shall be required to apply Type "B" asphalt street pavement as is necessary to provide continuity between the pre-existing edge of the asphalt to the curb installed in accordance with the width requirements specified herein for any curb and sidewalk installed along any city street. 
(Ord. No. T-72, § 1, 2004; Ord. No. R-53, § 1, 1998; Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.080 - Curbs and sidewalk construction deferment. 
    Permittees applying to construct curbs and sidewalks as provided and required by this chapter, may request a deferment of constructing curbs and sidewalks as required by this chapter, for up to six months. The construction deferment request shall be submitted in writing to the director of public works prior to engaging in any action requiring the construction of curbs and sidewalks. Approval for deferment requests will be based upon weather related hardships only. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.090 - Permit fee. 
    A permit fee shall be charged by the city for the issuance of a curb and/or sidewalk construction permit, which fee shall be in addition to all other fees for permits or charges relative to any proposed work. The amount of such fee shall be $25.00 as a minimum permit fee plus $0.50 per lineal foot of curb and sidewalk after the first 50 feet. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.100 - Performance bond required. 
    Before a curb and sidewalk construction permit may be issued under the provisions of this chapter, the applicant shall deposit with the director of public works a surety bond in an amount equal to the value of the improvement as determined by the director of public works and in a form approved by the city attorney. Said bond shall guarantee compliance with all provisions of this chapter as well as compliance with all conditions specified on the permit as issued by the director of public works. Said bond shall further guarantee that all curb and sidewalk work shall be free from settling and defects in workmanship or materials for a period of two years after the date said work is completed and accepted by the city. The director of public works shall have the authority to waive the performance bond required as noted above in extraordinary circumstances and for homeowners proposing to construct sidewalk improvements valuated at no more than $2,000.00. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.110 - Insurance required. 
    Before a curb and sidewalk construction permit may be issued, the applicant shall secure comprehensive general liability insurance for personal injury and property damage in the amount of $500,000.00 which shall remain in full force and effect throughout the duration of the permit. The policy of insurance shall name the City of Cheney as an additional named insured and shall include a provision prohibiting cancellation of said policy except upon 30 days' prior written notice to the city. Proof that the applicant has such insurance must be furnished to the director of public works prior to issuance of the permit. Homeowners applying for a curb and sidewalk construction permit may submit a copy of their current homeowner's insurance policy for general liability insurance coverage of not less than $100,000.00. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.120 - Routing of traffic. 
    The permittee shall take such measures as are deemed necessary by the director of public works to assure that during the performance of the curb and sidewalk work, preconstruction traffic conditions and flow are maintained as nearly as practicable. No street may be closed by the permittee without the express permission of the director of public works. The permittee shall route and control traffic, including its own vehicles, as directed by the director of public works. Where flagmen are deemed necessary by the director of public works, they shall be furnished by the permittee at the permittee's expense. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.130 - Applicable standards. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, all work performed pursuant to a curb and sidewalk construction permit shall be done in accordance with the standard specifications as written and referenced in the City of Cheney Development Manual. 
    The director of public works may require greater construction standards due to poor soil conditions, poor surface water drainage, or extraordinary grade slopes that in the opinion of the director are in the best interests of public safety. Any greater construction standards imposed shall become a condition of the curb and sidewalk construction permit. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.140 - Construction drawings. 
    The director of public works may require the preparation of construction drawings by a registered civil engineer for curb and sidewalk work that would provide additional information for location, grades and profiles. In addition, the director of public works may require construction drawings to indicate restoration and/or traffic control measures as part of the required work for curb and sidewalk construction. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.150 - Inspection. 
    Permittee is required to provide 48 hours' notice before beginning construction work within the city right-of-way. Permittee is also required to provide 24 hours' notice for inspection of all forms and excavation work. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.160 - Right-of-way restoration. 
    The permittee shall prosecute with diligence and expedite all work, and shall promptly complete such work and restore the street surface and right-of-way to its previous condition as soon as practicable, and in any event, not later than the date specified in the permit. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.170 - Appeals to city council. 
    Any person or persons aggrieved, or any officer, official of any department or commission of the city, jointly or severally, may file a written petition with the city council for a review of the director of public works' interpretation, enforcement provisions, or validity of requirements of this chapter. 
(a)  Each petition for appeal shall contain the legal description, address, or project name which the director of public works' interpretation directly affects. 
(b)  The petition shall set forth the provisions of the curb/sidewalk ordinance regulations which the director of public works has interpreted, the director of public works' interpretation thereof, the petitioner's interpretation of the same and the reasons why the petitioner believes the interpretation of the director of public works to be incorrect or invalid. 
(c)  The petition shall contain the name or names of all aggrieved parties and the names of all attorneys or agents representing the aggrieved parties together with the mailing address of the parties, their agents and attorneys. 
(d)  The mayor's office shall transmit the petition to the city council, who shall fix a date for the hearing on the petition, which date shall not be less than ten days nor more than 60 days from the date upon which the petition was received by the mayor's office. 
(e)  At least ten days prior to the date fixed for the hearing, the mayor's office shall cause to be mailed to the petitioner or their agents or attorneys, and to the owners of affected property and abutting properties, at the respective addresses shown on the petition, a notice of the time and place of the hearing on the petition. At the hearing the petitioner may appear in person, by agent or by attorney. Any other interested persons may be heard at the hearing in support of or opposition to the petition. 
(1)  The city council may initiate a review of the director of public works' interpretation of the provisions of this chapter by a majority vote of the city council. 
(2)  The city council may affirm or reverse the interpretation of the provisions of the curb/sidewalk regulations made by the director of public works, and any order, requirement, decision or determination relating thereto; and the city council's decision shall be based upon the record and the findings in each case, and to that end it shall have all the powers of the director of public works. Unless a majority of the city council vote in favor of reversing the decision of the director of public works, the decision shall stand affirmed. The city council shall maintain in the office of the mayor full and complete written records of all decisions involving the interpretation of the provisions of the curb/sidewalk regulations, which records shall be open to public inspection during all regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.190 - Severability. 
    If any provisions of this chapter, or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of the chapter, or application of the provisions of the chapter to other persons or circumstances is not affected. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 1(part), 1996) 
12.20.200 - Variances. 
    Any variance granted pursuant to section 12.20.060 of this Code prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall remain in effect as granted, provided the director of public works shall review all existing variances and shall give notice that no variance shall be continued beyond the presently effective term thereof unless upon a clear showing that regular pedestrian traffic does not use the street where the variance has been granted. Sidewalks constructed upon expiration of a variance shall conform with the requirements of chapter 12.20 of this Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. Q-69, § 2, 1996) 
12.20.210 - Property owner reimbursement agreement-Optional. 
    A property owner required to comply with the provisions of this chapter, shall have the option of submitting a written request to the director of public works for the purpose of asking that the city undertake the required construction of the curbs, sidewalks and asphalt widening, or any combination thereof, at the expense of the property owner. If the director, upon receiving such a request, determines that it would be feasible for the city to undertake the required work, then the director shall prepare a property owner reimbursement agreement whereby the property owner will agree to reimburse the city for all actual engineering and construction costs incurred by the city in the course of performing the required work on behalf of the property owner. Execution of the property owner reimbursement agreement will require the consent of a majority of the council. 
(Ord. No. R-77, § 1, 1999) 
CHAPTER 12.22 - STREET IMPROVEMENTS-ASSESSMENT REIMBURSEMENT AREA 

12.22.010 - Purpose. 
    Chapter 12.20 of the Cheney Municipal Code establishes the conditions under which street improvements consisting of curbs, sidewalks and asphalt widening must be installed in order to accommodate new construction or improvements, and whereas R.C.W. 35.72.050(1) authorizes a city to create an assessment reimbursement area wherein the city would finance the cost of the street improvements within the assessment reimbursement area and then become the sole beneficiary of the reimbursements charged to the property owners benefiting from the improvements. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.020 - Preliminary determination of assessment reimbursement area. 
    Boundaries/charges. Prior to construction of the street improvements that are identical in nature to those provided for under Chapter 12.20 of the Cheney Municipal Code, which will be financed in whole or part by the city, the city engineer shall prepare and submit to the director of public works, an estimate of the total construction costs for the street improvements along with a map showing those parcels that will be benefiting from the street improvements, but will not be participating with the city in financing the street improvements, but would be required to construct similar street improvements upon development pursuant to R.C.W. 35.72.040(1). The estimate shall include that portion of the total construction cost to be financed by the city which shall then be the basis for making a preliminary determination of the assessment reimbursement charges to be made to the parcels within the assessment reimbursement area. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.030 - Preliminary determination notice. 
    Prior to construction, and pursuant to R.C.W. 35.72.040(2), notice of the preliminary determination of the area boundaries and the assessment reimbursement charges shall be sent by certified mail to the property owners of record within the proposed assessment reimbursement area along with the following statement informing the property owners of their rights and options: 
    As a property owner within the proposed assessment reimbursement area whose preliminary boundaries are enclosed with this notice, you or your heirs and assigns may be obligated to pay under certain circumstances, a pro rata share of the construction and contract administration costs for certain street improvements that have been determined to benefit your property. The proposed amount of such pro rata share of the cost is also enclosed with this notice. You, or your heirs and assigns, may have to pay such share, if any development takes place on your property which would have required, as a condition of development, the street improvements that were financed in whole or part by the City of Cheney, if said development occurs within _____ years from the date the ordinance establishing the final assessment reimbursement charge goes into effect. You have a right to object to your property's assessment charge, and you may do so by requesting a hearing before the Cheney City Council within 20 days of the date of this notice. All such requests must be in writing and filed with the city clerk. After the ordinance establishing the final assessment reimbursement charge goes into effect, it shall be binding on all parcels of record within the assessment area. Dated:________. 
    If any property owner requests a hearing in writing within 20 days of the mailing of the assessment reimbursement charge, a public hearing will be held before the council, notice of which shall be given to all affected property owners. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.040 - Creation of assessment reimbursement area-Ordinance. 
    The council shall make the final determination of the assessment reimbursement area either through a hearing provided for under Cheney Municipal Code section 12.22.030 herein or after a public meeting held more than 20 days after the date the preliminary determination notice was mailed to the affected property owners. An assessment reimbursement area may be ordered only by an ordinance passed by an affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of the council. Every ordinance ordering an assessment reimbursement area shall describe the street improvements and establish an assessment reimbursement area known as "Assessment Reimbursement Area No...." which shall include all of the property specially benefited by the street improvements. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.050 - Assessment reimbursement charge-Method. 
(a)  Upon completion of construction of the street improvements within the assessment reimbursement area, and after determining the portion of the actual construction cost of the street improvements that were financed by the city, the city engineer, pursuant to RCW 35.72.030, shall prepare the assessment reimbursement charge which shall be a pro rata share of both the construction and administration costs of the street improvements. 
(b)  The method or methods used to calculate the allocation of the assessment reimbursement charge may be either front footage, number of units, square footage, or may be the zone termini method or some other recognized method(s) of calculation to determine the benefit accruing to the property as a result of the street improvements within the assessment reimbursement area. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.060 - Assessment reimbursement charge-Hearing. 
    Notice of the assessment reimbursement charge shall be forwarded by certified mail to the property owners of record within the assessment reimbursement area. If any property owner requests a hearing in writing within 20 days of the mailing of the assessment reimbursement charge, a public hearing will be held before the council, notice of which shall be given to all affected property owners. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.070 - Assessment reimbursement charge-Ordinance. 
    The council shall make the final determination of the assessment reimbursement charge either through a hearing provided for under Cheney Municipal Code section 12.22.060 or after a public meeting held more than 20 days after the date the notice was mailed to the affected property owners. An assessment reimbursement charge may be confirmed only by an ordinance passed by an affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of the council. The ordinance confirming the assessment reimbursement charge will be recorded with the Spokane County Auditor's Office within 30 days from the date the ordinance goes into effect. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.080 - Interest on assessment reimbursement charge. 
    If the assessment reimbursement charge is paid within 30 days from the date the ordinance confirming the assessment reimbursement charge goes into effect, no interest is payable. Otherwise, interest is payable from the date the ordinance confirming the assessment reimbursement charge goes into effect until the date of payment of the assessment reimbursement charge. The rate payable will be the Washington State investment pool rate of interest on the date that the ordinance confirming the assessment reimbursement charge goes into effect. Interest is calculated on the basis of a 360-day year and is not compounded. Total interest payable may not exceed the principal amount of the assessment reimbursement charge. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.090 - Administration costs. 
    The city shall add five percent, but not less than $20.00 nor more than $500.00, to each reimbursement charge assessed to the parcels within the assessment reimbursement area for the city's administration costs. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.100 - Payment of assessment reimbursement charge. 
    Payment of the assessment reimbursement charge shall be made by the property owner of record benefitting from the street improvements within the assessment reimbursement area if the property that is the subject of the charge is subsequently developed within 15 years from the date the ordinance confirming the charge goes into effect pursuant to RCW 35.72.020(4). Payment shall be made in one lump sum including interest and administrative costs, prior to the issuance of a building permit for any new development on the property benefitted. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
12.22.110 - Appeal. 
    An appeal with respect to the determination that similar street improvements would be required upon development, which is the basis for determining those parcels that would be assessed, shall be adjudicated through the appellate process provided for under Cheney Municipal Code section 12.20.170. 
(Ord. No. R-76, § 1(part), 1999) 
CHAPTER 12.32 - SNOW REMOVAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Code cities empowered to manage and control all highways, streets and sidewalks, etc.-See RCW ch. 35A.47. 

12.32.010 - Depositing snow from private property on streets, sidewalks. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall shovel, push, doze or by other means remove any snow from any service station lot or driveway, any parking lot, any private driveway or other private property and deposit the same upon any curbing, parking strip, sidewalk, or upon any alley or city street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. D-24, § 1, 12-16-1952) 
12.32.020 - Exception. 
    The provisions of section 12.32.010 of this chapter shall not apply to the removal of snow from any public sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. D-24, § 2, 12-16-1952) 
12.32.030 - Removing snow by truck. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall shovel or otherwise remove any snow from any building or other structure situated on private property and deposit the same in any street or alley within the corporate limits of the city unless the same is immediately loaded upon a truck or other vehicle and removed from such street or alley. Snow sliding from roofs of any building or other structure upon any street or alley shall be construed to have been removed by the owner or tenant thereof and the same shall be immediately removed by truck or other vehicle from such street or alley at the expense of the owner or tenant. 
(Ord. No. D-24, § 3, 12-16-1952) 
12.32.040 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person violating the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined in a sum of not more than $100.00 or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period of not more than 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment and each day's violation thereof, including allowance of removed snow deposited upon any sidewalk, street or alley shall constitute a separate offense and upon conviction thereof a separate penalty shall be assessed for each day's offense. 
(Ord. No. D-24, § 4, 12-16-1952) 
CHAPTER 12.34 - VOLCANIC ASH CLEANUP 

12.34.010 - Findings of council. 
    The city council finds as follows: 
(1)  The eruption of Mt. St. Helens on May 18, 1980, has resulted in the deposit of substantial quantities of volcanic ash upon all areas within the City of Cheney. 
(2)  The volcanic ash so deposited on the city has created serious hazard to the public health, safety and welfare affecting all citizens and residents of the city. 
(3)  It is necessary for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare that the volcanic ash deposited by said eruption be removed from all areas of the city without undue delay. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 1, 1980) 
12.34.020 - Removing ash. 
    It shall be the duty and obligation of each owner and occupant of premises within the city to remove from the premises owned or occupied by them as roofs, driveways, sidewalks and other barren areas not covered by vegetation, substantially all of the ash residue resulting from the eruption of Mt. St. Helens and cause the same to be hauled away and deposited at areas of disposal designated by the city. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 2, 1980) 
12.34.030 - Multiple occupancy owner duty. 
    In the event of multiple occupancy of premises, then the duty to comply with the regulation provided in section 12.34.020, shall be that of the owner of such premises, except any area of such premises which is dedicated to the exclusive use of one occupant. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 2.2, 1980) 
12.34.040 - Depositing ash on public access unlawful. 
    From and after July 11, 1980, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit or cause to be deposited upon the public streets, public sidewalks, or other public ways of the city, any residue of the ash from the eruption of Mt. St. Helens occurring on May 18, 1980. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 2.3, 1980) 
12.34.050 - Ash declared public nuisance. 
    The presence of volcanic ash resulting from the eruption of Mt. St. Helens on May 18, 1980, upon the roofs, driveways, sidewalks, parking areas and other barren areas not covered by vegetation constitutes a public nuisance and a hazard to the public health, safety and welfare to the citizens and residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 4, 1980) 
12.34.060 - Supplemental criminal remedy-Removal notice. 
    In addition to and supplemental to the criminal remedy provided in section 12.34.070 the city, acting through its code enforcement officer may: 
(1)  Issue a notice to comply with the terms of this chapter to any owner or occupant of premises when he finds that the deposit of volcanic ash exists on any roof, driveway, sidewalk, parking area, or other barren area not covered by vegetation. 
(2)  Such notice may be served upon the occupant or owner in the same manner as the service of process, or such notice may be served by United States mail, postage prepaid, directed to the occupant or owner at the occupant's or owner's last address according to city records. 
(3)  Require by such notice that the terms of this chapter be complied with within five days of the date of the service or mailing of such notice. 
(4)  In the event such notice shall remain not complied with within the time set out therein, the city may proceed to remove the volcanic ash referred to in the notice and the actual cost of removal and disposal thereof plus 20 percent thereof as overhead shall be assessed as a civil penalty against the occupant and owner. Such civil penalty shall be recoverable against the occupant and owner by action in the City of Cheney Police Court. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 4.2, 1980) 
12.34.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation convicted of violation of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. K-87, § 3, 1980) 
CHAPTER 12.36 - OBSTRUCTING SIDEWALKS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. Nos. 64, 245, E-9 and J-44. 

12.36.010 - Obstructing sidewalk or street. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to obstruct or encumber any street, alley, or sidewalk by placing thereon any fence, building, structure, excavation, debris, spoil, or other material except as authorized by this code. 
(Ord. No. L-21, § 1(part), 1981) 
12.36.020 - Awnings, canopies, signs, etc. 
    Awnings, canopies, signs and roof extensions may be placed over the public sidewalks provided the same are constructed pursuant to a duly issued-building permit. 
(Ord. No. L-21, § 1(part), 1981) 
12.36.030 - Signs, goods, wares and merchandise on sidewalks. 
    Any occupant of premises abutting a public sidewalk may display or place on the public sidewalk abutting the occupied premises signs, goods, wares and merchandise offered for sale or in the process of delivery to, or removal from, said premises; provided, however, that a pathway on said sidewalk of at least four feet in width shall be kept clear for the unobstructed passage of the public. No such signs, goods, wares or merchandise shall be permitted on any public sidewalk between the hours from 7:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. the following day. 
(Ord. No. L-21, § 1(part), 1981) 
12.36.050 - Riding on sidewalk prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to ride any bicycle upon the sidewalks of any of the streets within the city. 
(Ord. No. N-46, § 2, 1985; Ord. No. L-21, § 1(part), 1981) 
CHAPTER 12.38 - RIGHT-OF-WAY 

12.38.005 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is enacted for the purpose of establishing the procedures to be followed for obtaining a license for the installation of a structure in, over, or under the right-of-way. Any structure that could impede travel in, or the general use of, the right-of-way shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 1, 2003) 
12.38.010 - Definitions. 
    The following terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the following meaning: 
    Address means the address appearing on the license application, or in a written notice of address change or amended license application filed with the director. The address for the city shall be the Director of Public Works, 609 Second Street, Cheney, Washington 99004. 
    City means City of Cheney, Washington. 
    City council means the legislative branch of government for the city. 
    Department means the Cheney Department of Public Works. 
    Director means the director of public works for the City of Cheney, Washington. 
    License means the document issued by the city granting permission for use of right-of-way. License, by definition, does not convey any property right, or any other vested right, title or interest, and is revocable at-will by the Cheney City Council, or by the director of public works pursuant to this chapter. 
    Licensee means the person to whom a license has been issued. 
    Right-of-way means all public property whether improved or unimproved that is dedicated for street and sidewalk use that includes but is not limited to motorized and non-motorized transportation, drainage, and utilities. 
    State means the State of Washington. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 2, 2003) 
12.38.020 - License required. 
    A license shall be required for all right-of-way uses from the date the ordinance enacting this chapter goes into effect. Any unlicensed structure in the right-of-way prior to the enactment of this chapter shall not be construed as having any property right or a vested right of use. The city has the authority and retains the right to require that any unlicensed structure in the right-of-way existing prior to the enactment of this chapter be removed. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 3, 2003) 
12.38.030 - Exemptions. 
    Any maintenance work or improvements made within the right-of-way by the city shall be exempt from this chapter. Parking on city streets shall be exempt from this chapter but strict compliance with all applicable parking regulations under this code shall be required at all times. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 4, 2003) 
12.38.040 - Powers of director. 
    The director of public works shall have the power to administer and interpret all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 5, 2003) 
12.38.050 - Right-of-way license. 
    The issuance of a license shall be required for the installation of structures in, over, or under the right-of-way. A right-of-way license issued under this chapter shall not authorize any structure that impedes the safe and efficient use of the right-of-way. The term of the license may be for up to a five-year period of time. Examples of structures that may qualify for a right-of-way license include but are not limited to: signage, bus shelters/stops, trash receptacles, special and unique structures such as fountains, clocks, flagpoles, benches, kiosks, banners, street furniture, and decorations. Right-of-way licenses shall only be issued to applicants who can demonstrate ownership of the private property immediately adjoining the right-of-way that is the subject of the licensed use. Right-of-way licenses, unless otherwise revoked, may be renewed upon expiration at the discretion of the director. A right-of-way license may be revoked or modified by the director in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or at-will by city council. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 6, 2003) 
12.38.060 - Application and issuance of license. 
(a)  An application for a right-of-way use license shall be filed with the department. All applications must be submitted at least 90 calendar days prior to the proposed use of the right-of-way. Each application shall include at a minimum the following information pertaining to the proposed use: 
(1)  A scale drawing showing the dimensions of the structure that would occupy the right-of-way along with the specific location of the right-of-way; 
(2)  A description of the use including the duration for the use; 
(3)  Evidence showing the applicant owns the property immediately adjoining the right-of-way; 
(4)  All other information that may be required by the director to process the application; 
(5)  Payment of the license processing fee. 
(b)  The director shall review the application to determine whether the information required is sufficient and to determine whether the proposed use is consistent with this chapter. The director shall circulate the application for comments from other city departments. If the director finds that the application is consistent with the requirements under this chapter, then the director may issue the license and impose conditions as necessary to protect the public health and safety while preserving the structural integrity of the right-of-way. If the director denies an application for a license then the applicant shall be sent a notice of the denial by certified mail. If the director denies an application for a license then the applicant may appeal the director's decision under the appellate process provided for under this chapter. 
(c)  A license shall be issued for a specified period, unless otherwise revoked, but in no event shall the license be for a period of more than five years. If the licensee wishes to continue to use the right-of-way beyond the time prescribed under the license then the licensee may apply for a renewal of the license 30 working days prior to the expiration of the license. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 7, 2003) 
12.38.070 - License fees. 
    A non-refundable application and processing fee of $75.00 shall be charged for each license application received. A use fee shall be imposed that shall be calculated on the basis of the square foot value of the license area multiplied by the length of the license. The amount of the use fee shall be established from time to time by city council resolution. The use fee shall be collected at the time the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 8, 2003) 
12.38.080 - Insurance. 
    The licensee shall obtain and maintain public liability and property damage insurance in amount of $100,000.00 which shall remain in full force and effect during the duration of the license. The insurance policy shall name the city as an additional insured party and the policy shall not be canceled or reduced without prior written notice to the city at least 30 days in advance of the cancellation. Proof of insurance shall be provided to the director as a condition for issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 9, 2003) 
12.38.090 - Liens. 
    The licensee, upon receiving notice to remove a structure from the right-of-way shall have ten calendar days in which to remove the structure unless an extension is granted by the director. In the event the licensee fails to remove the structure within ten calendar days after receiving notice or after receiving an extension from the director, the city shall have the authority to remove the structure and the cost of removal shall become a lien against the private property adjoining the right-of-way where the structure was removed. The lien so created shall be subject to foreclosure pursuant to the foreclosure laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 10, 2003) 
12.38.100 - Hold harmless. 
    As a condition for the issuance of the license, the licensee shall agree to defend, indemnify, and hold harmless the city, its officers, employees and agents for any and all suits, claims or liabilities caused by or arising out of any work or use authorized by any such license. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 11, 2003) 
12.38.110 - Revocation of license. 
(a)  All licenses issued under this chapter shall be temporary and shall not vest any right, title, or interest in the right-of-way, and may be revoked at-will by the city council, or revoked by the director for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  In the event of any violation of the terms and conditions of the license, including but not limited to the failure to maintain insurance as required by this chapter; 
(2)  In the event the structure becomes unsafe or unsightly and the licensee fails to take appropriate corrective action; 
(3)  In the event the licensee fails to use the right-of-way as provided for under the license; 
(4)  In the event the city shall need the use of the right-of-way. 
(b)  The licensee shall be notified of the revocation by certified letter sent to the licensee's address. 
(c)  The licensee shall be responsible for all costs necessary to remove the structure from the right-of-way and for the restoration of the right-of-way. 
(d)  The revocation of a license by the director, except for the failure to maintain insurance as required by this chapter, may be appealed under the appellate process provided for under this chapter. 
The city council retains and reserves the authority to modify or revoke a license at-will and the decision is not subject to further appeal under the laws of this state. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 12, 2003) 
12.38.120 - Appeal. 
    Any decision by the director resulting in the denial of a right-of-way license application or the revocation of a right-of-way license issued under this chapter may be appealed to the city council by filing a notice of review with the city clerk within ten calendar days from the date the notification of the denial or revocation is sent by certified mail. The city council's decision shall constitute the final decision of the city. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 13, 2003) 
12.38.130 - Violation-Penalty. 
    In addition to any other penalty or civil action provided by law, any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a class one civil infraction. The maximum penalty and the default amount for committing a class one civil infraction shall be $250.00, not including statutory assessments. Each day's failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter constitutes a separate infraction. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 14, 2003) 
12.38.140 - Severability. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter should be held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section, sentence, clause or phase of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. T-46, § 15, 2003) 
CHAPTER 12.40 - DEBRIS REMOVAL 

12.40.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions are provided for the sole purpose of proper interpretation and administration of this chapter: 
    Building official means the building official for the City of Cheney. 
    Debris includes, but is not limited to, mud, dirt, gravel, rocks, wood or building materials, litter, garbage, or vegetation. 
    Director means of the director of public works for the City of Cheney. 
    Person means any individual, property owners, firm, association, or corporation. 
    Private roads means privately owned and maintained streets and sidewalks as defined under chapter 12.70. 
    Public property means all streets, sidewalks, curbs, alleys, right-of-way, and other public spaces within the City of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 2, 2005) 
12.40.020 - Transportation of debris-Restrictions. 
    Debris shall be transported in tightly contained carriers so as to prevent any of the debris from spilling onto public property and private roads. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 3, 2005) 
12.40.030 - Deposits of debris-Prohibited. 
    Mud, rock, or any other debris falling from the body, fenders, frame, undercarriage, wheels, or tires of a vehicle onto public property and private roads is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 4, 2005) 
12.40.040 - Construction site debris-Preventive measures-Work stoppage. 
    Contractors shall be responsible for instituting measures to reasonably prevent the disposal of debris from their construction sites onto public property and private roads. In addition to the penalty for violating any of the provisions of this chapter as provided for under section 12.040.070, the building official shall have the authority to issue a stop work order for failure to remove debris as specified under section 12.040.050. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 5, 2005) 
12.40.050 - Accumulation of debris-Removal. 
    Any person who is responsible for transporting debris which is deposited onto public property or private roads shall be responsible for the cleanup and removal of the debris to the satisfaction of the director. Failure to remove the accumulation of debris within the time period specified by the director which results in the necessity for the city to undertake such removal in the interest of the public shall cause the violator to be liable for all costs to the city incurred in connection with the removal. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 6, 2005) 
12.40.060 - Damage to public property or private roads-Failure to restore. 
    Any person who damages public property or private roads as a result of depositing debris shall be responsible for restoring such public property or private roads to a condition that is at least equal to the condition that existed prior to the incident causing the damage to the public property or private roads. Such restoration shall be to the satisfaction of the director, within a timeframe stipulated by the director. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 7, 2005) 
12.40.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 8, 2005) 
12.40.080 - Severability. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of the ordinance codified in this chapter should be held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section, sentence, clause or phase of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. U-3, § 9, 2005) 
CHAPTER 12.44 - EXCAVATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
For statutory provisions outlining the powers of code cities to regulate public ways, see RCW 35A.11.020. For the powers of first class cities to manage and control all streets, highways, sidewalks and public lands, see RCW 35.22.280. For the provision granting code cities all the powers of cities of any class, see RCW 35A.21.160. 
Ordinance history: Ord. No. D-22, 1952; Ord. No. G-30, 1968; Ord. No. I-25, 1973; Ord. No. N-8, 1984. 

12.44.010 - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall dig, excavate or penetrate any city roadway or alleyway by creating a ditch, excavation or other sub-grade penetration for water, sewer, storm sewer, natural gas, telephone, cable TV, electrical power or other utility, or for any other purpose, without first obtaining a "roadway excavation permit" therefore issued by the public works department, upon the written approval and recommendation of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.020 - Permit-Application-Copies-Fees. 
    All applicants for a roadway excavation permit shall file a written application therefore in triplicate on forms furnished by the public works department; one copy will be retained by the director of public works, one copy made available to the applicant and one copy made available to the director of public works/construction inspector or the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.030 - Permit. 
    A roadway excavation permit for opening of any roadway owned by the city, shall be issued only upon written approval of the director of public works as provided in section 12.44.010. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.040 - Application-Contents. 
A.  Any person desiring to apply for an excavation permit under this chapter shall do so by filing a written application therefore with the city director of public works. Such application shall be signed by the person who intends to conduct the excavation. Applicant must be a licensed and bonded contractor of the State of Washington. The application shall be in such form as the director of public works may reasonable require and shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 
B.  All applications shall be accompanied by an excavation plan showing the extent of the proposed excavation work. The excavation plan shall indicate all locations and dimensions of the proposed excavation and any other information as may be required by the director of public works. 
C.  A nonrefundable application fee of $75.00 shall accompany each application for the issuance of a roadway excavation permit. Said application fee shall be in addition to all other fees for permits or charges relative to any proposed construction work. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.050 - Term of permit. 
    All excavation permits issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall expire on a date certain, which date shall be established by the director of public works as the date on which the excavation is to be completed. This expiration date shall be clearly noted on the permit. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.060 - Performance bond required. 
    Before an excavation permit may be issued under the provisions of this chapter, the applicant shall deposit with the director of public works a surety bond in an amount determined by the director of public works to be sufficient to ensure collection of the work and fulfillment of the warranty provided for herein and in a form approved by the city attorney. Said bond shall guarantee completion of all excavation and street restoration work required by this chapter and by the conditions of the permit within the time limits set on the permit by the director of public works. Said bond shall further guarantee that all excavation and street restoration work shall be free from settling and defects in workmanship or materials for a period of two years after the date said work is completed and accepted by the city. The director of public works shall have the authority to waive the performance bond required as noted above in extraordinary circumstances. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.070 - Insurance required. 
    Before an excavation permit may be issued, the applicant shall secure comprehensive general liability insurance for personal injury and property damage in the amount of $500,000.00 which shall remain in full force and effect throughout the duration of the permit. The policy of insurance shall name the City of Cheney as an additional named insured and shall include a provision prohibiting cancellation of said policy except upon 30 days prior written notice to the city. Proof that the applicant has such insurance must be furnished to the director of public works prior to issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.080 - Routing of traffic. 
    The permittee shall take such measures as are deemed necessary by the director of public works to assure that during the performance of the excavation work pre-excavation traffic conditions and flow are maintained as nearly as practicable. No street may be closed by the permittee without the express permission of the director of public works. The permittee shall route and control traffic, including its own vehicles, as directed by the director of public works. Where flagmen are deemed necessary by the director of public works, they shall be furnished by the permittee at the permittee's expense. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.090 - Clearance for fire equipment. 
    The excavation work shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire stations and fire hydrants. Materials or obstructions shall not be placed within 15 feet of fire hydrants. Passageways leading to fire escapes or firefighting equipment shall be kept free from obstructions at all times. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.100 - Protection of traffic. 
    The permittee shall erect and maintain suitable barriers to confine earth from trenches or other excavations in order to encroach upon the city streets as little as possible. The permittee shall construct and maintain crossings over excavations and across streets under restoration or improvement which, in the opinion of the director of public works, are adequate and safe to accommodate vehicular and pedestrian traffic at all times. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.110 - Protection of adjoining property-Access. 
    The permittee shall at all times and at the permittee's expense, preserve and protect from injury and adjoining property by providing proper foundations and taking other measures which, in the opinion of the director of public works, are suitable for such purposes. The permittee shall at all times maintain adequate access to all properties adjoining the excavation or work site. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.120 - Protective measures-Fences, barriers. 
    The permittee shall erect at the permittee's expense such fence, railing or barriers about the site of the excavation or street restoration work as, in the opinion of the director of public works, may be necessary to prevent danger to vehicles or pedestrians using the city streets or sidewalks, and such protective barriers shall be maintained until the director of public works otherwise directs. Such protective barriers shall be equipped with adequate lighting to provide for both daytime and nighttime visibility. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.130 - Excavated material-Maintenance required. 
    All excavated material which is piled adjacent to the excavation shall be piled and maintained in such manner so as not to endanger those working in the excavation or pedestrians or users of the streets. When the confines of the area being excavated are too small to permit the piling of excavated material beside the excavation, the director of public works shall be the authority to require the permittee to haul the excavated material to a storage site and then rehaul it to the excavation at the time of backfilling. It is the responsibility of the permittee to secure the necessary permission and make all necessary arrangements for any required storage and disposal of excavated material. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.140 - Cleanup requirements. 
    As the excavation work progresses, all streets and private property shall be thoroughly cleaned of all rubbish, excess earth, rock and other debris resulting from such excavation. All cleanup operations at the location of such excavation shall be accomplished at the expense of the permittee and shall be completed to the satisfaction of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.150 - Backfilling. 
    Backfilling in any street opened or excavated pursuant to an excavation permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be compacted to a degree equivalent to that of the undisturbed ground in which the excavation was begun unless, the director of public works determines a greater degree of compaction is necessary to produce a satisfactory result. All backfilling shall be accomplished according to city standards and specifications and shall meet the approval of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.160 - Street restoration. 
A.  Permanent restoration of the street shall be made by the permittee in strict accordance with the standards and specifications of the City of Cheney and in a manner meeting the approval of the director of public works. Permanent restoration may include overlays of portions of the street which have been disrupted by the excavation work. 
B.  The permittee shall guarantee and maintain the site of the excavation work to city standards and specifications for a period of two years following the completion of the restoration and acceptance by the city. Acceptance or approval of any excavation work or street restoration by the director of public works shall not prevent the city from asserting a claim against the permittee and his or its surety under the surety bond required by this chapter for incomplete or defective work if such incompleteness or defective work is discovered within two years from completion of the excavation work. The presence of the director of public works during the performance of any excavation work shall not relieve the permittee of its responsibilities under this chapter. 
C.  If the permittee has failed to complete the excavation work and restore and surface of the street to city standards and specifications and the approval of the director of public works within the time fixed by the permit, or fails to perform any work or protective measure required by this chapter or by the director of public works shall have this authority to have all such uncompleted work or restoration completed. The permittee shall be liable for any costs incurred by the city in completing such work. The cost for asphalt restoration is as follows: 
Less than 5 sq. yds. = $280.00 5-7 sq. yds. = $28.00 per sq. yd. plus $140.00 setup fee Over 7 sq. yds = $22.00 per sq. yd. plus $185.00 setup fee  
12.44.170 - Pavement cut requirement. 
    Before commencing excavation in a paved street, every permittee doing so, shall first cut the pavement around the circumference or parallel to the excavated area with a pneumatic hammer, saw, cutting wheel or other approved method. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.180 - Inspections. 
    The director of public works or designee may make such inspections as they deem reasonably necessary in the enforcement of this chapter. An inspection fee of $50.00 for the first three days of roadway excavation and every subsequent three-day period shall be assessed $50.00 to the permittee. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.190 - As-built drawings, plans and profiles. 
    Upon completion of the excavation work, the director of public works may request the permittee to submit to the city accurate drawings, plans and profiles showing the location and character of all underground structures installed during the excavation work. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.200 - Provisions not applicable to city work. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to any excavation work or street restoration performed by the city or by any contractor retained by the city to perform such work or restoration on the city's behalf. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.210 - City held harmless. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee of the city any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured by the performance of any excavation work for which an excavation permit is issued under this chapter; nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof by deemed to have assumed such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized under this chapter, the issuance of any permit or the approval of any excavation work. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.220 - Stop work order. 
    The director of public works or his or her designee may issue a written stop work order to any person violating any provision of this chapter or performing any work in violation of any permit issued under this chapter. The written stop work order may be served by delivering the same on any person engaged in the work and/or on the permittee. All such persons shall immediately stop work and/or cause such work to be stopped until further direction by the director of public works or his or her designee to proceed. Such stop work order shall constitute immediate revocation of the permit issued under this chapter, subject to reinstatement of the permit by the director of public works upon the taking of appropriate remedial action. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.230 - Roadway excavation of newly constructed or resurfaced streets. 
A.  Any utility contractor or permittee desiring to trench, dig, open, excavate, etc., in a roadway, that has been recently rebuilt or overlayed, will not be allowed to disturb the roadway surface for a period of five years from the completion of the rebuilding or overlaying of the roadway. At the discretion of the director of public works, the permittee may be allowed to install the utility or its line under the roadway without disturbing the surface. 
B.  In an exceptional situation, with the approval of the director of public works, the newly built or overlayed roadway may be disturbed, upon showing of adequate repair. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
12.44.240 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in a amount not to exceed $1,000.00 or be imprisoned in the city jail or other incarceration facility for a period not to exceed six months. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punished as such hereafter. 
(Ord. No. P-19, § 1(part), 1991) 
CHAPTER 12.46 - STREET IMPROVEMENT PERMITS 

12.46.010 - Required. 
    No private person, firm or corporation shall improve any city street or alley by grading, excavating, filling, or surfacing the same without first obtaining a permit issued by the code enforcement officer upon the written approval and recommendation of the city engineer and the utilities supervisor of the city. Any such improvement for which a permit is issued shall be constructed according to plans and specifications prepared by the city engineer. Such improvement shall be subject to inspection by the code enforcement officer for compliance with such plans and specifications. 
(Ord. No. J-13, § 1, 1975) 
12.46.020 - Fee. 
    No such permit for street or alley improvement shall be issued until the permittee pays to the city a fee calculated by the city engineer to be such sum as will reasonably compensate the city for its engineering and inspection costs in connection with the improvement. 
(Ord. No. J-13, § 2, 1975) 
12.46.030 - Performance bond. 
    No such permit for street or alley improvement shall be issued unless the permittee files with the city clerk a performance bond in such amount as estimated by the city attorney, and conditioned that the permittee shall complete such improvement according to the plans and specifications therefor and maintain proper guards and warning lights during the period of construction. 
(Ord. No. J-13, § 3, 1975) 
12.46.040 - Applicability of sections 12.44.050 through 12.44.070. 
    The provisions of sections 12.44.050, 12.44.060, and 12.44.070 of the Cheney City Code shall be applicable to any work performed under permit issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. J-13, § 4, 1975) 
CHAPTER 12.48 - ASSIGNMENT OF STREET NUMBERS 

12.48.010 - Assignment of street numbers. 
    The assignment of street numbers to buildings and structures shall be the function of the code enforcement officer. The code enforcement officer shall keep a record in his office of all street numbers assigned to each building or structure within the City of Cheney. The code enforcement officer, in the assignment of street numbers, shall take care that the assignment of such numbers shall be consistent throughout the city. The code enforcement officer shall maintain in his office a book of diagrams upon which he shall record the street numbers assigned to each structure within the city. The code enforcement officer is authorized to change those street numbers presently assigned to structures which are misleading or inappropriate. 
(Ord. No. J-91, § 1(part), 1977) 
12.48.020 - Numbering building required. 
    Each person or persons, firm, company, corporation, or association owning, leasing, or controlling any structure or building in the city for which a street number is assigned by the code enforcement officer shall attach or affix to the structure or building the street number specified therefor. 
(Ord. No. J-91, § 1(part), 1977) 
12.48.030 - Nature and size of numerals. 
    The numerals comprising the street number shall be attached to the structure or building in such manner as to stand forth prominently upon that side of the building or structure which faces the street. Each numeral shall be at least three inches in height and two inches in width. 
(Ord. No. J-91, § 1(part), 1977) 
12.48.040 - Penalty for violations. 
    The violation of this chapter shall be considered a misdemeanor and any person being convicted thereof shall be fined in any sum not exceeding $25.00. 
(Ord. No. A-72, § 5, 1916) 
CHAPTER 12.50 - STREET VACATION PROCEDURES 

12.50.010 - Street vacation to accord with RCW chapter 35.79. 
    Streets within the City of Cheney may be vacated only in accordance with RCW chapter 35.79. 
(Ord. No. M-34, § 1, 1983) 
12.50.020 - Appraisal. 
(a)  Prior to passage of any ordinance vacating any street, the mayor shall cause an appraisal to be made of the land to be vacated. The appraisal may be done by any paid employee of the city, or may be made by a committee composed of members of the city council. The appraiser(s) shall consider any evidence of value provided by the person or entity petitioning for vacation, and any other evidence deemed necessary to establish the value of the property. 
(b)  The city council shall accept the appraisal, or may direct additional appraisal be conducted. 
(Ord. No. M-34, § 2, 1983) 
12.50.030 - Appraisal determines nominal value. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall preclude an appraisal determining the property to have a nominal value, and if so determined, the property shall be deemed to have a value of $2.00. Property situated so as to be unmarketable, or if coupled with adjoining property not to substantially increase the value of the adjoining property shall be deemed to have nominal value. 
(Ord. No. M-34, § 3, 1983) 
12.50.040 - Payment to city. 
    No vacation of a street shall be made except upon payment to the city of a sum equal to one-half of the appraised value of the property, and payment for the costs incurred by the city in granting the vacation to include, but not limited to, costs of publication of the vacating ordinance. 
(Ord. No. M-34, § 4, 1983)
