    It shall be unlawful for any purchaser of electricity to add any additional lights or other devices requiring electric current greater than 5KVA in connected load to the service installed and originally inspected without first filing written notice thereof, with the department upon the printed form provided for that purpose, and in addition to incurring the penalty hereinafter provided, such purchaser shall be liable to the city for all damages, arising from interrupted service, or from increased load on meters, transformers or appliances, or occurring in any manner as a result of such addition or additions. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. B-20, § 11, 1940) 
14.04.120 - Bills charged against premises. 
    All bills for electricity shall be charged against the premises where supplied, or the owner thereof, and said premises shall be held liable for the payment of such electricity, together with such penalties as may accrue against the same by reason of any of the provisions of this title, and service to said premises shall be refused until payment thereof is made. No change of ownership, business or occupancy shall affect the application of this section. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. B-20, § 12, 1940) 
14.04.135 - Load switching. 
    Customers whose premises are served by two services shall not switch electrical loads from one service to the other without prior approval of the department. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 2, 1984) 
14.04.140 - City property. 
    All lamps, meters, wires and other appliances supplied by the city shall be and remain the property of the city and may be removed whenever the director shall so elect. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. B-20, § 14, 1940) 
14.04.150 - Separate meters-When required. 
(a)  When any consumer desires to use electricity for purposes classified under different rates, separate meters must be installed to measure the electricity supplied at each rate, and the electricity passing through each meter must be charged for at the prices specified in the rate schedule for such separate use. 
(b)  Where more than one meter is required to record the consumption of the customer, the consumption of each meter shall be computed separately in rendering bills. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. B-20, § 15, 1940) 
14.04.155 - Delivery point. 
    The rates in sections 14.04.190 through 14.04.248 are based upon the supply of service to the entire premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single voltage and phase. Separate supply for the same customers at other points of consumption, or at different voltage or phase, shall be separately metered and billed. 
(Ord. No. R-28, § 3, 1997) 
14.04.160 - Billing-Payment date. 
(a)  Each meter shall be read monthly and on or about the same day of each month, as may be practicable. The city shall mail each customer a statement each month setting forth the charges for usage. All charges shall be due and payable 15 days after the date of mailing of such statement and shall become delinquent the next following business day after the 15 th day. 
(b)  Delinquent charges shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  All charges for electrical connections, service and usage provided in this chapter, together with penalties and interest thereon, shall be a lien upon the property to which such electrical service is rendered, in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  As an additional and concurrent method of enforcing the lien for electrical service, charges, and interest, the city may, after delinquency, shut off the electrical service. Service shall not be restored until the delinquent bill, interest thereon, the disconnect notice fee specified in subsection (f), and the reconnection charge specified in subsection (e) of this section, shall have been paid in full. 
(e)  When service shall have been shut off for failure to pay amounts due, the reconnection charge shall be as follows: 
(1)  If reconnection is requested to be made during the regular business hours, between 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Monday through Friday except holidays, no reconnection charge in addition to the disconnect notice fee specified in subsection (f) of this section shall be assessed; when the reconnection must be made at the pole, rather than at the meter base, the reconnection fee shall be established by resolution of the city council; 
(2)  If reconnection is requested to be made outside of the normal business hours described in subsection (e)(1) of this section, a fee established by resolution of the city council shall be applied, in addition to the disconnect notice fee; when the reconnection outside of normal business hours must be made at the pole, rather than at the meter base, the reconnection fee shall be established by resolution of the city council in addition to the disconnect notice fee; 
(f)  When a disconnect notice has been ordered for failure to pay, a disconnect notice fee established by resolution of the city council shall be charged to the delinquent account. This charge shall be in addition to interest on the delinquent bill described in subsection (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 1, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 1, 2005; Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. J-96, § 1, 1977; Ord. No. B-20, § 16, 1940) 
14.04.165 - Billing demand. 
    The billing demand is the maximum average kva (thousand volt amps) load used by the customer for any period of 15 consecutive minutes during the month for which the bill is rendered, as indicated or recorded by a demand meter. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 2, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. R-28, § 4, 1997) 
14.04.167 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-78, § 3, adopted December 8, 2015, repealed § 14.04.167, which pertained to power factor charge and derived from Ord. No. R-28, § 5, 1997. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 3, 12-8-2015) 
14.04.170 - Meter-Broken-Charge. 
    If the seal of the city's meter is broken, or the meter from any cause does not properly register, the consumer shall be charged the average daily consumption as shown by the meter during the previous six months. 
(Ord. No. B-20, § 17, 1940) 
14.04.180 - Tampering with system. 
    It is unlawful for any person to in any manner injure, mutilate, destroy, remove, disconnect, or in anywise interfere or tamper with any of the machinery, poles, wires, meters, underground ducts, structures, cables, or other appurtenance belonging to or in any manner connected with the electric system of the city. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1985; Ord. No. B-20, § 18, 1940) 
14.04.185 - Charge for unauthorized use. 
    In addition to criminal penalties as provided under section 14.04.180, any person who tampers with a city's electric meter or other parts of the city's electric system for the purpose of obtaining electricity without the city's authorization shall be subject to: 
(1)  A tampering charge established by resolution of the city council; and 
(2)  A charge equal to three times the cost of the electricity consumed during the unauthorized use, calculated under the applicable electric rates in effect at that time, plus applicable taxes. 
    In addition to the fees stated in this section, a reconnection charge shall be paid before service is restored. 
    Billing for unauthorized use charges is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 2, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 2, 2005; Ord. No. R-18, § 1, 1997) 
14.04.190 - Schedule 1-Residential rate. 
(a)  Availability . 
(1)  This schedule is applicable to residential customers for all domestic use, including water heating, space heating and single-phase motors not in excess of seven and one-half horsepower individual capacity, in single private dwellings and their appurtenances, including clubs and fraternities occupying a private dwelling where the occupants share the expense thereof on a nonprofit basis. 
(2)  Where a portion of a dwelling is regularly used for business purposes, the energy consumed in that portion so used will be separately metered and billed at the applicable commercial rates. In the event that separate circuits are not provided by the customer, the entire premises shall be classified as nonresidential and billed accordingly. The residential rate shall not apply to service to institutions such as recognized rooming houses and boarding houses operated for profit, the space in an apartment or other residential buildings primarily used as an office or studio for professional or other gainful purposes. 
(b)  Customer service charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Energy charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Tax adjustment . Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 3, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 1, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 1, 2001; Ord. No. R-28, § 6, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 1, 1991; Ord. No. O-47, § 1, 1988; Ord. No. M-46, § 1, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 1, 1982; Ord. No. L-20, § 1, 1981; Ord. No. K-60, § 1, 1979; Ord. No. K-4, § 1(part), 1978; Ord. No. J-38, § 1, 1976; Ord. No. I-81, § 1, 1974; Ord. No. E-23, 1956; Ord. No. B-95, Schedule 1, 1950) 
14.04.200 - Schedule 2-General service. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to all commercial and nonresidential light, heat and power customers and multi-family residential facilities with a common meter, except flat-rate street lighting, outdoor area lighting, large power service and public authorities, charges for which are set out in subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section. Energy supplied under this schedule shall not be submetered for resale or resold to others. 
(b)  Customer service charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Energy charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Billing demand charge . 
(1)  Established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Power factor charge. The billing demand charge shall be adjusted for power factor correction as described in section 14.04.167 of this chapter. 
(f)  Tax adjustment . Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. X-03, § 1, 12-13-2016; Ord. No. W-42, § 4, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 2, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 2, 2001; Ord. No. R-28, § 7, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 2, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 2, 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 2, 1991; Ord. No. O-47, § 2, 1988; Ord. No. N-75, § 1, 1986; Ord. No. M-46, § 2, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 2, 1982; Ord. No. M-12, § 2, 1982; Ord. No. L-20, § 2, 1981; Ord. No. K-60, § 2, 1979; Ord. No. K-4, § 1(part), 1978; Ord. No. I-87, § 1, 1975; Ord. No. I-81, § 2, 1974; Ord. No. F-98, § 1, 1967; Ord. No. B-95, § 2, 1950) 
14.04.210 - Schedule 3-Public authority service. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to all municipalities or divisions or agencies of federal or state governments. 
(b)  Customer service charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Energy charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Billing demand charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Tax adjustment. Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 4, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. W-42, § 5, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 3, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 3, 2001; Ord. No. R-28, § 9, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 3, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 3, 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 3, 1991; Ord. No. 0-47, § 3, 1988; Ord. No. N-75, § 2, 1986; Ord. No. M-46, § 3, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 3, 1982) 
14.04.220 - Schedule 4-Flat rate street lighting. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to the municipal government of the City of Cheney only. The light department will furnish under this schedule all standards, pole brackets, transformers, regulators, switches, wire, ducts and miscellaneous equipment necessary to furnish service under this classification. The applied rates include lamp replacements and all necessary maintenance and replacement of equipment. 
(b)  Customer service charge . All energy shall be furnished at rates established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Tax adjustment . Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 6, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 4, 2004; Ord. No. S-61, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. S-52, § 4, 2001; Ord. No. S-34, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. R-98, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. R-60, § 1, 1998; Ord. No. R-36, § 1, 1998; Ord. No. R-28, § 9, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 4, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 4, 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 4, 1991; Ord. No. M-46, § 4, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 4, 1982; Ord. No. L-20, § 3, 1981; Ord. No. K-60, § 3, 1979; Ord. No. K-4, § 1(part), 1978; Ord. No. I-81, § 4, 1974; Ord. No. B-5, Schedule 4, 1950) 
14.04.230 - Schedule 5-Outdoor area lighting rate. 
(a)  Availability . This schedule shall be applicable to service for outdoor area lighting systems and other electrical devices which are controlled by a photoelectric cell and which do not exceed 250 watts. 
(b)  Character of service . Alternating current service, either series of multiple systems, or in combination, at option of the light department. 
(c)  Service charge . Services shall be unmetered and charged at rates established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Location of equipment . The light department may, at the request of the customer, locate and install the equipment. The customer shall reimburse the department for such installation at actual costs including overhead costs, as prescribed by section 14.04.250, excluding the cost of the lighting fixture, lamp and installations of the lighting fixture. 
(e)  Relocation of equipment . The light department shall, at the request of the customer, relocate or change existing equipment. The customer shall reimburse the light department for such changes at actual costs including overhead charges as prescribed by section 14.04.250 
(f)  Tax adjustment . Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 7, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. R-28, § 10, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 5, 1994; Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1985; Ord. No. M-46, § 5, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 5, 1982; Ord. No. K-60, § 4, 1979; Ord. No. K-4, § 1(part), 1978; Ord. No. I-81, § 5, 1974; Ord. No. B-5, Schedule 5, 1950) 
14.04.240 - Schedule 6-Temporary service. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to all customers wishing temporary service, the city supplying such service contingent on availability of power and facilities. 
(b)  Installation charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(1)  If the pole-line facilities must be extended, or if three-phase service is desired, the customer will be charged the actual cost of labor for construction and dismantlement, plus rental of the additional transformers, switches, poles, wires, etc., required to render the service, including appropriate overheads. 
(c)  Customer service charge . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Energy charges . Established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Tax adjustment . Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 8, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-90, § 2, 10-14-2008; Ord. No. T-54, § 5, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 5, 2001; Ord. No. R-28, § 11, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 6, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 5, 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 4, 1991; Ord. No. M-46, § 6, 1984; Ord. No. M-14, § 6, 1982; Ord. No. L-20, § 4, 1981; Ord. No. K-4, § 1(part), 1978; Ord. No. I-81, § 6, 1974; Ord. No. B-95, Schedule 6, 1950) 
14.04.245 - Schedule 7-University. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to services to Eastern Washington University receiving service at primary voltage whose capacity requirement is in excess of 1,500 kilowatts of demand per month. 
(b)  Energy charges. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Billing demand charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Customer service charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Tax adjustment. Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 5, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. W-42, § 9, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 6, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 6, 2001; Ord. No. S-15, § 2, 2000; Ord. No. R-28, § 12, 1997; Ord. No. Q-35, § 7, 1994; Ord. No. P-86, § 6(part), 1993; Ord. No. P-16, § 6, 1991; Ord. No. N-75, § 3, 1986; Ord. No. M-46, § 7, 1983; Ord. No. M-14, § 7, 1982; Ord. No. L-20, § 5, 1981; Ord. No. K-73, § 1, 1980; Ord. No. K-60, § 5, 1979) 
14.04.247 - Schedule 11-Utility transformation service. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to other electric distribution utilities which receive electric service over light department substation transformer facilities. 
(b)  Delivery charges. Charges will be established by agreement between the electric distribution utility and the city. 
(c)  Tax adjustment. Billing is not subject to tax adjustment. 
(Ord. No. U-90, § 1, 10-14-2008; Ord. No. T-54, § 8, 2004) 
14.04.248 - Schedule 8-Large primary service. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule is applicable to all large commercial and industrial customers receiving service at primary voltage whose capacity requirements is in excess of 2,000 kilowatts of demand per month. 
(b)  Energy charges. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Billing demand charge. Established by resolution of the city council. Customers who receive service at more than one metering point on the same premises shall be billed on a coincidental demand basis. 
(d)  Customer service charge. Established by resolution of the city council. 
(e)  Tax adjustment. Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 6, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. W-42, § 10, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. T-54, § 7, 2004; Ord. No. S-52, § 7, 2001; Ord. No. S-15, § 3, 2000; Ord. No. R-28, § 14, 1997; Ord. No. R-20, § 1, 1997) 
14.04.249 - Schedule 10-Leased equipment. 
(a)  Availability. This schedule shall be applicable for customers who have signed agreements with the department for the use of department-owned equipment on the customer's premises. 
(b)  Customer service charge. 
(1)  The monthly rate of leased equipment shall be calculated by: dividing the initial cost of the equipment (including the labor, equipment and materials required to place the equipment in service, the cost of maintenance of the equipment during its use, and the overhead charges as prescribed in section 14.04.250), by the number of months in the life expectancy for that type of equipment as determined following generally accepted depreciation schedules for such equipment. 
(2)  There shall be no charge for removal of leased equipment. The director may refuse to install the leased equipment if the customer has requested that similar equipment be removed within the past year. 
(c)  City ownership. Equipment leased by the department to the customer shall remain the property of the city. The customer shall be responsible for damage or loss of the property while in the customer's possession. Leased equipment which has been damaged beyond normal wear and tear, or which is not recoverable by the department at the termination of the lease, shall be charged to the customer at the depreciated cost, including overhead charges as prescribed in section 14.04.250. 
(d)  Limit of liability. The city provides for the lease of equipment as a convenience to its customers. The city's liability for equipment leased under this section shall be limited to the work performed by the city. Liability for manufacture and design of the equipment is limited to manufacturer's warranties. The city makes no warranty as to the effectiveness, efficiency or safety of the equipment. The customer is advised to read carefully all materials provided by the manufacturer, and to operate the equipment in the prescribed manner. 
(e)  Tax adjustment. Billing is subject to tax adjustment as provided by law, federal, state, county or municipal, which may be in effect as of the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter or thereafter enacted. 
(Ord. No. R-18, § 2, 1997) 
14.04.250 - Charge for work, material. 
    All work and material performed or furnished by the department to customers except as provided for in sections 14.08.040 and 14.08.050 shall be charged for at the cost thereof. 
(Ord. No. Q-11, § 1, 1994; Ord. No. B-20, § 30, 1940) 
14.04.255 - Connection charges. 
    Each person making application to purchase electricity from the city shall pay the city a connection charge for service through each separate meter at the following rates: 
(a)  When connection is requested to be made between 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Monday through Friday except holidays, a charge established by resolution of the city council will be applied. 
(b)  When connection is requested to be made outside of the hours specified in subsection (a) of this section, a charge established by resolution of the city council will be applied. 
(c)  The after hours reconnect fee will not be charged on the designated disconnect/reconnect day for a request made before 4:00 pm. 
(Ord. No. W-42, § 11, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-56, § 3, 2007; Ord. No. U-11, § 3, 2005; Ord. No. N-25, § 1(part), 1984; Ord. No. I-91, § 1, 1975) 
14.04.260 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; and in addition to the penalty hereinabove provided, the service of any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this title shall be disconnected, and the person violating shall be liable for all damages resulting and for all extra current used by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. U-11, § 4, 2005; Ord. No. B-20, § 31, 1940) 
14.04.270 - Municipal tax on electric utility. 
    The city utility tax imposed pursuant to CMC 5.40.035 is computed as a cost to the respective utility fund as a percentage of gross income and is not computed as a surcharge upon the individual rate. The tax is imposed upon the entire electric service area for the City of Cheney Light Department. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 7, 12-8-2015) 
CHAPTER 14.08 - SERVICE 

14.08.010 - Purpose. 
    This chapter establishes the policy of the city for: additions to the electrical power facilities of the city; the charges and allowances for electric service; and other matters related to the delivery and acceptance of electrical energy. 
(Ord. No. W-43, § 1, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. N-25, § 3(part), 1984; Ord. No. J-34, § 1, 1976) 
14.08.020 - Conditions of service. 
    Subject to the supply of electrical energy available to the city through Bonneville Power Administration and other electrical power suppliers, the city will furnish electrical energy to customers within the city's service area in compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. W-43, § 2, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. N-25, § 3(part), 1984; Ord. No. J-34, § 2, 1976) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-43, § 2, adopted Aug. 26, 2014, amended § 14.08.020, and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Policy statement" to "Conditions of service" as set out herein. 
14.08.030 - Determination that electrical power is available. 
    Upon receipt of an application to purchase electrical energy and/or extend the city's electrical distribution system to an area not then served by the city, the director shall determine whether or not electrical energy is available to the applicant. Should the director determine that adequate electrical energy is not available as required in the application, the director may reject the application provided the reasons for such rejection are stated in writing. 
(Ord. No. W-43, § 3, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. N-25, § 3(part), 1984; Ord. No. J-34, § 3, 1976) 
14.08.040 - Rates for new extensions and installations. 
    The charges to the customer for the extension of new primary or secondary service or alteration of existing primary or secondary electrical service from city electrical lines, including poles, transformers, conductors and other equipment for a line extension or service change to the lines or facilities to the point of interconnection with the customer's equipment, shall be the cost of labor, equipment and materials as established by resolution of the city council. (Ord. No. W-78, § 8, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. W-43, § 4, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 5, 2005; Ord. No. Q-11, § 2, 1994; Ord. No. N-25, § 3(part), 1984; Ord. No. K-83, § 1, 1980; Ord. No. J-34, § 4, 1976) 
14.08.050 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. W-78, § 9, adopted December 8, 2015, repealed § 14.08.050, which pertained to rates for new extensions and installations-underground services and derived from Ord. No. W-43, § 5, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 6, 2005, Ord. No. Q-11, § 3, 1994; Ord. No. N-25, §3 (part), 1984; Ord. No. K-83, § 2, 1980; Ord. No. J-34, § 5, 1976. 
14.08.055 - New large single electric load. 
(a)  For the City of Cheney. a new large single load (NLSL) is defined as new load to the system having an anticipated usage of over one (1) average megawatt. 
(b)  The rate and class for any NLSL shall be determined by resolution of the city council. This rate will be based on the impact to the existing customers rates, the price of Tier 2 (or other acquired) power from BPA, additional transmission cost and the financial impact of the NLSL on the city electric utility. 
(Ord. No. W-78, § 10, 12-8-2015) 
14.08.060 - Cancellation or change of service request. 
    When a customer requests to cancel or change the service date for a previously submitted service request, either for a connect or a disconnect, the customer shall be charged a cancellation/change fee as established by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. W-43, § 6, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 7, 2005) 
14.08.070 - Address correction fee. 
    When a customer submits a service request for the wrong service address, the customer may be charged an address correction fee as established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. W-43, § 7, 8-26-2014; Ord. No. U-11, § 8, 2005) 
14.08.080 - Written agreement-Bond or cash deposit required. 
(a)  In every instance where all or a portion of the cost of the installation of electrical service is to be borne by the applicant, an agreement shall be executed in writing between the applicant and the city setting forth the applicant's estimated cost and describing the work to be performed. Such agreement may be executed on behalf of the city by the director without further authorization of the city council. 
(b)  The applicant shall furnish the city a bond, with a qualified corporate surety, in a form approved by the city attorney, or may deposit cash in lieu of bond, as security for payment of the costs chargeable to the applicant; the bond or cash deposit shall be conditioned that the applicant will pay the city the applicant's portion of the cost of the work requested by the application within 30 days after substantial completion of the work. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the executed written agreement and of the bond or cash deposit, the city shall proceed with the work without reasonable delay. 
(Ord. No. N-25, § 3(part), 1984; Ord. No. J-34, § 8, 1976) 
14.08.090 - Customer may contract with qualified electrical contractor. 
    In accordance with section 35.22.640 of the Revised Code of Washington, when an electric customer requests a temporary service, permanent service, or expanded service, the customer may, with the written approval of the light department, contract with a qualified electrical contractor licensed under chapter 19.28 RCW to install any material or equipment in lieu of having city utility personnel perform the installation. 
(a)  In the event the city-owned electric utility denies the customer's request to utilize a private electrical contractor for such installation work, it shall provide the customer with written reasons for such denial. 
(b)  If a customer elects to employ a private electrical contractor as provided in this section, the private electrical contractor shall be solely responsible for any damages resulting from the installation of any temporary service, permanent service, or expanded service and the city shall be immune from any tortious conduct actions as to that installation. 
(c)  Design of any improvements done under this section must be approved by the light department prior to construction. 
(d)  The property owner will be charged for the cost of the light department's inspection of the improvements, up to a maximum of 15 percent of the value of the improvements. Following inspection and acceptance, ownership of these facilities will be transferred to the city. 
(Ord. No. U-11, § 9, 2005) 
CHAPTER 14.10 - POLE ATTACHMENTS 

14.10.010 - General provisions. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to ensure the safe and efficient use of overhead lines on city-owned poles within the city's rights-of-way or public utility easements and to compensate the city for the use of the poles. This chapter establishes provisions necessary to ensure compliance with city ordinances and state statutes, and the city's standard construction practices and specifications. 
    This chapter applies to all current or future electric and telecommunication system entities that attach lines, equipment, or other devices to city-owned poles, also referred to as "licensees," provided that annual pole attachment fees set under agreements which precede the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall continue under the terms of the agreements until the expiration or termination of the agreements. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations, shall have the meaning given herein, unless more specifically defined within a specific section of this agreement: 
    Applicable standards means all applicable engineering and safety standards governing the installation, maintenance and operation of facilities and the performance of all work in or around electric utility facilities and includes the most current versions of National Electrical Safety Code ("NEC"), and the regulations of the Washington Industrial Safety and Health Act ("WISHA"), each of which is incorporated by reference in this chapter, and/or other reasonable safety and engineering requirements of the city or other federal, state or local authority with jurisdiction over city facilities. 
    Assigned space means space on the city's poles or within the city's conduit system that can be used, as defined by the applicable standards, for the attachment or placement of wires, cables and associated equipment for the provision of communications service or electric service. The neutral zone or safety space is not considered assigned space. 
    Attachment means the licensee's communications facilities that are placed directly on the city's poles or overlashed onto an existing attachment or that are placed within the city's conduit system, but does not include either a riser or a service drop attached to a single pole where the licensee has an existing attachment on such pole. 
    Capacity means the ability of a pole or conduit system segment to accommodate an additional attachment based on applicable standards, including space and loading considerations. 
    City facilities means all personal property and real property owned or controlled by the City of Cheney, including poles and conduit system. 
    Common space means space on the city's poles that is not used for the placement of wires or cables but which jointly benefits all users of the poles by supporting the underlying structure and/or providing safety clearance between attaching entities and electric utility facilities. 
    Communications facilities means wire or cable facilities including but not limited to fiber optic, copper and/or coaxial cables or wires utilized to provide communications service including any and all associated equipment. Unless otherwise specified by the parties, the term "communications facilities" does not include wireless antennas, receivers or transceivers. 
    Communications service means the transmission or receipt of voice, video, data, Internet or other forms of digital or analog signals over communications facilities. 
    Conduit system means the city's conduits, manholes, vaults, risers, pull-boxes and trenches. 
    Director means the director of the city light department or his/her designee. 
    Licensee means an owner of communications facilities, its authorized successors and assignees, who has received a license to attach its communications facilities to city poles. 
    Make-ready work means all work, as reasonably determined by the city, required to accommodate the licensee's communications facilities and/or comply with all applicable standards. Such work includes, but is not limited to, pre-construction survey, rearrangement and/or transfer of city facilities or existing attachments, inspections, engineering work, permitting work, tree trimming (other than tree trimming performed for normal maintenance purposes), pole replacement and construction, or conduit system clearing. 
    Occupancy means the use or specific reservation of assigned space for attachments on the same utility pole or portion of the utility's conduit system. 
    Overlash means to place an additional wire or cable communications facility onto an existing attachment owned by the licensee. 
    Permit means written or electronic authorization of the city for the licensee to make or maintain attachments to specific city poles or spans of the conduit system pursuant to the requirements of this agreement. 
    Pole means a pole owned by the city used for the distribution of electricity and/or communications service that is capable of supporting attachments for communications facilities. 
    Pre-construction survey means all work or operations required by applicable standards and/or the city to determine the potential make-ready work necessary to accommodate the licensee's communications facilities on a pole or within a span of the conduit system. Such work includes, but is not limited to, field inspection and administrative processing. The pre-construction survey shall be coordinated with the city and include the licensee's professional engineer. 
    Reserved capacity means capacity or space on a pole or within a portion of the conduit system that the city has identified and reserved for its own electric utility requirements, including the installation of communications circuits for operation of the city's electric system, pursuant to a reasonable projected need or business plan. 
    Tag means to place distinct markers on wires and cables, coded by color or other means specified by the city and/or applicable federal, state or local regulations, that will readily identify the type of attachment (e.g., cable TV, telephone, high-speed broadband data, public safety) and its owner. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.030 - Notification and coordination. 
(a)  Wherever in this chapter notice is required to be given by the licensee to the city, notice shall be made to the city clerk. For notices required to be given by the city to the licensee, the licensee shall from time to time provide to the city clerk the proper address to submit such notices. Such notices shall be in writing and shall be effective when personally delivered to, or when mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, with postage prepaid and, except where specifically provided for elsewhere, properly addressed to the party receiving the notice. 
(b)  The licensee shall maintain a staffed 24-hour emergency telephone number, not available to the general public, where the city can contact the licensee to report damage to the licensee's facilities or other situations requiring immediate communications between the parties. Such contact person shall be qualified and able to respond to the city's concerns and requests. Failure to maintain an emergency contact shall subject the licensee to a penalty established by resolution of city council, and shall eliminate the city's liability to the licensee for any actions that the city deems reasonably necessary given the specific circumstances. 
(c)  Response to city notifications. Each licensee shall within ten calendar days respond to city notifications related to, but not limited to, maintenance, relocation, rearrangement, violations or abandonment of joint pole installations. 
(d)  Replacement or relocation of joint use poles. Whenever it is necessary to replace or relocate a joint-use pole, the city shall give notice in writing at least 30 days prior to the date on which it intends to change such pole (except in case of emergency, when verbal notice will be given and subsequently confirmed in writing) to the licensees. Each licensee shall relocate facilities to the new pole within 60 days at the expense of the licensee as provided by this chapter. When circumstances warrant additional time to relocate, the director may grant such additional time as is reasonable under the circumstances. 
(1)  Relocation of poles requiring overhead lines to be relocated overhead. If such relocation is reasonably necessary for construction, alteration or improvement of the right-of-way for purposes of public health, safety and welfare, as required by the city, licensees may not seek reimbursement for their relocation expenses from the city unless otherwise provided for by law. In the event the relocation is requested by a private third-party, that third-party shall pay the cost of relocation. 
(2)  Relocation of facilities from overhead to underground. If such relocation is requested by the city when reasonably necessary for construction, alteration or improvement of the right-of-way for purposes of public welfare, health and safety, the licensee may not seek reimbursement for its relocation expenses from the city, unless otherwise provided for by law. If requested by a private third-party, the third-party shall pay the cost of such relocation. 
(3)  Discontinued use of poles. In the event of discontinued use of poles by the city, all licensees may be afforded an opportunity to purchase such poles at a fair market value, in accordance with city policy and state law. 
(e)  In the event the city wishes to discontinue use of any such pole or poles and to remove, relocate and/or retire it or them, it shall send a written notice to that effect to the licensees and the licensees shall remove the attachments from such pole or poles within 60 days after the sending of such notice or within such shorter period of time as is required in case of emergency. 
(f)  Coordination. Sufficient coordination, including submittal of project plans and exchange of information, shall take place between licensees so that the attachment does not create a violation of, or conflict with, any applicable legal requirement. All licensees shall promptly share design specifications for their infrastructure with others upon request. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.040 - Transfers. 
(a)  Required transfers of licensee's communications facilities. If the city reasonably determines that a transfer of the licensee's communications facilities is necessary, the city will, at its option, either perform the transfer using its personnel, and/or contractors and/or require the licensee to perform such transfer at its own expense within 60 calendar days after receiving notice from the city. If the licensee fails to transfer its facilities within 60 calendar days after receiving such notice from the city, the city shall have the right to transfer the licensee's facilities using its personnel and/or contractors at the licensee's expense plus the penalty specified in this chapter. The city shall not be liable for damage to the licensee's facilities except to the extent provided in section [liability]. The written advance notification requirement of this section shall not apply to emergency situations, in which case the city shall provide such advance notice as is practical given the urgency of the particular situation. The city shall then provide written notice of any such actions taken within ten days of the occurrence. Irrespective of who owns them, the licensee is responsible for the transfer of facilities that are overlashed on to the licensee's attachments. 
(b)  Billing for transfers performed by the city. If the city performs the transfer(s), the city will bill the licensee for actual costs in accordance with section 14.10.080. The licensee shall reimburse the city within 30 calendar days of the receipt of the invoice. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.050 - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Certification of designs. Unless excepted by the city, cabling and pole attachment designs, specifically relating to pole strength and clearances considering all pole attachment uses, as required by the Washington Industrial Safety and Health Act, shall be certified by a qualified designer and approved by the city. 
(b)  Safety. Licensees, in accordance with applicable national, state and local safety requirements, shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain facilities and shall use commonly accepted methods and devices to prevent failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injury or nuisance to the public. Licensee's facilities in, over, under any city rights-of-way or property, shall at all times be kept and maintained in a safe, suitable condition and in good order and repair. 
(c)  Violation of codes or standards. In any instance where the licensee's facilities are installed contrary to the Electrical Construction Code of the State of Washington or the city's standard practices and specifications, the licensee shall, at its sole expense, and within 30 days following written notice from the city, change, improve, or renew its installed equipment in such manner as the city may direct. If violation of any conditions applicable to the installation is observed, the city reserves the right to stop construction immediately and correction of the violation will be made before any part of the construction is continued. 
(d)  Guys and anchors. The licensee shall, at its expense, install guys necessary to support the strain imposed on any pole by the installation of its facilities. When existing anchors are adequate in size and strength to support the equipment of all licensees, a licensee may attach its guys thereto. When anchors are not of adequate size and strength, the party whose new facilities necessitate additional anchors shall, at its own expense, install new anchors or request the owner to replace existing anchors with anchors adequate in size and strength. 
(e)  Responsibility for costs. The licensee shall bear all costs involved in contacting any pole owned by the city. If it is necessary for the city to do any work on poles to provide contact space, this work will be done only as crews are available to do so in their regular work schedule. Any other schedule will be on overtime rate at the expense of the company whose new facilities necessitate the work. 
(f)  Communications space available to licensees. 
(1)  Use of available space occupied by others. Where space is available and in compliance with the State of Washington Electrical Construction Code and all other applicable legal requirements, licensees engaged in the telecommunications utility business may be allotted contact space in the area occupied by other licensees. 
(2)  Conditions of use. All licensees shall operate and maintain their communications facilities in such a condition as to avoid conflict or interference with other licensees. Additions to or alterations by a licensee shall be coordinated with all licensees. A licensee may not prevent the installation, alteration or maintenance of facilities of another licensee. Changes to communications facilities on a joint use pole shall be at the expense of the party whose activities necessitate the changes. 
(g)  Maintenance and emergency repairs. 
(1)  Maintenance required. Each party shall at all times maintain all of its attachments, perform any necessary tree-trimming or cutting incidental thereto and shall keep them in safe conditions and in thorough repair. 
(2)  Emergency work by city. In an emergency where it is necessary to clear lines and restore electric power to the city's customers as the result of an accident, windstorm, earth slide, or other condition where power lines, poles or other supporting structures are damaged, destroyed or are in serious danger, the city may transfer the licensee's facilities to new or other poles or do any other work required in connection with the licensee's equipment necessary to restore electric service to the city's customers. The licensee shall reimburse the city for all costs incurred in connection with such emergency work done on the licensee's facilities. 
(h)  Overlashing. Permits are required for any overlashing allowed under this chapter and the licensee shall pay any necessary make-ready work costs to accommodate such overlashing. 
(i)  Permits for work in public or private right-of-way. Licensee shall be responsible for obtaining from the appropriate public or private authority or other appropriate persons any required authorization to construct, operate and/or maintain its communications facilities on public and/or private property before it occupies any portion of the city's poles. The city retains the right to require evidence that appropriate authorization has been obtained before any permit is issued to the licensee. The licensee's obligations under this section include, but are not limited to, its obligation to obtain all necessary approvals to occupy public/private rights-of-way and to pay all associated costs. The licensee shall defend, indemnify and reimburse the city for all loss and expense, including reasonable attorney's fees, that the city may incur as a result of claims by governmental bodies, owners of private property, or other persons, that the licensee does not have sufficient rights or authority to attach the licensee's communications facilities on the city's poles or within its conduit system. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.060 - Permit application procedures. 
(a)  Permit required. The licensee shall not install any attachments on any pole or within any city conduit system without first applying for and obtaining a permit pursuant to the applicable requirements of this chapter. Unless otherwise notified, pre-existing authorized attachment(s) of the licensee shall be grandfathered with respect to permitting, but shall be subject to the attachment fees. The licensee shall provide the city with a list of all such pre-existing attachments within six months of the effective date of this chapter. 
(b)  Permits for overlashing. Permits are required for any overlashing allowed under this chapter and the licensee, licensee's affiliate or other third party, as applicable, shall pay any necessary make-ready work costs to accommodate such overlashing. 
(c)  Professional certification. As part of the permit application process and at the licensee's sole expense, a qualified and experienced professional engineer or an employee or contractor of the licensee who has been approved by the city, must participate in the pre-construction survey, conduct the post-construction inspection and certify that the licensee's communications facilities can be and were installed on the identified poles or within specified portions of the conduit system in compliance with the standards of this chapter and in accordance with the permit. The city, at its discretion, may waive the requirements of this subsection with respect to service drops. 
(d)  Application for permit. A complete application for permit for pole attachment shall consist of: (i) the application for permit form, in a form approved by the director; (ii) the certified pre-construction survey; (iii) detailed plans for the proposed attachments; and (iv) an application fee as determined by city council. 
(e)  Issuance. The city will issue a permit(s) to the licensee only when the city determines, in its sole judgment, exercised reasonably, that: 
(1)  It has sufficient capacity to accommodate the requested attachment(s); 
(2)  The licensee meets all requirements set forth in this agreement; and 
(3)  Such permit(s) comply with all applicable standards. 
(f)  Permit as authorization to attach. After receipt of payment for any necessary make-ready work, the city will sign and return the permit application, which shall serve as authorization for the licensee to make its attachment(s). 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.070 - Make-ready work. 
(a)  Estimate for make-ready work. In the event the city determines that it can accommodate the licensee's request for attachment(s), including overlashing of an existing attachment, it will, upon request, advise licensee of any estimated make-ready work charges necessary to accommodate the attachment. 
(b)  Payment of make-ready work. Upon completion of the make-ready work, the city shall invoice the licensee for the city's actual cost of such make-ready work. Alternatively, the city, at its discretion, may require payment in advance for make-ready work based upon the estimated cost of such work. In such case, upon completion the licensee shall pay the city's actual cost of make-ready work. 
(c)  Who may perform make-ready work. Make-ready work shall be performed only by the city and/or a contractor authorized by the city to perform such work. 
(d)  Scheduling of make-ready work. In the event the licensee requests that the make-ready work be performed on a priority basis or outside of the city's normal work hours, the licensee will be responsible for any resulting increased costs. Nothing herein shall be construed to require performance of the licensee's work before other scheduled work or city service restoration. 
(e)  Licensee's installation/removal/maintenance work. All of the licensee's installation, removal and maintenance work shall be performed at the licensee's sole cost and expense, in a good and workmanlike manner, in compliance with all applicable regulations, and must not adversely affect the structural integrity of the city's poles, conduit system or other facilities or other attaching entity's facilities or attached equipment. All such work is subject to the insurance requirements of this chapter. Licensee shall assure that any person installing, maintaining, or removing its communications facilities is fully qualified and familiar with all applicable standards, duties, and the city's minimum design specifications. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.080 - Fees and charges. 
(a)  Pole attachment fees. The city shall invoice the licensee for the per-pole attachment fee prior to June 30 of each year. The invoice shall set forth the total number of the city's poles on which the licensee was issued and/or holds a permit(s) for attachments during such annual rental period, including any previously authorized and valid permits. The licensee shall pay the city the invoiced attachment fee for each attachment to the city's poles prior to July 31 of each year. The annual rental fee for each pole attachment shall be established by resolution of the city council. The licensee will provide a full accounting of its pole attachments upon request by the city. 
(b)  Determination of charges. Wherever this chapter requires the licensee to pay for work done or contracted by the city, the charge for such work shall include all reasonable material, labor, engineering and administrative costs and applicable overhead costs. 
(c)  Interest. If the city does not receive payment for any fee or other amount owed within 30 calendar days after it becomes due, the licensee shall pay interest to the city at the rate of 12 percent per month on the amount due. 
(d)  Default for nonpayment. Nonpayment of any amount due under this chapter beyond 90 days shall constitute a material default of the licensee's obligations under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.090 - Indemnification and hold harmless. 
    The licensee shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officers, officials, employees and volunteers from any and all claims, injuries, damages, losses or suits, including attorney fees, arising or issuing out of the joint use of city poles under this chapter, except as may be caused by the negligence or willful conduct on the part of the City of Cheney. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.100 - Insurance required. 
(a)  Any licensee receiving a permit under the terms of this chapter, the fair market value of which is $3,500.00 or less, shall provide to the city satisfactory proof of the existence of a comprehensive liability insurance policy, in an amount and form determined by the director or city attorney, but in no event providing coverage of less than $50,000.00 for personal injury to any one person, $100,000.00 for injury to more than one person arising out of the same incident, and $20,000.00 for property damage, against claims arising pursuant to permits issued pursuant to this chapter. The city shall further be provided with an endorsement to such policy, naming the city as an additional insured. 
(b)  Any permittee receiving a permit under the terms of this chapter, the fair market value of which is over $3,500.00, shall provide to the city satisfactory proof of the existence of a comprehensive liability insurance policy, in an amount and form determined by the director or city attorney, but in no event providing coverage of less than $200,000.00 for personal injury to any one person, $500,000.00 for injury to more than one person arising out of the same incident, and $100,000.00 for property damage, against claims arising pursuant to permits issued pursuant to this chapter. The city shall further be provided with an endorsement to such policy, naming the city as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.110 - Removal on expiration or termination. 
    At the expiration or other termination of individual permit(s), licensee shall remove its communications facilities from the affected poles or portions of conduit system at its own expense. If licensee fails to remove such facilities within 60 calendar days of expiration or termination or some greater period as allowed by the city, the city shall have the right to have such facilities removed at licensee's expense. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.120 - Termination of permit. 
    The city shall have the right to terminate any permit issued, whenever the licensee is in default of any term or condition of this chapter, including but not limited to the following circumstances: 
(a)  Construction, operation or maintenance of the licensee's communications facilities in violation of law or in aid of any unlawful act or undertaking; 
(b)  Construction, operation or maintenance of the licensee's communications facilities after any authorization required of the licensee has lawfully been denied or revoked by any governmental or private authority or violation of any other agreement with the city; or 
(c)  Construction, operation or maintenance of the licensee's communications facilities without the insurance coverage required under this chapter. 
In the event of termination of any of licensee's rights, privileges or authorizations, the city may seek removal of licensee's communications facilities, provided that licensee shall be liable for and pay all fees and charges pursuant to terms of this chapter to the city until licensee's communications facilities are actually removed. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.130 - Inspection. 
(a)  The city may conduct an inventory and inspection of attachments at any time. Licensee shall correct all attachments that are not found to be in compliance with applicable standards within 30 calendar days of notification. 
(b)  No liability. Inspections performed under this section, or the failure to do so, shall not operate to impose upon the city any liability of any kind whatsoever or relieve licensee of any responsibility, obligations or liability whether assumed under this chapter or otherwise existing. 
(c)  Attachment records. Notwithstanding the above inspection process, licensee is obligated to furnish the city on an annual basis an up-to-date map depicting the locations of its attachments in an electronic format specified by the city. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.140 - Unauthorized occupancy. 
(a)  Penalty fee. If any of the licensee's attachments are found occupying any pole or segment of the conduit system for which no permit has been issued, the city, without prejudice to its other rights or remedies under this chapter, may assess an unauthorized access penalty fee as determined by resolution of the city council. In the event the licensee fails to pay such fee within 30 calendar days of receiving notification, the city has the right to remove such communications facilities at the licensee's expense. 
(b)  No ratification of unlicensed use. No act or failure to act by the city with regard to any unlicensed use shall be deemed as ratification of the unlicensed use and if any permit should be subsequently issued, such permit shall not operate retroactively or constitute a waiver by the city of any of its rights or privileges under this chapter or otherwise; provided, however, that the licensee shall be subject to all liabilities, obligations and responsibilities of this chapter in regards to the unauthorized use from its inception. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.150 - City's reserved rights. 
(a)  The city, as pole owner, may deny access if the attachment project will result in adverse safety or reliability or generally accepted engineering standards not being met, or where the city retains future use of the structure. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to compel the city to maintain any of its poles for a period longer than is necessary for its own service requirements. 
(b)  No provision of this chapter shall be construed to require the city to relocate its attachments or modify and/or replace its poles for the benefit of the licensees, provided, however, any denial by the city for modification of the pole is based on nondiscriminatory standards of general applicability. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.160 - Assignment. 
    Permits shall not be assigned or transferred without the prior written consent of the city, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. The use of licensee's communications facilities by third parties (including but not limited to leases of dark fiber) that involves no additional attachment or overlashing is not subject to this section. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.10.170 - No interest in property. 
    No use, however lengthy, of any city facilities, and no payment of any fees or charges required under this chapter, shall create or vest in the licensee any easement or other ownership or property right of any nature in any portion of such facilities. Neither this chapter, nor any permit granted under this chapter, shall constitute an assignment of any of the city's rights to city facilities. Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, the licensee shall, at all times, be and remain a licensee only. 
(Ord. No. T-64, § 1(part), 2004) 
CHAPTER 14.20 - NET METERING 

14.20.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of net metering of electricity is to: 
(a)  Encourage private investment in renewable energy resources; 
(b)  Stimulate the economic growth of the community; and 
(c)  Enhance the continued diversification of the energy resources of the community. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.20.020 - Definitions. 
    The definitions in this section apply throughout the chapter unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Customer-generator means a user of a net metering system. 
    Net metering means measuring the difference between the electricity supplied by an electric utility and the electricity generated by a customer-generator that is fed back to the electric utility over the applicable billing period. 
    Net metering system means a fuel cell, a facility that produces electricity and used and useful thermal energy from a common fuel source, or a facility for the production of electrical energy that generates renewable energy, and that: 
(1)  Uses as its fuel either solar, wind or hydropower; 
(2)  Has a generating capacity of not more than 100 kilowatts; 
(3)  Is located on the customer-generator's premises; 
(4)  Operates in parallel with light department's transmission and distribution facilities; and 
(5)  Is intended primarily to offset part or all of the customer-generator's requirements for electricity. 
    Meter aggregation means the administrative combination of readings from and billing for all meters, regardless of the rate class, on premises owned or leased by a customer-generator located within the service territory of a single electric utility. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. V-88, § 1, 3-13-2012) 
14.20.030 - Net metering required. 
    The city shall offer to make net metering available to eligible customer-generators on a first come, first served basis until the cumulative generating capacity of net metering systems equals 135 kilowatts, which represents one- half of one percent of the light department's peak demand during 1996. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. V-88, § 2, 3-13-2012) 
14.20.040 - Metering. 
    The city shall allow net metering systems to be interconnected using a standard kilowatt-hour meter capable of registering the flow of electricity in two directions. The city council may adopt additional metering requirements after it determines, after appropriate notice and opportunity to comment: 
(1)  That the use of additional metering equipment to monitor the flow of electricity in each direction is necessary and appropriate for the interconnection of net metering systems, after taking into account the benefits and costs of purchasing and installing additional metering equipment; and 
(2)  How the cost of purchasing and installing an additional meter is to be allocated between the customer-generator and the utility. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.20.050 - Fees. 
    The city shall charge the customer-generator a minimum monthly fee that is the same as the other customers of the electric utility in the same rate class, but shall not charge the customer-generator any additional standby, capacity, interconnection or other fee unless the city council determines after appropriate notice and opportunity for comment that: 
(1)  The light department will incur direct costs associated with interconnecting or administering net metering systems that exceed any offsetting benefits associated with these systems; and 
(2)  Public policy is best served by imposing these costs on the customer-generator rather than allocating these costs among the utility's entire customer base. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004) 
14.20.060 - Net energy measurement. 
    The net energy measurement shall be calculated in the following manner: 
(1)  The light department shall measure the net electricity produced or consumed during the billing period, in accordance with normal metering practices. 
(2)  If the electricity supplied by the light department exceeds the electricity generated by the customer-generator and fed back to the light department during the billing period, the customer-generator shall be billed for the net electricity supplied by the electric utility, in accordance with normal metering practices. 
(3)  If electricity generated by the customer-generator exceeds the electricity supplied by the light department, the customer-generator: 
(A)  Shall be billed for the appropriate customer charges for that billing period, in accordance with sections 14.20.030 through 14.20.050 of this chapter; and 
(B)  Shall be credited for the excess kilowatt-hours generated during the billing period, with this kilowatt-hour credit appearing on the bill for the following billing period. 
(4)  If a customer-generator requests, an electric utility shall provide meter aggregation. 
(A)  For customer-generators participating in meter aggregation, kilowatt-hours credits earned by a net metering system during the billing period first shall be used to offset electricity supplied by the electric utility. 
(B)  Not more than a total of one hundred kilowatts shall be aggregated among all customer-generators participating in a generating facility under this subsection. 
(C)  Excess kilowatt-hours credits earned by the net metering system, during the same billing period, shall be credited equally by the electric utility to remaining meters located on all premises of a customer-generator at the designated rate of each meter. 
(D)  Meters so aggregated shall not change rate classes due to meter aggregation under this section. 
(5)  At the beginning of each calendar year, any remaining unused kilowatt-hour credit accumulated during the previous year shall be granted to the light department, without any compensation to the customer-generator. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004; Ord. No. V-88, § 3, 3-13-2012) 
14.20.070 - Interconnection requirements. 
(a)  The customer-generator is responsible for the safety and power quality associated with the customer-generator's generating equipment. A net metering system used by a customer-generator shall include, at the customer-generator's own expense, all equipment necessary to meet applicable safety, power quality and interconnection requirements established by the National Electrical Code, National Electrical Safety Code, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and Underwriters Laboratories. 
(b)  The city council, after appropriate notice and opportunity for comment, may adopt by regulation additional safety, power quality and interconnection requirements for customer-generators that the city council determines are necessary to protect public safety and system reliability. 
(c)  The customer-generator shall be required to install automatic and manual protective devices to isolate the system from the city's system. This equipment must meet the interrupting rating determined by the city. 
(d)  The customer-generator shall submit to the city for review and approval, an application containing a scaled drawing of the applicant's generation facilities and the nearest utility pole by address and pole number, the generator size and type, the fuel type, a one line wiring drawing showing specific types of equipment, wire sizes and wire type and a discussion of the protection scheme. The applicant shall supply equipment electrical ratings including interrupting ratings provided by the equipment manufacturer. All information shall be submitted in triplicate. 
(Ord. No. S-74, § 1(part), 2004)
