(b)  Connections or installations with the public water system are permitted only upon approval by the director and payment of required fees and charges. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0404 - Application information. 
    The applicant shall provide: 
(a)  The purposes for which the water will be used; 
(b)  The number of service pipes desired; 
(c)  The number of structures or buildings and parcels to be supplied by the service; 
(d)  The number of flats or apartments in the building; 
(e)  The location where the city main is to be tapped, and the size of the tap to be made; and 
(f)  The location of the property by lot, block, addition and street number. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0406 - Applicant to furnish building permit. 
    Any person desiring to have premises connected with the public water system shall present a copy of the building permit or furnish such comparable information as required by the director. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0408 - Building construction or repair-Report from building official. 
    The director may request the building official to report the beginning of construction or repairs of all buildings in the city, including a copy of the building permit issued, containing a general description of the building to be erected or repaired, the name of the owner and contractor thereof, the official house number and street name, the lot, block and addition. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0410 - Changes in service. 
    Service connections may be removed or changed through application approved by the director upon reasonable conditions, and upon payment of applicable fees and charges. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0412 - Specific municipal disclaimer-Damage prevention devices. 
(a)  The city specifically disclaims all liability for damage to property or injury to persons accruing from: (a) temporary or permanent shut-off of water for necessary repairs, (b) breakage of any pipe or fixture of the public water supply system, (c) changes in pressure, or (d) other good cause. This disclaimer is a condition of accepting service from the city, except as otherwise required by the laws of this state. 
(b)  Water consumers who have any machinery, material, process or plant which require a constant supply of water shall install upon their premises water storage facilities to prevent damage caused by an interruption of the supply of water. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0414 - Interruption or restriction of service. 
(a)  Service may be interrupted or terminated, restricted, rationed or curtailed, with or without notice, as the director shall determine, for all necessary repairs, construction or alterations and in case of emergency, threat or danger to the public health or safety. 
(b)  In case of severe dry weather, fire or other environmental condition, the director shall be authorized to restrict, ration or curtail the public use of water as necessary to protect the public health and safety. 
(c)  Service to any premises may be suspended for nonpayment of accounts. Suspension of water service shall not relieve responsibility for complying with the provisions of this chapter. Such suspension shall render the premises where such service is suspended subject to condemnation for sanitary reasons and/or exercise of municipal power to abate a public nuisance at the risk and expense of the owner of the premises and/or other responsible persons. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0416 - Refusal of service-No rights created. 
(a)  Water service may be refused or reconnection denied where the provisions of this chapter, policies, standards or order of the director are violated. This section includes failure to obtain all inspections, perform proper installations due to localized contamination or health hazards, or failure to pay fees and charges. 
(b)  This chapter shall not create: (a) a duty to require construction of public works mains or supply facilities; (b) the right to connect to the public water system; or (c) otherwise receive water service from the city on the part of any person. The city reserves all rights to deny, limit or curtail service consistent with federal and state laws. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0418 - Abatement of public nuisance. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, and in addition thereto, the maintenance of any condition creating or tending to create a risk to the public health and safety, specifically including the public water system, shall constitute a public nuisance and, in the discretion of the director, or other authorized official, shall be subject to immediate abatement by the city at the premises owner's and/or responsible person's expense and liability. 
(b)  Costs to abate any nuisance as above defined may be charged as utility service furnished to the premises wherein the condition arose or exists. 
(c)  This section shall not limit the premises owner's or other party's rights to seek recovery against other responsible persons. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0420 - Stealing water. 
    No person may take water or permit water to be taken from the water supply of the city through any unauthorized means, or permit the use of said water without making application and payment for the service. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0422 - Tampering. 
    No person may: 
(a)  Open or shut any street valve or in any way tamper with or damage any meter, hydrant, valve or service pipe connecting any premises or building with the public water system; or 
(b)  Use or tamper with any fire hydrant or line unless such person is authorized by the city to perform such activities. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0424 - Unauthorized keys. 
    No unauthorized person may knowingly possess any curb stop key, valve key or hydrant wrench to the public water system, and no person may without authority make, construct, buy, sell or in any way dispose of to any person, any curb stop key, valve key or hydrant wrench to the public water system. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0426 - Contamination. 
    No person may contaminate, pollute or endanger in any way, directly or indirectly, the public water system of the city. A contaminant is any substance introduced without specific authorization of the city. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0428 - Duty to report contamination. 
(a)  Every person, upon knowledge, is required to report immediately to the director any contamination, pollution, or introduction of any unauthorized substance into the public water system of the city. 
(b)  This duty applies to accidental, careless, or intentional incidents regardless of the means of introduction or the person or persons responsible. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0430 - Miscellaneous prohibitions. 
    Every person who, with intent to injure or defraud, commits a misdemeanor when that person: 
(a)  Breaks, moves, disturbs, or defaces the seal of any water meter or any other seal applied to any other device; 
(b)  Obstructs, alters, injures, or prevents the operation of any meter or other instrument used to measure or register the quantity of water supplied to the consumer; 
(c)  Bypassing meter. 
(1)  Makes or permits any connection by means of a pipe, or otherwise, with any main or pipe used for the delivery of water in such manner as to take or permit the taking of water from said main or pipe without its passage through the meter or other instrument provided for registering the amount or quantity consumed; or 
(2)  Uses any water so obtained; 
(d)  Makes any connection or reconnection with such main or pipe, or turns on or off, or in any manner interferes with any valve, curb stop or other apparatus connected therewith; 
(e)  Prevents by the erection of any device, construction, or by any other means, free access to any meter or other instrument for registering or measuring the amount of water consumed; or 
(f)  Interferes with, obstructs, or prevents, by any means, the reading or inspection of such meter or instrument, by any of the officers or authorized employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0432 - Temporary hookup. 
    The director may allow temporary connections to the public water system upon reasonable conditions and payment of applicable fees and charges. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.050 - Water meters-Specification. 
    All water use shall be measured by a meter unless otherwise authorized by the director. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0502 - Meter supply. 
(a)  Water meters shall be approved and supplied by the water division at the expense of the customer. 
(b)  Costs of the water meter, installation, testing and inspection shall be paid by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0504 - Authority over meters and valves. 
(a)  All meters, valves or other such devices from the meter to the public water system shall remain subject to the strict regulation of the water division and no person may tamper with, repair or replace any such items. 
(b)  Meters shall be maintained, repaired and replaced by the water division. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0506 - Inspection/reading of meters. 
    Water meters shall at all times be accessible to water division personnel. Where it is necessary for the property owner or lessee to place the meter under lock and key, a key shall be furnished to the water division. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0508 - Testing meters-Expense. 
(a)  To test the accuracy of a water meter, it may be removed at the customer's request by the water division. The testing shall be performed using generally acceptable criteria and equipment with a report made available to the customer. 
(b)  The customer may be present to observe the testing. 
(c)  If the test discloses the meter varies by more than three percent, the water division will bear the entire expense of the test. Where no such error is found, the person who has requested the test shall pay a fee as provided in the current fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0510 - Construction specifications. 
(a)  Every customer shall have a separate service pipe with a ball valve placed inside the foundation wall to prevent damage from frost, and so situated that the water can be conveniently shut off and drained from the pipes. 
(b)  All water pipes in buildings shall be so arranged as to drain toward the stop and waste cock or drain cocks placed for that purpose. 
(c)  All water pipe materials shall be consistent with the City Engineering Design Standards. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.060 - New connections-Regulations-Charges. 
    Public water service is subject to the following. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0602 - Separate service. 
(a)  Each building shall have a separate service connection and separate meter unless otherwise specifically authorized by the director. 
(1)  Service connections to the public water system are provided in the public right-of-way unless otherwise approved. 
(b)  Where necessary to provide public water service, the director may require the property owner(s) to execute and record at their expense an easement on a form supplied by the director, allowing perpetual use and access by benefited properties. 
(1)  Said easement shall prohibit construction over or interference with the easement area and shall not be subject to revocation without the written approval of the director. 
(2)  The city shall have no repair or maintenance obligations as to any utility or improvements in the easement. 
(c)  A separate connection and meter may be required if there is a change in use to the premises/building which shall be made at the property owner's sole expense. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0604 - Unauthorized extensions unlawful. 
    Extensions of city utilities services from any building or premises to other buildings or premises without submitting written application on forms provided by the director, payment of required fees, and the director's approval, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0606 - Service pipes, valves, and equipment. 
(a)  Cost of all service pipes from the city mains to the premises, including a service valves, shall be paid by the applicant. The service line from the property line to the premises shall be placed in a trench, subject to inspection and approval of the water division. The water division shall connect the service line to the public water system. 
(b)  The property owner(s) shall install and maintain, at their own expense, all service lines to the premises, subject to inspection and approval of the water division. 
(c)  Multiple service lines are not permitted without approval from the director. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0608 - Standpipe and sprinkler connections. 
(a)  Connections for standpipe and sprinkler service for fire protection are subject to the same requirements as other service connections unless otherwise determined by the director. 
(b)  In all cases, the applicant shall provide such valves, meters or other devices at the applicant's sole cost and liability. 
(c)  Such connections may be separate from regular service taps, with installation received by the water division and/or building inspector. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0610 - Charge for standpipe or sprinkler. 
    Costs for maintaining a supply of water under pressure related to a standpipe or sprinkler service may be assessed at the rates provided in the fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.070 - Water connections-When required. 
    The owner of each lot or parcel of real property within the city, not already connected to the public water system, which lot or parcel of property contains any building or structure that requires water, shall connect to the public water system, at the owner's expense; such installation and connection shall occur whenever there is a public water line within 200 feet of such lot or parcel and such connection accomplished within 30 days after notice from the city. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0702 - Failure to connect when required-Penalty. 
    In the event connection is not made to the public water system within the 30 days as set out in section 16.04.070 above, then a penalty shall be assessed against such unconnected property for each month the property remains unconnected to the public water system, and the penalty, for each month, shall be equal to the charge for the applicable monthly water service, as set out in city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0704 - Assessing penalty for failure to connect against property. 
    In the event the building water system connection is not made to the public water system within two years after the time herein provided for, the director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to cause the same to be made and to file a statement of the costs thereof with the city clerk and thereupon a warrant shall be issued under the direction of the city council against the water fund for the payment of such costs. The amount, together with a penalty of ten percent per year thereof plus interest at the rate of ten percent per year upon the total amount of the cost and penalty, shall be assessed against the property, and shall become a lien thereon, and may be foreclosed as a mortgage in an action of law. Willful failure to connect by the owner of the property as hereby required shall be a misdemeanor. The total amount, when collected, shall be paid into the water fund. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0706 - Private water system-Abandonment-Connection with city system. 
    Whenever the public water system becomes available to a lot or parcel served by a private water well, or private water system as provided for in section 16.04.070, a direct connection shall be made to the public water system in compliance with this chapter, and any wells and/or other private water sources shall be abandoned in accordance with state and local requirements. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0708 - Establishment of water division reserve fund. 
    The treasurer of the city shall set aside out of the revenue of the water utility of the city an amount determined annually into a reserve account for capacity improvements. The water division reserve account shall be annually maintained, except for withdrawals recommended by the director and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.080 - Schedule of water charges. 
    The following charges for public water shall be contained within the city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0802 - Residential users. 
(a)  Minimum charge. The monthly minimum charge includes the first 500 cubic feet of water or less as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(b)  Excess water charges on residential water delivered in excess of 500 cubic feet per month shall be at the current water utility rates and fees for residential excess of water. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0804 - Multiple-unit users. 
(a)  Multiple-unit customers are defined as apartments, duplexes, cabins, trailers and other units in which space is made available for rent. Units with sleeping rooms only are expressly excluded and shall be charged as are residential users. 
(b)  Excess charges on water for multiple-unit users delivered in excess of 500 cubic feet per month shall be at the current water utility rates and fees for multiple-unit users excess water. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0806 - Commercial, school and industrial users. 
    All users not falling within residential or multiple-unit categories, unless excepted, shall be charged as follows: 
(a)  Minimum charge. The minimum monthly charge includes the first 500 cubic feet of water or less as established in the current water utility rates and fees: 
(b)  Excess water delivered charge for commercial, school, and industrial users in excess of 500 cubic feet per month will pay an excess water delivery rate as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0808 - Fire hydrant or fire protection system standby charge. 
    Fire protection system connections are assessed a monthly rate as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0810 - Tank water. 
    Tank water shall be sold at in volumes per hundred cubic feet as established in the current water utility rates and fees only after the issuance of an access permit for such water by the director of public works. City residents and/or current system users that have no outstanding city water bills, shall be issued a no-fee access permit upon request for tank water. All others requesting tank water shall be charged an annual access permit fee as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0812 - Temporary connection fee. 
    Upon application to the water department by a temporary user, the director of public works shall install a temporary connection. Water users through temporary connections shall be charged at the minimum rate per month as established in the current water utility rates and fees for the size meter deemed by the director of public works as necessary to efficiently meter water delivered to the customer or, at the option of the director of public works, a meter may be installed, and the charge for water based on the applicable rates. A temporary connection charge as established in the current water utility rates and fees shall be included with the application to cover the cost of installing and removing the meter. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0814 - Service charges for rereading water meters. 
    Whenever a customer requests a meter reading and the requested reading confirms the meter is functioning correctly, the water user shall pay a service charge for each such reading as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0816 - Charges outside city limits. 
(a)  The charges for water delivered outside the city limits shall be 150 percent of the applicable rate for water delivered within the city. 
(b)  New service connect charges for service connections outside the city shall be at 150 percent of the applicable new service connect charges within the city. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0818 - Schedule of municipal parks department irrigation charges. 
    The following charges for public water delivered to municipal parks within the city limits shall be contained within the city council resolution: 
(a)  The monthly minimum charge includes the first 500 feet of water or less as established in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(b)  Excess water delivered charge for municipal parks department in excess of 500 cubic feet per month will pay an excess water delivery rate as established in the current water utility rates and fees up to a maximum overage monthly amount per water meter size as follows: 
Meter Size Maximum Overage Monthly Amount 1 inch or less 5,000 cubic feet 1 to 11/2 inch 30,000 cubic feet 2 inch 170,000 cubic feet 3 inch 65,000 cubic feet  
(c)  Charges on water delivered in excess of the maximum overage monthly amount will pay an excess water delivery charge as established in the current water utility rates and fees over the maximum overage monthly amount as listed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0820 - Schedule of municipal facilities charges for general government operations. 
    The following charges for water delivered to general government facilities within the city limits shall be effective from January 1, 2002. 
(a)  The monthly minimum charge includes the first 500 cubic feet of water or less as established in the current water rates and fees. 
Excess water delivered charge for municipal facilities for general government operations in excess of 500 cubic feet per month will pay an excess water delivery charge as established in the current water utility rates and fees up to a maximum overage monthly amount per water meter size as follows: 
Meter Size Maximum Overage Monthly Amount 1 inch or less 5,000 cubic feet 11/2 inch 30,000 cubic feet 2 inch 170,000 cubic feet 3 inch 65,000 cubic feet  
(b)  Charges on water delivered in excess of the maximum overage monthly amount will pay an excess water delivery charge as established in the current water utility rates and fees over the maximum overage monthly amount as listed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.090 - Billing-Payment date. 
(a)  Each meter shall be read monthly and on or about the same day of each month, as nearly as may be practicable. The city shall mail each customer a statement each month setting forth the charges and other amounts due. All charges shall be due and payable 15 days after the date of mailing of such statement and shall become delinquent the next following business day after the fifteenth day. 
(b)  Delinquent charges shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, with a minimum service charge as provided in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(c)  When service shall have been shut off for failure to pay, the reconnection charges shall be paid as provided in the current water utility rates and fees. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0902 - Payment-Liens. 
(a)  All charges for services rendered, including utility service, costs, and labor and materials, are payable to the city treasurer. 
(b)  All charges for water connections, service and usage and all service charges provided in this chapter, or as may hereafter be amended, together with penalties and interest thereon, shall be a lien upon the property to which such water service is rendered, superior to all other liens and encumbrances whatsoever, except for general taxes and local special assessments. Enforcement of such lien or liens shall be in the manner provided by law. If such charges are not paid, upon delinquency the amount thereof shall become a lien against the premises receiving water service as provided in RCW 35.21.290 and RCW 35.21.300 and any other applicable laws. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other lawful remedy, the city may, after delinquency, shut off the water service. Service shall not be restored until the delinquent bill, interest thereon, and the reconnection fee have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0904 - Appointment of agent for multiple-dwelling units. 
(a)  For multiple dwelling units on a parcel, the director may require appointment of an agent who shall make payment for city water service. 
(b)  Failure of an agent to discharge any duty imposed by this section shall not relieve any property owner or any other person of any legal obligation imposed herein and the city reserves all rights and remedies at contract and law. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.0906 - Time of commencement. 
    Fees and charges commence the day the premises are connected to the public water system and water is delivered. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.100 - Ownership of public mains, lines, and facilities. 
    All public water mains, lines and facilities shall remain the property of the city regardless of location. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1002 - Service pipes, connections, and apparatus within private property. 
(a)  Service pipe and other apparatus within private property must be kept in good repair and protected from damage at the expense of the owner to include repair and replacement as necessary. 
(b)  Upon a failure to promptly repair any service or fixture, or make any changes or alterations required in this chapter, the director shall have authority, when deemed necessary, to go on the premises and make or cause to be made such changes, alterations or repairs, and charge the same against the premises and the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1004 - Securing meters and pipes against damage, strain or settling. 
(a)  Whenever a meter is to be or has been installed within that portion of the street lying between the curbline and the property line and in which an areaway exists, the director shall cause the erection of such bases, supports or barriers as will reasonably secure the meter and pipes against any damage. 
(b)  The cost of the erection of such bases, supports or barriers shall be charged against the property for which the meter was installed and to the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1006 - Driveways-Removal or protection of service pipes. 
(a)  Whenever a driveway or crossing, to be used for vehicular traffic, is constructed within that portion of a city street lying between the curb line and the property line, the director shall cause the removal and relocation of any water service connection or any part thereof which may be within the lines of such driveway or crossing, provided, however, that instead of such removal of water service connection the director may, if he deems it advisable, cause the construction and placing of an iron or masonry box or chamber of sufficient strength to withstand the stress of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  The cost of removal, relocation or maintenance of water service connections as provided in this section shall be charged against the property for which the driveway or crossing was constructed and to the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1008 - Responsibility for water supply within private property. 
(a)  The city assumes no responsibility for cost, expense, damage, repair or maintenance whatsoever for any private water pipes, mains, devices, fixtures or appurtenances not located upon public property or the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1010 - Leaking fixtures-Waste of water. 
    No water recipient or customer may permit unnecessary waste or use of water. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1012 - Repairs on private property. 
(a)  Unless specifically authorized by the director, all repairs to any portion of a facility or the water supply system located on private property are the responsibility of the property owner and in the event the director orders such repairs to be performed by city crews or others for the protection of the system and/or public health and safety, such repairs shall be paid for by the property owner as a condition of continued service. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to create any obligation on the part of the city to make repairs. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.110 - No protest agreement required-Future annexation. 
    Applicants for public water service to serve a lot or parcel outside the city limits shall be required to execute a "no protest" agreement with the city agreeing to future annexation of that lot or parcel into the city as a condition of water service. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1102 - Outside the city water service. 
(a)  City water utility service is initially intended to provide for the needs of the residents of the City of Cheney. The city reserves the right to decline to serve any area outside the city, or to condition such service upon entry into a written contract, upon such additional terms and conditions as may be determined at the time service is requested or thereafter, as municipal needs may require, considering additional expenses imposed or burdens created by outside the city service. 
(b)  Pursuant to authority granted by RCW 35.92.020, the director is authorized to enter into agreements for and on behalf of the city with owners of property beyond the city limits permitting connection of such property to the city's water utility service upon the terms and conditions and subject to the payments prescribed in this article when such connection will not impair the city's water system, including domestic and fire flow pressure, supply resources and municipal water rights, to include service to current or future city customers. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.120 - New mains-Specifications. 
    New mains shall be constructed as per the current City of Cheney Design Engineering Standards as amended. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.130 - Right of entry. 
    The director reserves the right to enter at any reasonable time any premises where city water is used for the purpose of making an examination of the premises, or a reading or test of the meter, or for any other reasonable purpose related to utility service, to include the right to remove the meter from the premises for examination and test when necessary in which the provisions of this chapter are being complied with. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.140 - Authority to operate fire hydrant. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, except when duly authorized by the director, and except employees of the city utilities and fire department, to open, operate, close, turn on, turn off, interfere with, attach any pipe or hose to or connect anything with any fire hydrant, stop valve or stopcock belonging to the city. 
(b)  Any person, other than employees of the city utilities and fire department, requiring the use of any hydrant, stopcock or valve belonging to the city must make written application for the same in advance to the director. The director shall then send a hydrant inspector to open such hydrant, stopcock or valve, and the time of such inspector shall be charged to the person making application for the use of such hydrant, stopcock or valve. 
(c)  Should it be necessary for the inspector to remain at the hydrant, stopcock or valve until the person using the same has secured the necessary supply of water, the full time consumed by the inspector shall be charged to the person securing such service. The director may require a deposit in advance as a condition for supply of such water. 
(d)  The director may also permit qualified plumbers, licensed and bonded in accordance with state laws, to open and shut any hydrant, stopcock or valve belonging to the city in order to make the necessary repairs or to test their work, and in every such case such persons shall leave the stop cock as they found it. They shall be responsible for any damage, losses or liabilities of the city or third parties arising from their acts, errors or omissions. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1402 - Obstructing fire hydrants. 
    No person may: 
(a)  Obstruct the access to any fire hydrant by placing around, thereon, or within 20 feet thereof, any stone, brick, lumber, dirt, rubbish or other material; 
(b)  Open or operate any fire hydrant; 
(c)  Draw or attempt to draw water therefrom; 
(d)  Willfully or carelessly injure the same; 
(e)  Fill up or cover over any valve box; 
(f)  In any manner tamper with or injure the same. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.1404 - Valves and outlets sealed-Fire inspections. 
(a)  Every valve or outlet must be sealed. Seals may be broken only in case of fire, and in such case prompt notification must be made to the water department and/or fire department, and the valve will be resealed. 
(b)  The premises upon which any such fire protection service is installed shall be open to the inspection of any authorized representative of the water department and/or fire department at all times, and the owner or tenant shall give such representative all reasonable facilities for making the inspection and any information he may require. The owner or tenant can test the apparatus at any time by notifying the water department and/or fire department that such a test is desired, and a time will be fixed for the test to be made. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.04.150 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter becomes liable to the City of Cheney for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
    Any person found to be guilty of violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or by imprisonment in the city jail for a term not exceeding 30 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. V-71, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
CHAPTER 16.08 - BACKFLOW PREVENTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Prior ordinance history: Ord. No. I-59 and Ord. No. N-26. 

16.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of the cross-connection control program, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  "Approved backflow prevention assembly" or "backflow assembly" or "assembly" shall mean an assembly to counteract backpressures or prevent backsiphonage. This assembly must appear on the list of approved assemblies issued by the Washington State Department of Health. The assembly must be purchased and installed as a complete unit including two shut-off valves and test cocks. 
(2)  "Backflow" shall mean the undesirable reversal of flow of water, other liquids, mixtures, gases or substances from the intended direction of flow in potable water distribution piping caused by backsiphonage or backpressure conditions. 
(3)  "Backflow prevention device" is a device or assembly, approved by the director or health officer, designed and tested to counteract back pressure and back siphonage. 
(4)  "Containment" shall mean a method of backflow prevention requiring the installation of a backflow prevention assembly at the point the city water service line enters the customer's water system. This also means Premise Isolation. 
a.  "Contamination" shall mean a physical, chemical, biological or radiological substance that causes an impairment of the quality of the potable water and creates a potential public health hazard. "Contaminated water" is water with contamination. 
(5)  "Cross-connection" shall mean any physical arrangement whereby the public water supply of the City of Cheney is connected, directly or indirectly, or in the judgment of the director or health officer has a risk of becoming connected, to a source of contamination as a result of backflow. Sources of contamination might include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Public or private water supply system, 
b.  Tank or storage reservoir, 
c.  Sewer line, 
d.  Sewer drain, 
e.  Conduit, 
f.  Pool, or 
g.  Any plumbing or fixture whatsoever. 
(6)  "Cross-Connection Control Manual" or "manual" shall mean the latest edition of "Accepted Procedure and Practice in Cross-Connection Control" promulgated by the Pacific Northwest section of the American Waterworks Association. A copy of the manual is available for public inspection at the water department office. 
(7)  "Cross-connection control program" shall mean the City of Cheney's effort to prevent and control cross-connections, as required by WAC 246-290-490 and any related policies, standards or orders issued by the director. 
(8)  "Customer" shall mean any person or other entity occupy any premises that is authorized to connect to the city's public water service system. 
(9)  "Customer's water system" shall mean all sources of water supply, storage, treatment and distribution facilities, piping, plumbing and fixtures under the control of the customer. 
(10)  "Director" shall mean the director of public works or designee. 
(11)  "Health officer" shall mean an authorized representative of the Washington State Department of Health or county health employee. 
(12)  "In-premises isolation" shall mean a method of protecting the health of consumers served by the customer's plumbing system (i.e. located within the property lines of the customer's premises) by the installation of an approved air gap, backflow prevention assembly or device at the point of hazard. 
(13)  "Pollution" shall mean an impairment of the quality of the public potable water supply which does not create a hazard to public health, but which does adversely affect the aesthetic qualities of such potable water for domestic use. Also referred to as "low hazard" or "non-health hazard". 
(14)  "Service connection" or "service line" is the connection between the public water supply system and the customer's premises or customer-operated distribution system. 
(15)  "Standard Operating Procedures Manual" or "SOP" shall mean the City of Cheney's current Standard Operating Procedures Manual. 
(16)  "WAC" shall mean the most recent edition of the Washington Administrative Code 246-290. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 2, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 2, 6-14-2011) 
16.08.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the City of Cheney cross-connection control program is to establish a municipal cross-connection control program to protect the public water system, consistent with WAC 246 290-490. In implementing this program the director shall be guided by the Cross-Connection Control Manual and the city's Standard Operating Procedures Manual. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 3, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 3, 6-14-2011) 
16.08.030 - Cross-connections prohibited-Nuisance declared. 
(a)  No person or entity may install, maintain or permit a cross-connection in violation of the cross-connection control program. Consistent with the definition of cross-connection herein, this prohibition is specifically intended to include potential sources or risks of contamination through backflow to the public water system. All such cross-connections are prohibited and shall be immediately removed or protected against by the customer in accordance with this chapter. Upon reasonable written notice, the director in addition to all other remedies, including emergency termination of water service, may order the installation of a backflow prevention assembly. In the event the customer fails to install the backflow prevention assembly as ordered, the director may refuse to provide water service or cause the same to be installed and thereafter assess the cost on the customer's water bill. 
(b)  The installation or maintenance of an unprotected cross-connection condition is declared a public nuisance, subject to immediate abatement or removal by the city at the customer's sole cost and liability. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 4, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 4, 6-14-2011) 
16.08.040 - Director's authority. 
(a)  The director shall be allowed to access premises or any building to ensure compliance with this program. In addition, the director may require any customer or occupant of premises to provide any information, and testing or surveying relating to the enforcement of the city's cross-connection control program. Failure to cooperate with any such request, in addition to being a violation of this chapter, may result in denial or termination of water service. 
(b)  In addition to the specifications in WAC, Cross-Connection Control Manual, and the city's Standard Operating Procedures Manual, the director may adopt additional policies and standards or issue an order to implement the city's cross-connection control program. Such order may include fees or charges to customers and/or other responsible persons for surveys, tests, equipment or other items furnished in the course of implementing the city's cross-connection control program. Such regulations or orders may address: 
(1)  Minimum cross-connection control operating policies; 
(2)  Assembly installation practices, containment and in-premis requirements; and 
(3)  Assembly testing procedures and record-keeping requirements. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 5, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 5, 6-14-2011) 
16.08.050 - Surveys and testing-Customers to cooperate. 
(a)  Customers are required to cooperate fully with the city in implementing the cross-connection control program. Customers may be required to provide satisfactory evidence of cross-connection control to the water department and to allow surveys, testing or other examination, including surveys and testing of backflow prevention assemblies, all as deemed necessary to implement the city's cross-connection control program. 
(b)  The water department shall have access to all service connections, premises and buildings served by the city's public water system during regular business hours or, at any time that an emergency arises, to conduct surveys to ascertain the need to eliminate or control cross-connections. 
(c)  Compliance with the city's cross-connection control program requirements are additional terms and conditions under which the City of Cheney supplies water service to its customers. 
(d)  For all new and modifications to existing service connections, customer shall provide information to the water division, which will allow an evaluation of the customer's premises in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 6, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 6, 6-14-2011) 
16.08.060 - No duty-Ratification. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision, no duty on the part of the City of Cheney, its officers, agents or employees is created. Any duty nonetheless deemed to arise is declared to be a duty to the general public only and not to any particular person, group, class or entity. 
(b)  All actions taken by city departments or officials pursuant to the provisions of chapter 246-290 WAC and the Cross-Connection Control Manual are hereby ratified and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. T-08, § 7, 2002; Ord. No. V-73, § 7, 6-14-2011) 
Title 17 - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. 2 of Ord. No. X-35, adopted Jan. 22, 2019, changed the name of tit. 17 from "Gas" to "Property Maintenance." 

CHAPTER 17.06 - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

17.06.010 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Property Maintenance Code" of the city. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 2, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to supplement and amend the codes and standards adopted herein. In addition to this chapter, any other city ordinances which by nature apply to the maintenance and use of public or private properties shall be considered part these standards. Notwithstanding anything in this title or adopted codes to the contrary, this title and the adopted codes shall be administered for the benefit of the health, safety and welfare of the general public and shall not be construed to establish any duties to protect or benefit any particular person or class of persons. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 3, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.030 - Conflict. 
    Should there be a conflict between the provisions of this chapter any ordinance or of this municipal code, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail over such other provisions adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 4, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.040 - Authority-Enforcement officer. 
    The code enforcement officer of the city, established through section 2.58.010, shall be deemed the "code official" as defined in Section 202 of the International Property Maintenance Code. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 5, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.050 - Notice and order of correction. 
    The code enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue a notice and order of correction in accordance with CMC 1.28 to require compliance with any provision of the property maintenance code. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 6, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.060 - Adoption of amendments. 
    The following amendments to the adopted codes in CMC 17.06.020 are adopted and apply within the City of Cheney: 
(1)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 202 shall read as follows: 
PREMISES. A lot, plot or parcel of land, or easement, not located in a public way, and including any structures thereon. 
(2)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 302.4, for the portion required therein to have a height inserted by the jurisdiction, shall read as follows: 
10 inches measured from the ground 
(3)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 308.1.2 shall be added and shall read as follows: 
Machinery and equipment. Exterior property and premises shall not be used for the leaving or storing of any machinery or equipment used by contractors or builders or by others or which are outlawed by zoning ordinances of the city. 
(4)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 302.10 shall be added and shall read as follows: 
Trees. Trees shall be maintained to the standards of CMC 12.60.120. Hazard trees shall be removed in accordance with CMC 12.60.060. 
(5)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 308.1.1 shall be added and shall read as follows: 
Household Items. Exterior property and premises shall be free from the accumulation of bed mattresses, bed springs or other bedding, toilets, bathtubs, sinks, water heaters, clothes washers, clothes driers, ovens/ranges or other household appliances, and damaged or stored or discarded furniture and other household goods or items including indoor furniture. For purposes of this section, exterior property and premises shall include carports and non-enclosed porches and decks, in a residential zone or other zone within the city where such items are inconsistent with permitted uses authorized within the zone. 
(6)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 308.1.2 shall be added and shall read as follows: 
Motor vehicle components. Exterior property and premises shall not be used or maintained as junkyards, or dumping grounds, for the storing or leaving of any worn out, wrecked or abandoned vehicles or machinery of any kind, or of any of the parts, tires and wheels whether on or off rims. SMS Note: See RCW 46.55.240. 
(7)  The International Property Maintenance Code, section 301.1 shall read as follows: 
The provisions of this chapter shall govern the minimum conditions and the responsibilities of persons for maintenance of structures, equipment, exterior property, and their adjoining public way(s). 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 7, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.070 - Board of appeals. 
    IPMC section 111 is hereby deleted. Appeals of decisions of the code enforcement officer shall be in accordance with CMC chapter 9.06. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 8, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.080 - Fees. 
(a)  There may be charged against the owner and assessed against the property of a substandard, unfit, abandoned, or otherwise a nuisance building all costs and expenses incurred by the city in: 
(1)  Administration and enforcement of this chapter; 
(2)  Securing an unfit, substandard, or abandoned building, a hearing processing fee; and 
(3)  An annual property monitoring fee. 
(b)  The fees and costs described herein shall established by the city council through resolution. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 9, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.090 - Unlawful acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use, occupy or maintain any building, structure, or premises in the city, or cause the same to be done, contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 10, 1-22-2019) 
17.06.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or imprisonment in jail for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punished as such. 
(Ord. No. X-36, § 2, 1-22-2019) 
CHAPTER 17.08 - FORECLOSURE REGISTRATION PROGRAM 

17.08.020 - Purpose. 
    This chapter establishes a registration program to protect the city from the deterioration, crime, and decline in property value caused by properties in the foreclosure process. The city hereby requires the lender or other responsible party(ies) in the foreclosure process to register such properties with the city to protect the neighborhoods from the negative impacts of absentee ownership including lack of adequate maintenance and security. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 2, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Abatement order means an appealable order, supported by specific factual findings, issued by the code enforcement officer which directs the owner of a foreclosure property to take certain specific steps, within a specific period of time, to ensure that the relevant property is in compliance with this section. 
    Code enforcement department means the department of the code enforcement officer as defined in CMC 2.58.020. 
    Enforcement officer means the code enforcement officer as defined in CMC 2.58. 
    Evidence of foreclosure status means any condition that on its own or combined with other conditions present would lead a reasonable person to believe that the property is a foreclosure property. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, overgrown and/or dead vegetation; accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers and/or mail; past due utility notices and/or disconnected utilities; accumulation of trash, junk, and/or debris; statements by neighbors, passersby, delivery agents, or government employees that the property is in foreclosure; the presence of boards over doors, windows or other openings in violation of applicable building code; and for residential properties, the absence of window coverings such as curtains, blinds, and/or shutters; the absence of furnishings and/or personal items consistent with residential habitation. 
    Foreclosure means the legal processes described in Title 61, Revised Code of Washington, in which a mortgagee or other lien holder terminates a property owner's equitable right of redemption to obtain legal and equitable title to the real property pledged as security for a debt or the real property subject to the lien. For purposes of this section, the foreclosure process is not concluded until the property obtained by the mortgagee, lien holder, or their designee, by certificate of title or other means, is sold to a non-related, bona fide purchaser in an arms'-length transaction to satisfy the debt or lien. 
    Foreclosure property means a property that is: 
(1)  Under a current notice of default and/or notice of trustee's sale; 
(2)  The subject of a pending tax assessor's lien sale; 
(3)  The subject of a foreclosure sale where the title was retained by the beneficiary of a deed of trust involved in the foreclosure; 
(4)  A property title to which has been transferred under a deed in lieu of foreclosure/sale; or 
(5)  Subject to a contract forfeiture. 
Property acquired by Spokane County at a tax foreclosure sale under chapter 84.64 RCW is not "foreclosure property" within the meaning of this section. For purposes of this section, a property remains a foreclosure property until it is sold at an arms'-length transaction to a non-related bona fide purchaser or until the foreclosure action has been dismissed and any default has been cured. 
    Lender means any person who makes, extends, holds, or services a real estate loan agreement and includes, but is not limited to, mortgagees; beneficiaries under deeds of trust; underwriters under deeds of trust; vendors under conditional land sales contracts; trustees and a successor in interest to any mortgagee, beneficiary, vendor or trustee and any other lien holder on the property. The term also includes any mortgagee, beneficiary or trustee that accepts a deed in lieu of foreclosure. 
    Local agent means an individual property manager, property management company, or similar person or entity, regardless of location of business or residence, and responsible for, having the authority to make decisions and required expenditures concerning, the maintenance and security of a foreclosure property and the abatement of nuisance conditions at the property. 
    Owner means any individual or group of natural persons, partnership, association, corporation or other entity having legal or beneficial title in real property including any borrower. 
    Property means any unimproved or improved, residential or commercial real property, or portion thereof, situated in the city, and includes the buildings or structures located on the property regardless of condition. 
    Responsible party means any person, partnership, association, corporation, or fiduciary having legal or equitable title to or any interest in any real property, including, but not limited to, an owner, borrower, and lender as defined in this section. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 3, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.040 - Establishment of a registry. 
    The City of Cheney Code Enforcement Department shall establish and maintain a foreclosure property registry to implement this chapter. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 4, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.050 - Registration of foreclosure properties. 
    Foreclosure property shall be registered as follows: 
(a)  By the enforcement officer. 
(b)  By any lender or other responsible party(ies) of a foreclosure property as defined in this section within ten days of the property becoming a foreclosure property upon initial inspection or following receipt of notice from the city and every 12 months thereafter until the property is no longer a foreclosure property. A separate registration is required for each property. 
(c)  The content of the registration shall include: 
(1)  Proof of ownership, or financial interest, such as a lien or loan; 
(2)  The name, address, phone number, and email address for the owner, lender, and responsible party and 24-hour contact phone number of the local agent of the respective entity; and 
(3)  Documentation which demonstrates the property is foreclosed, pending foreclosure, or subject to foreclosure, trustee's sale, tax assessor's lien sale or other legal proceedings. 
(d)  The lender, owner, or responsible party shall notify the code enforcement officer within ten days of the date of any change in the information contained in the registration. 
(e)  Mortgagees who have existing foreclosure properties on the effective date of this ordinance have 30 calendar days from the effective date to register the property with City of Cheney Code Enforcement Department. A separate registration is required for each property. 
(f)  All property registrations are valid for one year from the date of entry of registration as recorded by the City of Cheney Code Enforcement Department. Subsequent registrations are due every 12 months thereafter for renewal and must certify required registration data is current and correct. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 5, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.060 - Minimum property maintenance requirements. 
    While a foreclosure property is registered, the lender or responsible party shall be required to: 
(a)  Maintain and keep foreclosure property free of conditions including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Weeds, dry brush, dead vegetation, trash, junk, debris, building materials and junk vehicles; 
(2)  Accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers, notices (except those required by federal, state, or local law), and discarded personal items including, but not limited to, furniture, clothing, or large and small appliances; and 
(3)  Graffiti, tagging, or similar markings by removal or painting over with an exterior grade paint that matches and/or coordinates with the color of the exterior of the structure; 
(b)  Secure ponds, pools and hot tubs and ensure that they do not become a public nuisance; 
(c)  Secure the foreclosure property to prevent access by unauthorized persons, including, but not limited to, the following: The closure and locking of windows, doors (walk-through, sliding and garage), gates, and any other opening of such size that it may allow a child or any other person to access the interior of the property and or structure(s). Securing also includes boarding as applicable. Preferred material for boarding shall be painted with an exterior grade paint that matches and/or coordinates with the color of the exterior of the structure, or is of a material that mimics glazed windows and intact doors; 
(d)  Post the property with no trespassing signs and current emergency contact information for the local agent; 
(e)  Take any other action necessary to prevent giving the appearance that the property is abandoned; and 
(f)  Monitor the foreclosure property monthly or more frequently as necessary to prevent the creation of a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 6, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.070 - Monitoring of foreclosure property. 
(a)  Upon registration, the city will provide regular monitoring of foreclosure properties including, but not limited to, periodic site visitation, which will not exceed the city's rights of access as well as notification to lender or responsible party if the property begins to exhibit characteristics established in RCW 35.80.010. The city's monitoring of foreclosure properties does not relieve the lender or other responsible party from monitoring and maintaining the property as required by this section. 
(b)  At least monthly while a foreclosure property is registered, the lender or responsible party shall inspect the foreclosure property. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 7, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.080 - Waiver for city to abatement-Trespass of unauthorized individuals. 
(a)  As part of the foreclosure property registration, the owner, lender, local agent, responsible party, or other person having the legal authority to do so shall waive any objection to the city entering onto the property for purposes of abating any condition that would constitute an unfit or substandard building as established in RCW 35.80.010, or any condition deemed a property maintenance violation under CMC Title 17, and to issue a trespass order against any unauthorized individual from the foreclosure property. 
(b)  The city shall notify the owner, lender, responsible party, or local agent ten days prior to the city taking abatement action in order to allow the owner, lender, responsible party, or local agent to abate the condition first unless such abatement constitutes an emergency, in which case, the city may abate the emergency immediately. 
(c)  The cost of the abatement of any of the illustrative conditions contained in section 17.08.060 above shall be charged against the foreclosure property pursuant to CMC 17.06.070 and shall be lienable pursuant to CMC 17.16.010 and other applicable sections of the municipal code pursuant to state law. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 8, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.090 - Local agent. 
    The lender or responsible party shall provide the city with the name, address, telephone number, email address and 24-hour contact information of a local agent who has the authority to act to respond to complaints regarding the foreclosure property and to remedy any nuisance, substandard or unfit conditions found on the property. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 9, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.100 - Annual foreclosure property registration fee. 
    The lender or responsible party shall pay the annual non-refundable foreclosure property registration fee as set forth by City of Cheney Fee Resolution. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 10, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.110 - Policies and procedures. 
    The City of Cheney Code Enforcement Department shall develop procedures to implement this section which are consistent with and do not conflict with this section, the Cheney Municipal Code, or Washington law. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 11, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.120 - Violation. 
(a)  Any person, firm or entity who fails to a foreclosure property pursuant to the requirements of this section shall be subject to a class 1 civil infraction. Each day in which a foreclosure property which is subject to this section is not registered shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  Failure to maintain a foreclosure property as required by this section is a criminal misdemeanor violation under CMC 17.06.090 for maintaining a nuisance property in addition to applicable penalties for nuisance conditions in the municipal code or state law. 
(c)  Failure to provide notification of changes in ownership of a foreclosure property under this section is a class 1 civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 12, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.130 - Removal of properties from the registry. 
(a)  A property may only be removed from the foreclosure property registry upon the lender's, owner's, or responsible party's written certification that: 
(1)  The mortgage or lien on the property has been satisfied or legally discharged; 
(2)  The property is no longer in mortgage default; or 
(3)  The foreclosure property has been sold to a non-related party in a bona-fide, arms'-length transaction. 
(b)  A lender's statement that it no longer desires to pursue foreclosure, has filed a dismissal of lis pendens and/or summary of final judgment and/or certificate of title or otherwise, such as deed in lieu of foreclosure shall not be the basis for removal of a foreclosure property from the registry under this section. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, a transfer to another entity which is under common ownership with the lender, as determined in the sole discretion of the City of Cheney Code Enforcement Department, is not an arms'-length transaction. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 13, 1-22-2019) 
17.08.140 - Transfer of ownership. 
(a)  If the mortgage on a registered foreclosure property is transferred, the transferee shall be subject to the requirements of this section and shall, within five days of the transfer of the mortgage, register the property as a new registration in accordance with this section. Any previously unpaid registration fees are the responsibility of the transferee and are due and payable upon the new registration. 
(b)  If the mortgagee sells a foreclosure property in an arms'-length transaction to a non-related person or entity, the transferee is subject to the terms of this section and shall register the property as a new registration under this section within five days of the sale. Any previously unpaid registration fees shall be the responsibility of the new owner. 
(Ord. No. X-37, § 14, 1-22-2019) 
CHAPTER 17.18 - NUISANCES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. X-45, adopted Jan. 22, 2019, directed for the renumbering of ch. 19.18, §§ 19.18.010-19.18.200 as ch. 17.18, §§ 17.18.010-17.18.200. Original history has been maintained. 

17.18.010 - Intent of chapter. 
    The intent of the city council in enacting this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method to cause owner(s) and occupant(s) of property or their agent to remove junk, junk cars and nuisances from property within the city. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.010), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words used herein are defined as follows: 
    Abate means to repair, remove, destroy or to otherwise remedy an unlawful condition, by such means and in such manner as is necessary in the interests of the general health, safety and welfare of the community. 
    Enforcement officer shall include the building official, fire chief, police chief, police officer, director of community development, director of public works, code enforcement officer, deputy code enforcement officer, and the city administrator. 
    Garbage means all waste and residue from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food and food products including, but not limited to, discarded food wrappings and containers, paper, plastic and metal products used or intended for use in connection with the storage, sale, preparation or "clean-up" relating to food items; egg shells; used coffee grounds; used tea bags; meat trimmings; entrails of animals, poultry or fish; offal; medical wastes including bandages, syringes, medicines, plaster or other casts; and decomposed putrid material; whether such items are alone or in combination with other materials. 
    Junk means all articles such as appliances and furniture, parts thereof, boxes, cardboard, paper, glass, old wood, tires on or off rims, wheels, mattresses, bed springs or other bedding, growing or severed hay, grass, straw or weeds, litter or combustible or flammable waste or rubbish, building materials and similar articles and materials, crates, pallets, packing cases, scrap iron, wire, tin, ashes, bric-a-brac, broken glass, broken plaster and all such trash or abandoned materials or anything whatsoever in which flies, mosquitoes, vermin, or rats may breed (unless they are kept in receptacles as required by ordinance). This also includes all trash and debris other than which has been collected to await arrival of the city's garbage collector. As used in this chapter, the term "junk" refers only to materials left outside of any building and does not apply to material stored inside a lawfully constructed building so long as such building is wholly enclosed except for doors for ingress and egress. 
    Junk vehicle means a vehicle meeting at least three of the following requirements: 
(1)  Is three years old or older; 
(2)  Is extensively damaged, such damage including, but not limited to, any of the following: A broken window or missing windshield or missing wheels, tires, motor, or transmission; 
(3)  Is apparently inoperable; or 
(4)  Has an approximate fair market value equal only to the approximate value of the scrap value. 
    Owner means any person owning property, as shown on the real property records of Spokane County or on the last assessment roll for taxes, and shall also mean any lessee, tenant, occupant or other person having control or possession of the property. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, joint venture, partnership, estate, trust, limited liability company, association, government, governmental subdivision, agency, instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity. 
    Nuisance consists in doing an unlawful act, or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(1)  Annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any stream, public park, parkway square, street or highway in the city; 
(5)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life and use of property; or 
(6)  Obstructs the free use of property so as to essentially interfere with comfortable enjoyment of life and property. 
    Premises means any building, lot, parcel, real estate or land or portion of land, whether improved or unimproved, including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Vehicle means a motorized or non-motorized vehicle or device for carrying passengers, goods, or equipment, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, bicycles, boats, tractors, campers, trailers, or devices of a similar nature or and components of such devices. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.020), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.030 - Unlawful to store junk and junk vehicles. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person or owner of any premises in the city or the owner's agent or occupant of any premises to store, keep or accumulate junk or junk vehicles on such property, or allow anyone else to store, keep or accumulate junk or junk vehicles on such property. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.030), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.040 - Illegal dumping. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person, company or organization to dump any material within the city limits, except at licensed solid waste disposal facilities. Whenever waste material dumped in violation of this chapter contains three or more items bearing the name of one individual, there shall be a permissible inference that the individual whose name appears on such items committed the unlawful act of dumping and littering. The only exception is dirt or fill and then it can only be dumped at a location specified on an excavation and grading permit issued by the City of Cheney Building Department or associated with a public works project. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.040), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.050 - Nuisances designated. 
    The following specific acts, omissions, places, conditions and things, including, but not limited to these, are declared to be nuisances: 
(1)  The erecting, maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain in or upon and private lot, building, structure or premises, or upon any street, avenue, alley, parkway, or other public or private place in the city, of any one or more of the following: unsanitary; rodent, vermin, or other wild animal harboring or attracting; mosquito, insect attracting; or, fly producing, disease-causing conditions; places or things, that is to say: 
a.  Any putrid, unsound or unwholesome bones, meat, hides, skins, or the whole or any part of any dead animal, fish, or fowl; 
b.  Privies, vaults, cesspools, sumps, pit, or like places which are not securely protected from flies, or rats etc., which are foul or malodorous; 
c.  Filthy, littered or trash covered cellars, house yards, barnyards, stable-yards, factory-yards, manufacturing-yards, vacant areas, in rear of stores, vacant lots, houses, buildings or premises; 
d.  Animal manure in any quantity which is not secured, protected from flies and the elements, or is kept or handled in violation of any ordinance of the city; or 
e.  Liquid household waste, human excreta, garbage, butcher's trimming and offal, parts of fish or any waste vegetable or animal matter in any quantity; provided that nothing herein contained shall prevent the temporary retention of waste in receptacles in the manner provided by the health officer, or the dumping of non-putrefying waste in a place and manner approved by the health officer. 
(2)  The erecting, maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain in or upon and private lot, building, structure or premises, or upon any street, avenue, alley, parkway, drive or any private driveway or other public or private place in the city, of any one or more of the following: unsanitary; rodent, vermin, or other wild animal harboring or attracting; mosquito, insect attracting; or, fly producing, disease-causing conditions; places or things, that is to say: 
a.  Tin cans, bottles, cans, ashes, small pieces of scrap iron, wire and metal articles, bric-a-brac, broken stone or cement, broken crockery, broken glass, broken plaster and all such trash and abandoned materials unless they are kept in receptacles as required by ordinance; 
b.  Trash, litter, rags, accumulations of empty barrels, boxes, cardboard, crates, packing cases, pallets, mattresses, bed springs, bedding, excelsior, packing straw, hay or other packing material, lumber, scrap iron, tin, and other metal or anything whatsoever in which flies, mosquitoes, rats or other rodents may breed or multiply or which may be a fire danger, or which constitutes a hazardous attraction to children; 
(3)  Any unsightly building, billboard, or other structure, or any old, abandoned or partially destroyed building or structure, or any building or structure commenced and left unfinished for a period of more than 365 days; 
(4)  The keeping or storing of bed mattresses, bed springs or other bedding, toilets, bathtubs, sinks, water heaters, cloths washers, cloth driers, ovens/ranges or other household appliances, and damaged or stored or discarded furniture and other household goods or items including indoor furniture left outdoors, including carports and non-enclosed porches and decks, in a residential zone or other zone within the city where such items are inconsistent with permitted uses authorized within the zone; 
(5)  All places used or maintained as junkyards, or dumping grounds, for the wrecking or dismantling of vehicles, or machinery of any kind, or for the storing or leaving of any worn out, wrecked or abandoned vehicles or machinery of any kind, or of any of the parts, tires and wheels whether on or off rims, thereof, or for the leaving or storing of any machinery or equipment used by contractors or builders or by others and which are not outlawed by zoning ordinances of the city; 
(6)  Any underground or abandoned pit, excavation, shaft, well or other uncovered hole into which a person could fall; 
(7)  The dropping or placing on any street, alley, drive or any private driveway, park or thoroughfare of any tree trimmings leaves, grass, garden debris, dirt, rock, crushed rock, sand, gravel, bricks, ashes or any foreign substance of any kind whatsoever; 
(8)  Any refrigerator, freezer, or other insulated container within which a child could suffocate pursuant to RCW chapter 9.03; 
(9)  Any sign, poster or other advertising matter of any nature placed upon any telegraph, telephone, electrical distribution pole or other poles, trees, sidewalks, streets, signs, or other traffic control devices or other structures or places within the streets, alleys or other public places or rights-of-way which are not allowed by ordinances of the city; 
(10)  Any building, house, room or other structure or vehicle, maintained or used for the purpose of lewdness, assignation, or prostitution; 
(11)  All houses, rooms, booths or other structures used as a place of resort where disorderly persons are allowed to congregate, or which drunkenness is carried on or permitted; 
(12)  Toxic, radioactive, caustic, flammable, explosive or other dangerous or hazardous substances, except for as housed where applicable and stored in accordance with health, environmental, fire, refuse and zoning laws; 
(13)  Throwing, emptying or depositing, or allowing to be thrown, emptied, or deposited into any privately or publicly owned refuse can, dumpster, or other receptacle, any hazardous or dangerous substances; 
(14)  Maintaining or allowing to grow trees, plants, shrubs, or vegetation, or parts thereof, which overhang any sidewalk or street or which are growing thereon in such a manner as to obstruct or impair the free and full use of the sidewalk or street by the public, or block or impair the reasonable public view of traffic, street, or informational signs; 
(15)  The growing, permitting, or allowing the growth of any grass, noxious weeds as established by RCW chapter 17.10, or uncultivated bushes and/or vines to exceed ten inches in height, or any rank vegetable growth which exudes unpleasant or noxious odors, in areas of the city other than those which have been, or shall be designated as agricultural areas pursuant to the zoning ordinance of the city. When total removal of growth from a piece of property is impractical due to size, or to environmental factors, approved fuel breaks may be established between the land and the endangered property. The width of the fuel break shall be determined by the height, type, and the amount of growth, wind conditions, geographical conditions, and type of exposures threatened, as determined by the fire chief or fire marshal; 
(16)  Maintaining or keeping a junk vehicle or parts thereof in the city, except in an authorized wrecking yard as established by the City of Cheney Zoning Code; 
(17)  Every person owning, occupying or controlling any premises bordering any street, alley or public place in the city limits of Cheney and allowing or permitting the growth of any grass, weeds or uncultivated bushes and/or vines to exceed ten inches in height, or any rank vegetable growth which exudes unpleasant or noxious odors between the property line of such property and the street. 
(18)  All partially burned structures that exist within 30 days of the date of the event burning the structure and no evidence of clearing of refuse, debris, charred lumber, or rehabilitation occurs. For structures that are destroyed in their entirety and incapable of rehabilitation, all debris, refuse, material or charred lumber must be removed within 60 days of the date of the event burning the structure. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.050), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.060 - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any owner or person to permit, maintain, suffer, carry on or allow, upon any premises located within city limits, any of the acts or things declared by this chapter to be a nuisance. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, by itself or by its agents or employees, or as the agent or employee of another person, firm or corporation, to do or permit to be done upon any premises over which it has control, or to maintain, carry on, suffer or allow, at any place or places in the preceding sections mentioned, any of the acts or things herein declared to be nuisances, or to do or cause, or permit or suffer to be done, or maintain any act or thing which shall be detrimental or injurious to public health or offensive to the senses or contrary to public decency or morality. 
(Ord. No. X-45, § 1, 1-22-2019; Ord. No. U-95, § 3(19.18.060), 3-10-2009) 
17.18.070 - Voluntary correction agreement. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies whenever the enforcement officer determines that a violation of this chapter has occurred or is occurring.
